Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: NEW YORK - Oil settled up nearly 3 percent on Friday after a weak U.S. jobs report hurt the dollar and boosted commodities, but crude prices still ended the week sharply lower on concerns about oversupply.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: U.S. employment growth eased more than expected in August after two straight months of robust gains, the report showed.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: That initially led to doubts that the Federal Reserve would hike interest rates at its Sept. 20-21 meeting. The dollar, however, rose later in the day on bets that a September rate hike remained on the cards. [FRX/]

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: Crude prices were also supported by a steadying U.S. oil rig count.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: After being unchanged last week, the oil rig count provided by industry firm Baker Hughes rose by just one this week as crude prices held below the key $50-a-barrel mark that analysts and drillers said made drilling more viable. [RIG/U]

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: "Notwithstanding today's dollar-driven rally, September is usually a weak time for oil with demand coming off the peak summer period. So if the rig count stays steady, we could finish the year at about $50," said Jay Hatfield of New York-based InfraCap MLP EFT, which invests in U.S. energy projects.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: Brent crude futures <LCOc1> settled up $1.38, or 3 percent, at $46.83 a barrel. For the week, Brent was down 6 percent, its biggest drop in five weeks.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: U.S. West Texas Intermediate futures <CLc1> rose $1.28, also 3 percent, to settle at $44.44. WTI fell nearly 7 percent on the week, its largest decline in eight weeks.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: "It's quite likely oil will hold at mid-$40 levels," said Carl Larry Director, director of business development for oil & gas at Frost & Sullivan. "More telling of how oil performs will be the rig count in coming weeks and OPEC gestures to support prices."

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: In early trading on Friday, oil rose after Russian President Vladimir Putin said in a Bloomberg interview that he supported attempts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to implement an output freeze with other oil producers.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: OPEC, led by Saudi Arabia and other big Middle East crude exporters, will meet non-member producers led by Russia at informal talks in Algeria from Sept. 26 to 28 to discuss an output freeze.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: If OPEC fails to strike a deal in Algeria, the cartel is expected to try other measures to support oil prices during its policy meeting in Vienna on Nov. 30.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: Many analysts remain skeptical that it would be successful.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: "The oil price will remain volatile over the coming weeks," said Hans van Cleef, senior oil economist at ABN Amro. REUTERS

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: WASHINGTON - U.S. employment growth slowed more than expected in August after two straight months of robust gains and wages were tepid, which could effectively rule out an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve this month.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with hiring in manufacturing and construction sectors declining, the Labor Department said on Friday. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.9 percent as more people flocked to the labor market.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The report came on the heels of news on Thursday that the manufacturing sector contracted in August for the first time in six months, which had already cast a shadow on a rate hike at the Fed's Sept. 20-21 policy meeting.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Last month's jobs gains, however, could still be sufficient to push the U.S. central bank to tighten policy in December.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: "It reduces the likelihood that the Fed will raise rates in September, but the labor market remains strong enough to

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: support a rate hike in December," said John Silvia, chief economist at Wells Fargo Securities in Charlotte, North Carolina.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Economists had forecast payrolls increasing 180,000 last month and the unemployment rate slipping one-tenth of a percentage point to 4.8 percent. The payrolls rise reinforces views the economy has regained speed after almost stalling in the first half of the year.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Rate hike probabilities for both the September and December meetings rose after remarks last Friday by Fed Chair Janet Yellen that the case for raising rates had strengthened in recent months.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Financial markets on Friday were pricing in a roughly 21 percent chance of a rate hike this month and a 54.2 percent probability in December, according to the CME Fedwatch tool.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: A Reuters survey of the big banks that do business directly with the Fed showed 13 of the 14 so-called primary dealers expect a rate increase this year, with only three anticipating the move this month.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The Fed lifted its benchmark overnight interest rate at the end of last year for the first time in nearly a decade, but has held it steady since amid concerns over low inflation.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The dollar rose against a basket of currencies, while prices for U.S. government bonds fell. U.S. stocks ended higher.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Even though substantial labor market slack has been reduced, millions of Americans remain unemployed, a source of frustration that could weigh on the minds of some voters in the November presidential election.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's campaign team said the jobs numbers were a sign of a disappointing economic performance tied to what a senior campaign adviser called "Clinton globalist policies."

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: But the Democratic National Committee said the employment report was further proof of the sound economic policies of the Obama administration. The DNC said its presidential candidate, Hillary Clinton, was ready to build on that momentum and create an economy that "works for everyone, not just those at the top."

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: CALENDAR QUIRKS RESTRAIN PAYROLLS, WAGES

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The step-down in employment growth comes after the economy created a total of 546,000 jobs in June and July.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: With the labor market near full employment and the economy's recovery from the 2007-09 recession showing signs of aging, a slowdown in job growth is normal. According to Yellen, the economy needs to create just under 100,000 jobs a month to keep up with population growth.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The smaller-than-expected rise in payrolls also likely reflects difficulties adjusting the data for seasonal fluctuations related to school calendars. Over the last several years, the government's initial August payrolls estimates have been weak only to be subsequently revised higher.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: "As the August numbers have tended to come in on the softer side in the past, we think that this mostly reflects seasonal adjustment problems rather than underlying weakness," said Harm Bandholz, chief economist at UniCredit Research in New York.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The timing of the next rate hike could also be determined by wage growth. Average hourly earnings increased three cents or 0.1 percent in August after a solid 0.3 percent rise in July.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The moderation in gains, which reflects a calendar quirk, pulled down the year-on-year gain to 2.4 percent from an upwardly revised 2.7 percent in July, which was the largest rise in seven years.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Americans worked fewer hours last month, with the average workweek dipping 0.1 hour to 34.3 hours. Other details of the report showed the labor force participation rate, or the share of working-age Americans who are employed or at least looking for a job, unchanged at 62.8 percent last month.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The participation rate remains near multi-decade lows, in part reflecting demographic changes, partially explaining why wage growth has been sluggish.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Still, the payrolls gain added to July consumer spending, residential construction and durable goods orders in suggesting a pickup in economic growth after output rose 1.0 percent in the first half of the year.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: A second report from the Commerce Department on Friday showed the trade deficit fell 11.6 percent to $39.5 billion in July as soybean sales buoyed exports to a 10-month high, in another boost to the growth outlook for the third quarter.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The Atlanta Fed is forecasting gross domestic product rising at a 3.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Last month, manufacturing sector employment fell 14,000 after rising for two straight months. Construction payrolls slipped 6,000, while mining shed a further 4,000 jobs in August.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Professional and business services added 22,000 jobs last month after creating 80,000 positions in July. Retail sector employment increased by 15,100 jobs and payrolls in the leisure and hospitality sector rose 29,000.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Temporary-help jobs, a harbinger of future hiring, fell 3,100. Government payrolls rose 25,000 in August, extending the streak of job gains in the public sector to four months. REUTERS

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: SHANGHAI/HONG KONG - The Chinese government said on Friday it was investigating two high-profile takeover proposals involving U.S. companies, the latest sign of its growing influence on whether deals are approved - even those appearing to have little impact in China.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The Commerce Ministry said at a briefing on Friday it was probing ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing's planned acquisition of U.S. rival Uber Technologies Inc's <UBER.UL> China unit and Comcast Corp's <CMCSA.O> purchase of movie studio DreamWorks Animation.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The scrutiny, announced the day before world leaders descend on China's eastern city of Hangzhou for a meeting of the Group of 20, underscores the ministry's increasingly tough stance on companies that strike deals without seeking its approval.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The Chinese are increasingly using their regulatory might to gain influence in the global economy, according to one expert in international relations.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "DreamWorks and Comcast barely touch China, but it's a way to assert their new position in the world. They want to remind us, 'We're big and you have to pay attention to us,'" said Jim Lewis, of Washington’s Center for Strategic and International Studies think tank.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: A representative of the U.S. Department of State declined comment and referred queries to China's Commerce Ministry.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: There had not been a filing for the Didi-Uber deal, the ministry said last month. Comcast already said it had completed the deal for DreamWorks, which may indicate it did not think it needed to wait for Chinese approval.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry requires companies to notify it of transactions before they close if those merging have combined global turnover in the previous year exceeding 10 billion yuan ($1.5 billion) or their combined China income exceeds 2 billion yuan ($300 million).

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Didi said its deal did not trigger these thresholds, while lawyers said they were surprised that the DreamWorks deal was being probed given its small China footprint.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "With the DreamWorks-Comcast deal, I was kind of surprised," said Wendy Yan, Shanghai-based partner at Faegre Baker Daniels.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry said it had launched the investigation into the takeover following unspecified complaints that the combination of Comcast, one of the largest U.S. cable and broadcasting groups, with the movie studio could hurt competition in the Chinese market.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "I'd be interested to know who made such complaints and how exactly the (Comcast-DreamWorks) merger would affect the China market because they are not in a dominant position," added Yan.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: A representative for Comcast declined to comment on the Chinese probe.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Comcast, owner of NBCUniversal, said in April it would buy DreamWorks, the producer of the "Kung Fu Panda" and "Shrek" franchises, for $3.8 billion. DreamWorks was one of the first Hollywood names to open a production studio in China and NBCUniversal in 2014 announced plans to open a $3.3-billion Universal theme park in Beijing.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: China's film market, the world's second largest, is a magnet for movie producers looking to tap the country's 1.4 billion people, even though there are signs that stellar box office growth may be starting to slow.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Comcast announced the completion of the DreamWorks deal last week. The ministry has the power to fine companies it believes should have sought clearance, and can also force them to sell assets to get approval, or even to unwind transactions

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "If (Comcast) didn't file and they should have filed, this will be resolved with a fine and a press release," said Bruce McDonald, a veteran of the U.S. Department of Justice, now at law firm Jones Day. "Is this China just being tough on a U.S. company? I don't think so, it might be them being sticklers for following Chinese filing rules."

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: CONSUMER ANGER

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Lawyers said that the Didi deal to buy Uber's China unit had caused a stir among local consumers and rivals. The two ride-hailing firms were already the number one and two top players together controlling around 90 percent of the market.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry had signaled its discontent with the two companies last month because they had not filed a merger application to the regulator.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: A representative for Uber referred questions to Didi. A Didi spokeswoman said: "We are in communication with the authorities."

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Consumer groups and rivals have warned that fares could rise steeply if the two companies join forces. Both Uber and Didi had spent billions of dollars subsidizing fares in a price war to lure riders and drivers.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Marc Waha, head of the antitrust practice at Norton Rose Fulbright in Hong Kong, said a key concern for the ministry would be the elimination of Uber as a competitor to Didi.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "If the market is considered to only comprise those two car hailing services, the transaction could be seen as a merger from two-to-one, which is likely to be problematic, however small the target is."

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "Very often a small target acts as a maverick on the market, leading to low prices," he added.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry has developed a reputation globally as a tough regulator, but it has only blocked two transactions since China's antimonopoly law came into force in 2008, compared with 1,447 unconditional clearances, Norton Rose data shows.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Faegre Baker Daniels's Yan added, however, Chinese regulators could end up with a deluge of new deals to work through if the latest probes were a sign of things to come.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "If the China government reaches out its hands too far they may need to deal with things they are not able to do and they need to have the manpower to review all these global mergers which may not have China implications," she said. REUTERS

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: SINGAPORE — Manufacturing activity in the Republic shrank for the 14th straight month in August, although the pace of contraction slowed as the electronics sector posted its first expansion in more than a year.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: The Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) came in at 49.8 last month, 0.5 point higher than in July, showed data from the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management. The 50-point mark separates expansion and contraction. The improvement was due to higher new orders and new exports, as well as higher factory output and employment.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: The electronics sub-index — which contributes to one-third of the Republic’s manufacturing performance — expanded for the first time since June last year, increasing 0.5 point from the previous month to 50.2, due to higher new orders, new export orders and factory output.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: “Previously, the electronics sector was a drag to overall manufacturing but now it is actually helping … while the other sectors continue to be challenging,” said Mr Song Seng Wun, CIMB Private Banking economist.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: “Typically the electronics industry tends to lead the broader manufacturing sector, so the electronics PMI’s return to expansion territory, if sustained over the coming months, would definitely be a welcome signal,” said Ms Selena Ling, head of treasury research & strategy, OCBC Bank.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: Despite the life seen in electronics, economists still view the broad picture for manufacturing as difficult, due to soft global demand.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: Regionally, PMIs are a mixed bag. Last month, the PMIs for Vietnam, India, Taiwan stayed in the expansion zone, while Malaysia and Thailand contracted.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: The private sector Caixin/Markit Chinese manufacturing PMI, which focuses on small- and medium-sized firms, dropped 0.6 point from July to 50 points. The official Chinese PMI, which mostly covers larger state-owned manufacturers, improved 0.5 point from the previous month to 50.4 points.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: “Overall, the manufacturing sector remains challenging,” said Mr Song. “We are essentially faced with a difficult operating environment where external demand remains soft. Generally, Asian PMIs improved slightly but just marginally. China is still fairly uninspiring in manufacturing activities.” ANGELA TENG

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: NEW YORK/WILMINGTON, Del. - A Delaware judge on Friday granted a motion to expedite Alere Inc's <ALR.N> lawsuit against Abbott Laboratories <ABT.N>, which seeks to ensure that Abbott lives up to the terms of its $5.8 billion takeover of the diagnostics company, representatives for Alere said.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: Alere filed suit last week in the Delaware Court of Chancery, arguing that Abbott is trying to stymie the deal by purposefully delaying key submissions to anti-trust regulators. Abbott denies the charges.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: Delaware Vice Chancellor Sam Glasscock did not say when a trial would be held and did not address hearing dates. Instead he ordered the parties to go back to their clients and ask if they would consider mediation.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: Former Chancellor William Chandler is available to be a mediator, according to the judge.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: "The judge’s suggestion that the parties work together is helpful and we look forward to engaging in that process," Abbott said in a statement. "Abbott continues to be compliant with its obligations under the merger agreement."

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: An Alere spokesperson said the company was pleased with the court's decision.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: Abbott agreed to acquire Alere in February. In late April, Abbott struck an even bigger deal to buy St. Jude Medical <STJ.N> to position itself as the dominant player in the market for cardiovascular devices.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: After the St. Jude deal was announced, Alere said in a filing that it had declined an offer from Abbott to pay it up to $50 million to break off their merger agreement.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: Alere claims in its complaint that Abbott is motivated to end its deal with Alere in order to free up capital for its $24 billion takeover of St. Jude.

Headline: Delaware judge expedites Alere lawsuit against Abbott
Text: Abbott has said it is in compliance with the deal and that Alere's financial problems and related delays in filing its financial statements had slowed its progress. REUTERS

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: NEW YORK - U.S. shares inched higher and European shares rallied on Friday after weaker-than-expected U.S. jobs data gave the Federal Reserve more leeway to stand pat on interest rates, while the dollar gained and longer-dated Treasury yields edged up.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: U.S. nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs in August after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with job cuts in manufacturing and construction, the Labor Department said. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast payrolls rising 180,000 last month.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Fed funds futures on Friday suggested traders saw a 21-percent probability of a Fed rate hike later this month, down from Thursday's probability of 24 percent, according to CME Group's FedWatch program.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Rate hike probabilities for September and December had risen after last Friday's remarks by Fed Chair Janet Yellen that the case for raising rates had strengthened in recent months.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: U.S. and European share markets cheered the jobs figures' implication that the Fed may wait until December to act.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: "People are taking a little bit of a relief that it wasn’t a 200,000 plus print, certainly in the equity market," said Sean Lynch, co-head of global equity strategy at Wells Fargo Investment Institute in Omaha, Nebraska.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: MSCI's all-country world equity index <.MIWD00000PUS> was last up 2.94 points, or 0.7 percent, at 420.29.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: The Dow Jones industrial average <.DJI> closed up 72.66 points, or 0.39 percent, at 18,491.96. The S&P 500 <.SPX> ended up 9.12 points, or 0.42 percent, at 2,179.98. The Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> closed up 22.69 points, or 0.43 percent, at 5,249.90. [nL1N1BE1KT]

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Europe's broad FTSEurofirst 300 index <.FTEU3> closed up 2.06 percent, at 1,378.94.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: For the week, the S&P 500 rose 0.5 percent to mark its first positive week in three, while the FTSEurofirst 300 posted its second straight week of gains and its biggest since mid-July, at 1.9 percent.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Despite the jobs data not clearly reinforcing a September rate hike, the dollar gained on the prospect of a December rate increase.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: The dollar index <.DXY>, which measures the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, was last up 0.21 percent at 95.850 after hitting a one-week low of 95.189 immediately after the data. [nL1N1BE1BU]

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Safe-haven U.S. Treasuries prices initially rallied on the U.S. jobs data, with two-year yields <US2YT=RR> falling to their lowest in 10 days of 0.746 percent and benchmark 10-year yields hitting a one-week low of 1.543 percent <US10YT=RR>.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: But yields reversed that drop later in the session, with two-year yields last little changed at 0.794 percent and 10-year yields last at 1.601 percent, compared with a 10-year yield of 1.570 percent late on Thursday. [nL1N1BE1ET]

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: "We’re in a low-expectation environment and these numbers are still positive," said Ellis Phifer, market strategist at Raymond James in Memphis, Tennessee, in reference to the U.S. jobs data.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: The dollar's initial weakness helped prompt gains in oil prices, though despite the day's rise, crude prices still ended the week sharply lower on concerns about oversupply.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Brent crude <LCOc1> settled up $1.38, or 3.04 percent, at $46.83 a barrel. U.S. crude <CLc1> settled up $1.28, or 2.97 percent, at $44.44 a barrel.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: For the week, Brent fell 6 percent, its biggest drop in five weeks, while U.S. crude fell nearly 7 percent to mark its largest decline in eight weeks.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: U.S. gold futures <GCcv1> settled up 0.7 percent at $1,326.70. [nL8N1BE20K] REUTERS

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: NEW YORK - Wall Street's biggest banks are sticking to bets that the U.S. Federal Reserve will raise interest rates once this year, and the increase would most likely occur in December after a tepid employment report for August quashed most talk of a move as early as this month.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Economists for 13 out of 14 primary dealers who responded to a Reuters poll on Friday said they expect the Fed to lift the targeted range for its benchmark short-term interest rate by a quarter-percentage point to a median level of 0.63 percent by year end. The current mid-point for the federal funds rate is 0.38 percent.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Friday's outcome is broadly in line with the results of a poll one month ago. Then, 14 of 21 primary dealers, or firms that do business directly with the Fed, had forecast a year-end federal funds rate of 0.63 percent.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Economists in Friday's poll assigned a median probability for a rate hike at the Sept. 20-21 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy-setting body, of just 35 percent. That probability rises to 63 percent by year end.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: By contrast, market-based forecasting tools, such as federal funds futures, imply a less-than 25 percent probability of the Fed hiking this month and just over 50 percent by December.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: The economists were polled following Friday's monthly payrolls report, which showed U.S. employers added fewer-than-expected workers in August.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with hiring in manufacturing and construction sectors declining, the Labor Department said on Friday. Analysts had expected payrolls to rise by 180,000.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: The unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.9 percent as more people flocked to the labor market.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Of the 13 banks forecasting a rate rise this year, just three - Goldman Sachs, BNP Paribas and Societe General - see it occurring as early as this month.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: For Goldman Sachs and Societe General, that represented an acceleration in their view of the Fed's next tightening move, even as the U.S. employment report for August came in well below target.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Goldman Sachs Chief Economist Jan Hatzius said in a note that while the August employment report featured some soft elements, it still would be "just enough" to induce the Fed to move later this month. He placed a 55 percent probability on the Fed raising its rate at its next meeting compared with just a 30 percent probability in the prior poll.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Looking beyond December, nine of the 12 economists forecast at least two rate increases next year, with a median forecast for the rate by December 2017 of 1.13 percent. REUTERS

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: SEOUL - Samsung Electronics Co Ltd has recalled all Galaxy Note 7 smartphones equipped with batteries it has found to be fire-prone and halted their sales in 10 markets, denting a revival of the firm's mobile business.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Koh Dong-jin, head of the South Korean company's smartphone business, declined to comment on how many phones needed to be replaced, but said Samsung had sold 2.5 million of the premium devices so far.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Speaking at a news conference on Friday, Koh expressed regret over the recall, which will affect markets including South Korea and the United States. Models in China feature a different battery and are not being recalled by Samsung, the world's biggest smartphone vendor.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The recall comes just over two weeks after the company launched its latest premium phone, which features an outsized screen and high-resolution camera. It follows reports of the 988,900 won ($885) phone igniting while charging.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The manufacturer plans to replace not only phones with faulty batteries sold to consumers, but also retailer inventories and units in transit. Nomura estimated that more than 1 million units have been sold to end consumers.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: "I can't comment on exactly how much the cost will be, but it pains my heart that it will be such a big number," Koh said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Strategy Analytics said the combined cost of the recall and lost sales would lop $5 billion off Samsung's smartphone revenue this year and cut smartphone profit margin by 1.5 percent.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The scale of the recall is unprecedented for Samsung, which prides itself on its manufacturing prowess. While recalls in the smartphone industry do happen, including for rival Apple Inc, the nature of the problem for the Galaxy Note 7 is a serious blow to Samsung's reputation, analysts said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The company should act quickly to minimize damage to its smartphone recovery, after a string of product successes had reversed a fall in market share, they added.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: CUSTOMERS PUT ON HOLD

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The phone first launched in 10 markets in North America, Asia and the Middle East. Further roll-outs have occurred since in markets like China, where sales started just this week. Its wider availability, set for coming weeks, is now on hold.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: While there are occasional reports of phones catching fire or otherwise burning users, documented cases that lead to widespread product recalls remain relatively rare. Samsung said it was aware of 35 reports of affected Note 7 batteries.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: In 2007, the largest battery recall in consumer electronics history took place when Nokia, then the world's top mobile handset maker, offered to replace 46 million phone batteries produced for it by Japanese maker Matsushita Battery.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Germany's biggest operator, Deutsche Telekom, said it had stopped delivering orders for the Galaxy Note 7, while French operator Orange said on its website that it had stopped pre-sales of the phone and postponed its planned sales launch - scheduled for Friday.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: In Britain, mobile carriers EE and Vodafone continue to accept pre-orders for the Note 7 on their sites. A Vodafone spokesman said its planned Sept. 19 sales launch could now slip, but the company was waiting for more details from Samsung to decide.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: U.S. operators have been taking pre-orders since early August. All major wireless carriers, including No. 1 U.S. wireless provider Verizon Communications Inc, said they had stopped selling the Galaxy Note 7. Samsung said in a separate statement it started an exchange program in the country for the Note 7.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Major U.S. retailers Best Buy and Target also said they had halted sales of the Note 7.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Verizon said that if a customer wants to return or exchange the Galaxy Note 7, it would waive through Sept. 30 the restocking fee it charges customers. T-Mobile US, majority owned by Deutsche Telekom, said in a statement it would also waive restocking and shipping charges to customers who want to return the recalled phone.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: SECOND-HALF HOPES

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Samsung has said it aimed for the Note 7 to maintain strong sales momentum in the second half of the year against stiffening competition from the likes of Apple, which is widely expected to release its latest iPhone next week.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Strategy Analytics said Samsung will likely sell fewer than 10 million Note 7s this year compared with its previous estimate of 14 million globally.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Samsung said new sales of the Note 7 in affected markets would resume after it deals with replacements, a process it expects will begin in about two weeks. The firm would extend refund periods for affected customers and offer exchanges for other Samsung phones, Koh said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Investors sold Samsung shares after the delay announcement on Thursday, stripping about $7 billion from the firm's market value, which remains just off recent record highs. Sentiment recovered somewhat in trading on Friday as the shares rose 0.6 percent compared with 0.3 percent in the broader market.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Credit Suisse said a recall or major shipment delays could wipe 1.5 trillion won ($1.34 billion) from Samsung's 2016 operating profit estimate of 30.2 trillion won in an "absolute worst case" scenario.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: But the brokerage said that scenario was unlikely, as it expected Samsung to resolve the problem before the fourth quarter.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: HI Securities analyst James Song said the replacement costs may be somewhat limited as Samsung could recycle components of the recalled phones.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: "It is clever for Samsung to replace the affected models, not offering fixes," he said, adding this would help consumer confidence.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Samsung's mobile division accounted for about 54 percent of the firm's January-June operating profit of 14.8 trillion won.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: ($1 = 1,117.4300 Korean won) REUTERS

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: NEW YORK - U.S. stocks advanced on Friday as a weaker-than-expected payrolls report tamped down expectations for a September rate hike from the U.S. Federal Reserve, although hawkish comments from another Fed official kept expectations for one this year intact.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: U.S. nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs in August after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with job cuts in manufacturing and construction, the Labor Department said. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast payrolls rising by 180,000 last month.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Traders trimmed the probability of a Fed rate hike this month to 21 percent from the 24-percent chance on Thursday, according to CME Group's FedWatch program. However, the odds for a December rate increase edged up to 54.2 percent from 53.6 percent the previous day.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: "People are taking a little bit of a relief that it wasn’t a 200,000-plus print, certainly in the equity market," said Sean Lynch, co-head of global equity strategy at Wells Fargo Investment Institute in Omaha.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: "Equity markets are going to give the Fed at least one rate increase but if they start to perceive a series of hikes coming, and coming sooner than later, that is when equity markets will get a little nervous here."

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Despite the soft report, Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker on Friday said the U.S. economy appears strong enough to warrant significantly higher interest rates. Lacker argued that a range of economic analysis suggests the Fed's benchmark overnight interest rate is too low.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Several Fed officials have made hawkish comments about a rate hike in recent weeks, leaving investors unable to rule out the possibility of an increase at the central bank's next meeting, scheduled for Sept. 20-21.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The dollar index <.DXY>, which measures the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, bounced back after touching a one-week low to trade up 0.22 percent.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The Dow Jones industrial average <.DJI> rose 72.66 points, or 0.39 percent, to 18,491.96, the S&P 500 <.SPX> gained 9.12 points, or 0.42 percent, to 2,179.98 and the Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> added 22.69 points, or 0.43 percent, to 5,249.90.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: For the week, both the Dow and S&P 500 rose 0.5 percent and the S&P gained 0.6 percent.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The energy sector <.SPNY>, up 0.8 percent, helped pace gains as both WTI <CLc1> and Brent <LCOc1> oil prices settled up 3 percent, but crude prices still ended the week with sharp losses on oversupply concerns.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Utilities <.SPLRCU>, which benefit from low interest rates, were up 1.2 percent, the best performing of the 10 major S&P sectors.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Lululemon Athletica <LULU.O> lost 10.6 percent, its worst day since early December, at $68.57 after the Canadian yoga wear retailer reported quarterly comparable-sales growth below expectations.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Broadcom <AVGO.O> fell 2.2 percent to $173.11 after the chipmaker's revenue in its largest segment stalled in the latest quarter. The stock was the biggest drag on the S&P and the Nasdaq.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the NYSE by a 4.23-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 2.25-to-1 ratio favored advancers.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The S&P 500 posted 41 new 52-week highs and 2 new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 151 new highs and 18 new lows. REUTERS

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Federal Reserve policymakers already skeptical of the need for an interest-rate hike this month gained some ground against their more hawkish colleagues after a government report Friday showed U.S. job gains slowed last month.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: But as long as data in the next few months suggests continued moderate economic growth and a rise in inflation toward the Fed's 2-percent target, Fed policymakers look likely to back a December rate hike as a prudent step toward normalizing what has been nearly a decade of ultra-easy monetary policy.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: The Fed raised short-term interest rates last December by a quarter of a percentage point, but have left them unchanged so far this year. Last week, Fed Chair Janet Yellen said an improving labor market and signs that inflation are firming have strengthened the case for a rate hike, and most regional Fed bank presidents as well as Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer appear to back a rate hike sooner than later.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Some analysts continue to expect the Fed to raise rates this month, including economist Jan Hatzius at Goldman Sachs who said the August job gains are "just enough" to be convincing. August figures are often revised higher in subsequent months.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Even without any revision, monthly average job gains for the most recent three months register 232,000, more than double the level that Yellen says is needed to keep the unemployment rate steady.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: "It appears that the funds rate should be significantly higher than it is now," Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker, a consistent advocate for a rate hike even when the unemployment was higher than its current 4.9 percent, said Friday.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Lacker also said the August payrolls data suggests the job market is still tightening.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: But with resistance among other key Fed policymakers to a near-term rate hike strong, a September rate hike was already seen as unlikely before the jobs report.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Traders of interest rate futures see about a one in four chance of a rate hike at the Fed's Sept. 20-21 meeting.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: December, however, is another story, with the rate futures market seeing about a 60 percent chance of a rate hike then.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: While the August gain of 151,000 jobs was less than expected, it is still plenty to provide work for new job entrants as well as any discouraged workers reentering the labor market.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: And Fed officials have long said they expect job gains to slow as the U.S. economy nears full employment.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: "Most (Fed policymakers) think another rate hike sometime soon is the right thing to do," Roberto Perli, Cornerstone Macro economist wrote after the report. "A rate hike this year was a solid base case before the employment report, and still remains a solid base case now." REUTERS

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: FRANKFURT - Former Volkswagen <VOWG_p.DE> manager Wolfgang Schreiber is suing the carmaker for hundreds of millions of euros in royalty payments for his role in developing a dual clutch gearbox, Der Spiegel reported.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: The German magazine, citing a lawsuit over patents filed in a Munich court, said Schreiber had turned down 20 million euros ($22 mln) in compensation and was seeking "adequate" compensation.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: The dual clutch gearbox is in use in millions of VW-branded passenger cars.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: A Volkswagen spokesman confirmed Schreiber had formally demanded compensation from VW, but declined to comment on details such as the amount being sought, given that it is an ongoing and unresolved dispute.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: ($1 = 0.8966 euros) REUTERS

Headline: Fed's Lacker favors raising U.S. rates sooner than later
Text: RICHMOND, Va. - The U.S. Federal Reserve's last policy meeting in July would have been a good time to raise interest rates, Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker said on Friday.

Headline: Fed's Lacker favors raising U.S. rates sooner than later
Text: Speaking to economists in Richmond, Virginia, Lacker said he was still in the group of Fed policymakers who favor raising interest rates sooner than later. REUTERS

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: ALPBACH, Austria - Multinationals like coffee chain Starbucks <SBUX.O> and online retailer Amazon <AMZN.O> pay less tax in Austria than one of the country's tiny sausage stands, the republic's center-left chancellor lamented in an interview published on Friday.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: Chancellor Christian Kern, head of the Social Democrats and of the centrist coalition government, also criticized internet giants Google <GOOGL.O> and Facebook <FB.O>, saying that if they paid more tax subsidies for print media could increase.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "Every Viennese cafe, every sausage stand pays more tax in Austria than a multinational corporation," Kern was quoted as saying in an interview with newspaper Der Standard, invoking two potent symbols of the Austrian capital's food culture.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "That goes for Starbucks, Amazon and other companies," he said, praising the European Commission's ruling this week that Apple <AAPL.O> should pay up to 13 billion euros ($14.5 billion) in taxes plus interest to Ireland because a special scheme to route profits through that country was illegal state aid.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: Apple has said it will appeal the ruling, which Chief Executive Tim Cook described as "total political crap". Google, Facebook and other multinational companies say they follow all tax rules.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: Kern criticized EU states with low-tax regimes that have lured multinationals - and come under scrutiny from Brussels.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "What Ireland, the Netherlands, Luxembourg or Malta are doing here lacks solidarity towards the rest of the European economy," he said.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: He stopped short of saying that Facebook and Google would have to pay more tax but underlined their significant sales in Austria, which he estimated at more than 100 million euros each, and their relatively small numbers of employees - a "good dozen" for Google and "allegedly even fewer" for Facebook.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "They massively suck up the advertising volume that comes out of the economy but pay neither corporation tax nor advertising duty in Austria," said Kern, who became chancellor in May.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: ($1 = 0.8965 euros) REUTERS

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: RICHMOND, Va. - The U.S. economy appears strong enough to warrant significantly higher interest rates, Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker said on Friday.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Lacker, who is not a voting member of the U.S. central bank's rate-setting committee this year, said he still favors raising rates sooner than later and that the Fed's last policy meeting in July would have been a "good time" to tighten policy.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Speaking to a group of economists in Richmond, Lacker argued that a range of economic analysis suggests the Fed's benchmark overnight interest rate - the federal funds rate - is currently too low.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: "It appears that the funds rate should be significantly higher than it is now," he said in the speech.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: He made his comments after the U.S. government reported a hiring slowdown in August that could effectively rule out a rate increase later this month.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: While Lacker is not due to have a vote on policy until 2018, he does participate in discussions on interest rates. The Fed has appeared sharply divided between policymakers who favor rate increases soon and those who urge more caution.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Those favoring caution appeared to get a boost on Friday when a report showed 150,000 U.S. jobs were created last month, fewer than expected.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: But Lacker said the weaker pace of hiring still left the job market on a strengthening path and the case for higher rates would only grow stronger unless job growth slowed "significantly in the months ahead."

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: He suggested there were increased risks in waiting to raise rates.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: "The way the data is playing out I think the longer we wait there is a material increase in risks that we run," Lacker told reporters after his speech.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: The Fed hiked rates in December for the first time in nearly a decade and has signaled since March that two rate increases could be in order this year. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last week she thought the case for a rate hike had strengthened, but many investors have doubts the central bank will raise rates at all this year.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Lacker said he was concerned the economy could heat up enough for inflation to go above the Fed's 2 percent target, hurting the central bank's credibility. He said warning about prices "might not be fashionable" given that inflation has been below target in recent years.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: But there is a risk the Fed will have to jack up rates quickly, triggering a recession, he said in his speech.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: "It would be hard to calibrate policy settings carefully enough to avoid precipitating a contraction in real activity," Lacker said. REUTERS

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: LONDON - Apple CEO Tim Cook has said he will appeal the European Commission's ruling that his company received an unlawful 13 billion euro ($14.5 billion) subsidy when Ireland gave it preferential tax deals and that he was confident the decision would be reversed.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: But over a dozen lawyers, including three advising companies on appeals, told Reuters it was impossible to predict how EU courts would rule in an area that has not been tested before.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: State aid cases have up until now centered on targeted tax laws that countries introduce with an obvious aim of attracting investment and jobs by reduced tax bills.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: In the Apple case, and several others, the Commission has been investigating whether member countries' tax authorities were secretly giving tax breaks by being too generous in their application of accepted tax principles.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: The Commission believes some member states allowed companies to shift profits into untaxed subsidiaries by approving inappropriate transfer prices -- the prices subsidiaries of multinational companies charge each other for intra-group transactions.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Most experts said the EU judges dealing with any Apple appeal to overturn the ruling would be focused on whether the European Commission has strayed too far into dictating national tax policy by rejecting Ireland's view of transfer pricing.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: “What Apple and Ireland have done sounds really outrageous but the last word has not been spoken as to whether the Commission can use transfer pricing rules to identify what a subsidy is,” said Herwig Hofmann, Professor of law at the University of Luxembourg.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: “There’s a good argument to be made that if you want to do that, actually you have to harmonize tax laws and you don’t have the power to do that.” EU law says only governments can approve a harmonization of tax systems. The Commission has also been investigating tax transfer pricing at Fiat, McDonald's, Starbucks andAmazon.com Inc.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: The companies and the countries which gave the rulings all deny special treatment was given and have launched, or are considering, legal appeals.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: NO SPECIAL ADVANTAGE

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Some lawyers say that Apple's arrangement was legal in Ireland and theoretically available to any company and so the California-based company could not have received a advantage that was selective – key factors in most state aid cases. “There’s nothing that I have seen in any of the cases that have been taken by the European Commission that suggests there is selective application of the rules,” Tim Wach, Global Managing Director at international tax advisors Tax and.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: However, other lawyers note that Apple’s unusual tax structure – involving companies which are tax resident nowhere – means its tax rulings are unlikely to have many close comparators. And the rulings lead to a less than 1 percent tax rate -- something most other companies don’t enjoy.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: “If I had to bet my dollar on something here, I think Apple could have a hard time overturning the selectivity argument,” said Georg Berrisch, a partner at Baker Botts in Brussels.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Last year, the European Commission published a list of six tax rulings and 59 “measures similar in nature or effect” since1991, which it had challenged on the basis of state aid rules. It was successful in almost all cases.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Officials say these show its current actions are in line with previous precedents.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Many experts in the field disagree and last week the U.S. Treasury issued a detailed paper which assessed earlier cases and said “in none of the 65 cases involving State aid nor in any other cases examined by the U.S. Treasury Department, did the Commission challenge how a Member State tax authority applied its own transfer pricing rules in granting a specific ruling.”

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: OVER TO THE COURT

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Europe’s highest court, the Court of Justice of the European Union (ECJ), will hear any appeal by Apple.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: The court usually backs the Commission, but lawyers say it sometimes disagrees in state aid cases where it usually comes up against countries. The Irish government is still considering whether to launch its own separate appeal. Some lawyers say ECJ judges are influenced by political considerations and that if the Commission’s rulings prompt a major spat with the United States and member states don’t support the Commission, the court may hesitate to enforce a tax demand of up to 13 billion euros plus interest.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: So far, France and Germany have voiced support for the Apple ruling. The UK, which has voted to leave the bloc, filed a submission in support of the Commission's case against Fiat, according to lawyers involved in the case. The UK declined comment.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: A spokeswoman for the court said political considerations do not come into its decisions.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager agreed. “I don’t think the courts will hear any kind of political opinions or feelings or what’s in your stomach or whatever. They want the facts of the case,” she said.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: The ECJ could decide the Commission is allowed to challenge transfer pricing but knock back the Commission’s methodology for calculating Apple's bill.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: That would leave the door open to a smaller tax demand being levied.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: “The amount isn’t set in stone at all, I think this figurehead of 13 billion, that is yet to be analyzed in detail,” Hofmann said. If the court backs the Commission, the executive would theoretically be free to challenge hundreds of other complex tax arrangements used, mainly by U.S. companies, to minimize taxes on European sales.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: A Reuters investigation in 2013 showed that at least 74 percent of the 50 biggest U.S. technology companies, including Google and Facebook, use practices similar to Apple’s to reduce their tax bills. http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/07/23/us-tax-bigtech-idUSBRE96M08W201...

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Ireland is now supposed to calculate exactly how much Apple owes, which is typically paid ahead of an appeal, using the Commission’s methodology. However, a quirk of the Apple ruling may delay this. The Commission said other EU countries could claim some of the 13 billion euros by re-assessing the income of Apple subsidiaries on their territories.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Apple's appeal will first be to the EU’s General Court, which will take two to three years to rule, lawyers say. A likely appeal to the ECJ could take another two years.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: In meantime, lawyers will be watching more advanced case s.denis Waelbroeck, of law firm Ashurst in Brussels, who is advising Luxembourg on its appeal in the FIAT case, said the General Court could give a ruling on that next March.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: “Whatever outcome we get will influence Apple,” he said. REUTERS

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Ireland's cabinet agreed on Friday to join Apple in appealing against a multi-billion-euro back tax demand that the European Commission has imposed on the iPhone maker, despite misgivings among independents who back the fragile coalition.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The Commission's ruling this week that the U.S. tech giant must pay up to 13 billion euros ($14.5 billion) to Dublin has angered Washington, which accuses the EU of trying to grab tax revenue that should go to the U.S. government.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: With transatlantic tensions rising, the White House said President Barack Obama would raise the issue of tax avoidance by some multinational corporations at a summit of the G20 leading economies in China this weekend.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Paradoxically, Ireland is determined not to accept the tax windfall, which would be equivalent to what it spent last year on funding its struggling health service.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Finance Minister Michael Noonan has insisted Dublin would fight any adverse ruling ever since the European Union began investigating Apple's Irish tax affairs in 2014, arguing that it had to protect a tax regime that has attracted large numbers of multinational employers.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: On Wednesday, he failed to persuade a group of independent lawmakers, whose support is vital for the minority government, to agree to fight the ruling by European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager that Apple's low tax arrangements in Ireland constitute illegal state aid.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: However, he won them over when the cabinet met again on Friday.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Noonan said the retroactive nature of the EU ruling was "little short of bizarre and outrageous".

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "How could any foreign direct investor come into Europe if they thought the valid arrangements they made under law could be overturned a generation later and they be liable to pay back money," he said at a news conference.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Public Expenditure Minister Paschal Donohoe said Dublin stood behind its corporate tax regime as a means of creating jobs.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "This ruling has seismic and entirely negative consequences for job creation in the future," he said.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Apple, keen to defend its own interests, has already said it will lodge an appeal. For Fine Gael, the main Irish coalition party, a broader principle is at stake. It wants to take on Brussels to safeguard Ireland's decades-old low corporate tax policy that has drawn in multinationals such as Apple, creating one in 10 jobs in what was once an impoverished country.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: A FAIR RATE OF TAX

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The Independent Alliance, a group of five lawmakers, fell in line after the coalition agreed to conduct a review of what tax multinationals pay and what should they pay.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Transport Minister Shane Ross, an Alliance member, defended Apple up to a point. "I think they were acting legally. What they were doing was making use of extraordinary loopholes that existed there," he told reporters. "Multinationals provide absolutely vital jobs to the economy ... (but) multinationals should pay a fair rate of tax in Ireland."

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: A failure of the Alliance to come on board would have cast doubt on the government's survival prospects. Dublin has just over two months to lodge an appeal to the EU's General Court. If that fails, Dublin has said it plans to take the case to the European Court of Justice.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The issue goes to parliament on Wednesday next week, when lawmakers will be recalled from their summer break. The main opposition party, Fianna Fail, also favors challenging Brussels, so the government should easily win the Dail's backing to fight what is by far the largest anti-competition measure imposed on a company by the EU.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Some Irish voters are astounded that the government might turn down the money, and the left-wing Sinn Fein party has led attacks from the opposition.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Apple was found to be holding over $181 billion in accumulated profits offshore, more than any U.S. company, in a study published last year by two left-leaning nonprofit groups, a policy critics say is designed to avoid paying U.S taxes.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: But Apple chief executive Tim Cook has said part of the company's 2014 tax bill would be paid next year when the company repatriates offshore profits to the United States.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: OBAMA TO TAKE THE LEAD

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The U.S. government is keen to ensure that it, and not Ireland, gets the revenue.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said leaders of the G20 developed and emerging economies would tackle the wider issue when they meet in the Chinese city of Hangzhou on Sept. 4-5.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "The president will ... lead the discussion at the G20 about combating tax avoidance strategies that are implemented by some multinational corporations," Earnest said.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "We need to find a way to make the global system of taxation more fair - more fair to countries around the world, particularly countries like the United States."

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: A number of G20 governments are worried about how multinationals move profits around so they end up getting taxed in a country that has very low corporate rates.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Last year the Organisation for Economic Co Operation and Development unveiled new measures to tackle corporate tax avoidance. A number of countries have moved to implement some of them measures, but the United States has not.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: It needs to change its own tax rules which, for example, allow companies to build up tax-free profits offshore. However, Congress has struggled for years to agree such reforms.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: ($1 = 0.8937 euros) REUTERS

Headline: Ireland to hold independent review of corporate tax system
Text: DUBLIN - Ireland's coalition government has committed to holding an independent review of the country's corporate tax system after it agreed on Friday to join Apple in appealing against a multi-billion-euro back tax demand from the European Commission.

Headline: Ireland to hold independent review of corporate tax system
Text: The review will assess "what tax multinationals do pay and what they should pay", said junior minister John Halligan of the Independent Alliance, a group of five lawmakers whose initial misgivings delayed the launching of an appeal.

Headline: Ireland to hold independent review of corporate tax system
Text: The terms of reference for the review will be decided in the coming days, the Independent Alliance members told reporters. REUTERS

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: LONDON - Olympus <7733.T>, the Japanese medical equipment and camera maker, is suing former CEO and whistleblower Michael Woodford in a multimillion-pound legal row over allegations of wrongdoing surrounding an executive pension plan.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Almost five years after Woodford lifted the lid on one of Japan's biggest corporate frauds, his former employer is claiming more than 15 million pounds ($20 million) from him and a former colleague, alleging they conspired to maximize their pension benefits by unlawful means, according to court filings.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford, Olympus's first foreign chief executive, was fired two weeks into the job in 2011 after persistently querying unexplained payments worth around $1.7 billion and demanding the resignation of its former chairman and vice president.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: He then alerted global authorities and the media. Olympus initially said Woodford was fired for failing to understand its management style and Japanese culture. But in September 2012 the company and three former executives pleaded guilty in Japan to cover-up charges.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Olympus's KeyMed unit, a surgical products maker in southern England, has now filed a High Court claim against Woodford and Olympus veteran Paul Hillman alleging they breached their duties as directors and trustees of the defined benefit pension plan.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford and Hillman, a former company director who resigned in 2011, deny any wrongdoing and say they acted at all times in accordance with their duties.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "Mr Woodford and Mr Hillman consider the claims against them to be completely baseless and look forward to taking the proceedings to trial and demonstrating what they consider to be the true motivations behind the claims by Olympus," they said in a joint statement.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford, who joined Olympus in 1981 and rose through its ranks to become CEO, has countersued Olympus. He alleges the case brought by KeyMed breaches a 2012 out-of-court settlement over his dismissal and is seeking damages "in the high seven figures".

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Olympus headquarters in Tokyo declined to comment.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Rudolf Muench, a Hamburg-based general manager at Olympus's European headquarters in Germany, said KeyMed was only alerted to possible wrongdoing in 2014 when the "substantial value" of one of the pensions became known.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "KeyMed has a responsibility towards its stakeholders and therefore could not ignore the evidence that was presented," he said in an email to Reuters.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "DELIBERATE WRONGDOING"

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: In documents received by the court on Aug. 26 and seen by Reuters, Olympus said the 2012 full and final employment settlement with Woodford did not prevent further legal action when claims were based on "deliberate wrongdoing or fraud".

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: The case against the men hinges on allegations that they obtained board approval to set up the executive pension plan in 2005 by concealing from others that the purpose of the scheme was "to increase the security of their pension". This was contrary to a board agreement there would be no enhancement of executive benefits through the scheme, the documents allege.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Olympus said the executive scheme provided for overly generous fixed 5 percent per annum increases in pension payments once the pension was activated, that it adopted an overly conservative investment strategy and that it dropped a provision to cut benefits for younger surviving spouses.
