Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford and Hillman, whose wife is more than 10 years his junior, said the pension plan was established in 2007 after two years of discussions and that it was transparent and set up in consultation with the board, senior executives, independent trustees and on the advice of advisers and lawyers.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: They said Olympus raised no concerns about the pension plan during the last decade before issuing a claim in August 2015 and added allegations of fraud four months later "without any evidence to back them up".

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford, 56, said his annual pension benefit rose to 993,000 pounds at the end of his 30-year Olympus career. This was converted into a capital sum of 64.5 million pounds and transferred to a Self Invested Personal Pension (SIPP), a UK government-approved scheme, with Olympus's approval in 2014.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Defined pension benefits are linked to the number of years employees work and their salaries, are paid for life and can be paid to spouses, partners or dependants when the retiree dies.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Hillman, who is 64 and drawing his pension, told Reuters by telephone there was a catalog of correspondence to show the executive scheme had been set up and run correctly.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "There is a picture being painted of us being devious and doing things in dark corners when everything has been done openly, in a transparent way," he said.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: ($1 = 0.7536 pounds) REUTERS

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: WASHINGTON - The U.S. International Trade Commission voted on Friday to lock in duties on imports of cold-rolled steel flat products from Brazil, India, South Korea and Britain but said imports from Russia were not injuring the U.S. industry.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: The U.S. Commerce Department had previously found the products from Brazil, India, South Korea and Russia were being unfairly subsidized and sold in the United States at below fair value, and that the products from Britain were also being dumped.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: In the case of Brazil, India, South Korea and Britain, the ITC said their imports were harming the U.S. industry, a finding that effectively locked in place duties proposed by the Commerce Department that range as high as 58.36 percent.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: Russian imports will not face duties, because of a lack of a finding of injury.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: After the Commerce Department's finding in July, Brazil indicated it would challenge any duties on its products at the World Trade Organization. Brazilian exports are dominated by Cia. Siderúrgica Nacional <CSNA3.SA> and Usinas Siderurgicas de Minas Gerais SA <USIM5.SA>.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: Other companies whose exports are affected by the decision include South Korean steelmakers POSCO <005490.KS> and Hyundai Steel Co <004020.KS>, Indian producer JSW Steel Ltd <JSTL.NS> and a British subsidiary of Tata Steel Ltd <TISC.NS>.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: Cold-rolled steel is used in automotive body panels, appliances, shipping containers and construction.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: U.S. officials launched probes into the imports after being petitioned by AK Steel Corp, a subsidiary of AK Steel Holding Co <AKS.N>; ArcelorMittal USA LLC, a unit of ArcelorMittal SA <ISPA.AS>; Nucor Corp <NUE.N>; Steel Dynamics Inc <STLD.O>; and United States Steel Corp <X.N>. REUTERS

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: LONDON - Vilified retailer Sports Direct <SPD.L> takes another step in its attempted rehabilitation next week when it hosts members of the public and the media at its headquarters in northern England, slated for working conditions akin to a Victorian workhouse.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: The 450-store sportswear chain, known for discount offers such as mens' polo shirts priced at 5.50 pounds ($7.33), has been condemned by politicians for effectively paying workers less than the minimum wage and by shareholders for poor corporate governance.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: In a u-turn of its previous closed-door attitude, the group which also owns brands such as Lonsdale and Dunlop said last week it would invite non-shareholders to an open day on Sept. 7 to coincide with its annual shareholders' meeting (AGM), access to which has traditionally been restricted.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Attendees will be permitted to observe the AGM before being allowed to question the board, of which billionaire founder Mike Ashley, also owner of Newcastle United soccer club, is a member, then touring the site at Shirebrook in Derbyshire.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: The Shirebrook warehouse was slammed in a report by British lawmakers which said its working practices were closer to that of a Victorian workhouse than a reputable retailer.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: The poor publicity has already prompted a company response and in August thousands of Sports Direct workers were told they would receive back pay totaling 1 million pounds ($1.3 million after their wages fell short of the legal minimum.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Some investors in the chain, in which Ashley owns 55 percent, have rebuked its management and called on the board to launch a further independent review of the way it is run.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Yet an open day in itself is unlikely to appease the investors, given its shares languish 43 percent down this year, a drop which has wiped hundreds of millions of pounds off the value of Ashley's holding.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Investors have called for a review of board oversight, related party transactions and potential conflicts of interest, employment practices, acquisition strategy, oversight of supplier relationships and the management of stores.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Voting at the AGM will give them the chance to express their frustrations with the company, which has issued two profit warnings this year, most recently in March.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Shares in the firm also plunged after Britain voted to leave the EU, dragged down by the collapse in the value of the pound against the dollar and the fact Sports Direct had not hedged its currency for such an outcome.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Legal & General <LGEN.L>, Sports Direct's 11th largest shareholder, has already said it will oppose the re-election of Chairman Keith Hellawell as well as the other non-executive directors.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Sports Direct is also due to publish next week a report on working practices following an internal investigation.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: ($1 = 0.7492 pounds) REUTERS

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: BRUSSELS - The European Commission rejected criticism from one of its own former antitrust chiefs on Friday of its massive tax demand on Apple and pointedly noted that she now works for another U.S. tech company, Uber.

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Neelie Kroes, who was EU competition commissioner for five years until 2010 and ran digital policy until two years ago, said this week's ruling by current antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager that the iPhone maker must pay 13 billion euros of back taxes that Ireland had waived was an incorrect use of EU law.

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: "EU member states have a sovereign right to determine their own tax laws. State aid cannot be used to rewrite those rules," Kroes wrote in the Guardian. "However, the current state aid investigations into tax rulings appear to do exactly that."

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Asked about the article at a regular news briefing on Friday, chief Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said:

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: "We understand that it may be sometimes challenging to reconcile the role as a former commissioner with the temptation to publicly express the views of those in Silicon Valley or elsewhere who oppose the Commission's decisions."

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Kroes, a Dutch liberal who left Brussels when Jean-Claude Juncker replaced Jose Manuel Barroso as Commission president in 2014, now sits on the public policy board of Uber. The Silicon Valley company that runs the ride-hailing app is lobbying the Commission to do more to challenge national rules across the Union that have curbed Uber's development in Europe.

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Schinas said Kroes's criticism of Vestager's use of EU laws that ban governments giving firms unfair "state aid" -- in Apple's case via a tax deal -- was incorrect: "State aid rules ... were not applied in the way it was alleged," he said. REUTERS

Headline: Daimler reviews supplier ties in wake of crippling VW spat
Text: BERLIN - Daimler <DAIGn.DE> is reviewing relationships with its suppliers to avoid the kind of crippling production halts that afflicted rival Volkswagen <VOWG_p.DE>, its Chief Executive Dieter Zetsche said on Friday.

Headline: Daimler reviews supplier ties in wake of crippling VW spat
Text: A dispute between VW and one of its suppliers led to production slowdowns at six Volkswagen plants last month, highlighting how vulnerable modern car production systems are to stoppages.

Headline: Daimler reviews supplier ties in wake of crippling VW spat
Text: "You of course take an example like this to take precautions to minimize risks like this and ideally to rule them out," Daimler's Zetsche said at a roundtable event in Berlin.

Headline: Daimler reviews supplier ties in wake of crippling VW spat
Text: "That is why we reviewed existing measures, and intensified them in some cases, to avoid such a situation from arising," Zetsche said, without elaborating further. REUTERS

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: NEW DELHI/DETROIT - Ford Motor Co <F.N> has shelved plans to produce a new compact car family designed mainly for emerging markets like India and China, industry sources said, reflecting disappointing sales of mainstream models in the world's fastest growing car markets.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: India and China were expected to be the main manufacturing hubs for the new B500 range, slated to begin production in 2018 and to include a premium sedan, hatchback and sport utility vehicle (SUV), two sources with direct knowledge of Ford's plans told Reuters.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The automaker had also planned to build its new models in Brazil, Russia and Thailand, one of the sources said.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford's decision, communicated to its suppliers in July, follows a similar move by General Motors <GM.N> to postpone the launch in India of a new $5 billion family of compact vehicles.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford is now planning to redesign the EcoSport, Figo and Figo Aspire in India in 2020-2021, according to two separate U.S. sources familiar with Ford's plans.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Its more ambitious B500 program, though, is on ice because of muted demand for some small and mid-sized hatchbacks and sedans in India and China, where SUVs and "crossovers" combining the hatchback and SUV have proved increasingly popular.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The cost of upgrading plants to produce the new cars would also be prohibitively high, the first sources said.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: All of the sources declined to be named as they have not been cleared to discuss the plans publicly.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford declined to comment on the development.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "We are constantly evaluating opportunities to better meet the needs of consumers and do not comment on speculation about future product programmes," a Ford spokesman said in a statement.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: SHIFT TO SUVS

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: That said, Ford has invested over $2 billion in India and plans to spend more to set up a global engineering center in the southern city of Chennai that will help tweak products for the local market and more swiftly adapt to changing consumer trends.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The carmaker is also ramping up exports, including to Europe, to maximize usage of its two plants in India.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "India is a key market for us in Asia Pacific," said the spokesman, adding that the carmaker is committed to introducing new products and technologies in the South Asian nation.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: But instead of the bigger plan for the key markets of India and China, Ford will focus on updating existing models and develop and build more SUVs and crossovers, moving away from sedans and hatchbacks, the U.S. sources said.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: That would allow the carmaker to boost profit margins.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "The global shift to crossovers makes competing in small cars a tough proposition for GM and Ford," said Sam Fiorani, vice president of global vehicle forecasting at U.S.-based AutoForecast Solutions.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "It makes more sense for them to refresh older products now, harness lower development costs in China in the mid-term, and move toward small crossovers over the long haul."

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Chinese buyers have flocked to SUVs, as they grow wealthier and are often restricted to one vehicle in major cities, at the expense of contracting sedan sales.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: SUV sales rose 52 percent last year, although a glut of new model launches in the segment is already leading to discounts and lower margins.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Growing competition in the small SUV segment from local Chinese carmakers is also putting more pressure on pricing.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: SETBACK FOR "MAKE IN INDIA"

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The retreat by Ford and GM is a setback for India's "Make in India" push to become a global manufacturing powerhouse, including in the auto sector.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Retooling the assembly line to build the B500 vehicles at Ford's plant in Gujarat, Prime Minister Narendra Modi's home state, would have meant an investment of more than $100 million and created manufacturing jobs as it cranked out more cars.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford and GM have struggled to crack emerging markets in Asia, where competition from Japanese, South Korean and now Chinese automakers is fierce.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: GM shut production in Indonesia owing to its modest market share, and Ford also plans to close its operations in the Southeast Asian nation, as well as in Japan and Australia.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Dearborn-based Ford is now looking at each country in the region in terms of long-term profitability opportunities, said another source familiar with Ford's plans, while noting India remains a tough place to make money.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: SEOUL - Samsung Electronics Co Ltd <005930.KS> recalled all Galaxy Note 7 smartphones equipped with batteries it has found to be fire-prone and halted their sales in 10 markets, denting a revival of the firm's mobile business.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Koh Dong-jin, head of the South Korean company's smartphone business, expressed regret over the recall, which will affect markets including South Korea and the United States, at a news conference on Friday.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Models in China feature a different battery and are not being recalled by the world's biggest smartphone vendor.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The recall comes just over two weeks after the launch of Samsung's latest premium phone, which features an outsized screen and high-resolution camera, and follows reports of the 988,900 won ($885) phone igniting while charging.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Koh, who declined to comment on the number of phones needing replacement, said Samsung had sold 2.5 million of the premium devices so far. The manufacturer plans to replace not only phones with faulty batteries sold to consumers, but also retailer inventories and units in transit.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: "I can't comment on exactly how much the cost will be, but it pains my heart that it will be such a big number," he said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The scale of the recall is unprecedented for Samsung, which prides itself on its manufacturing prowess. While recalls in the smartphone industry do happen, including for rival Apple Inc <AAPL.O>, the nature of the problem for the Galaxy Note 7 is a serious blow to Samsung's reputation, analysts said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: It must act quickly to minimize damage to its smartphone recovery, after a string of product successes had reversed a fall in market share, they added.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: CUSTOMERS PUT ON HOLD

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The phone first launched in 10 markets in North America, Asia and the Middle East. Further roll-outs have occurred since in markets like China, where sales started just this week. Its wider availability, set for coming weeks, is now on hold.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Germany's biggest operator Deutsche Telekom said it had stopped delivering orders for the Galaxy Note 7, while French operator Orange said on its website that it had stopped pre-sales of the phone and postponed its planned sales launch - scheduled for Friday.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: In Britain, mobile carriers EE and Vodafone <VOD.L> continue to accept pre-orders for the Note 7 on their sites. A Vodafone spokesman said its planned September 19 sales launch could now slip, but was waiting for more details from Samsung to decide.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: U.S. operators have been taking pre-orders since early August. The No.1 U.S. wireless carrier Verizon Communications Inc <VZ.N> said it has stopped selling the Galaxy Note 7 in light of customer safety.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: If a customer wants to return or exchange the Galaxy Note 7, Verizon said it would waive the restocking fee it charges customers through September 30.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: T-Mobile US <TMUS.O>, majority owned by Deutsche Telekom, also said it has suspended sales, while AT&T <T.N> and Sprint <S.N> could not be reached immediately for comment.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: SECOND-HALF HOPES

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Samsung has said it aimed for the Note 7 to maintain strong sales momentum in the second half of the year against stiffening competition from the likes of Apple Inc <AAPL.O>, which is widely expected to release its latest iPhone next week.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: "I am concerned more about a potential reduction in sales than recall costs," said analyst Jay Yoo at Korea Investment & Securities. "The recall is likely to be a blow to earnings."

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Samsung said new sales of the Note 7 in affected markets would resume after it deals with replacements, a process it expects will begin in about two weeks. The firm would extend refund periods for affected customers and offer exchanges for other Samsung phones, Koh said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Investors sold Samsung shares after the delay announcement on Thursday, stripping about $7 billion from the firm's market value, which remains just off recent record highs. Sentiment recovered somewhat in trading on Friday as the shares rose 0.6 percent compared with 0.3 percent in the broader market <.KS11>.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Credit Suisse said a recall or major shipment delays could wipe 1.5 trillion won ($1.34 billion) from Samsung's 2016 operating profit estimate of 30.2 trillion won in an "absolute worst case" scenario.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: But the brokerage said that scenario was unlikely, as it expected Samsung to resolve problem before the fourth quarter.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: HI Securities analyst James Song said the replacement costs may be somewhat limited as Samsung could recycle components of the recalled phones.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: "It is clever for Samsung to replace the affected models, not offering fixes. That helps enhance consumer confidence and help reduce potential falls in future sales," he said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Samsung's mobile division accounted for about 54 percent of the firm's January-June operating profit of 14.8 trillion won.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: While there are occasional reports of phones catching fire or otherwise burning users, documented cases that lead to widespread product recalls remain relatively rare.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: India's passenger car market, where sales rose 7 percent last fiscal year to 2.8 million units, is dominated by Maruti Suzuki <MRTI.NS> and Hyundai Motor Co <005380.KS> with their extensive line-up of cars and vast dealer networks.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Maruti and Hyundai control two-thirds of the market whereas Ford's share in India, set to be the world's third-largest car market by 2020, has stagnated at about 3 percent.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Until Ford finalizes an alternative plan, the shift in strategy could leave gaps in its car portfolio in India, that today sits at the two ends of the price and size spectrum.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: In the meantime, Ford is increasing its focus on driving down costs by sourcing more parts locally and using more common features across models to achieve economies of scale. REUTERS

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: In 2007, the largest battery recall in consumer electronics history took place when Nokia <NOKIA.HE>, then the world's top mobile handset maker, offered to replace 46 million phone batteries produced for it by Japanese maker Matsushita Battery.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Ireland fully behind corporate tax regime ahead of review: minister
Text: DUBLIN - Ireland's government stands fully behind its corporate tax regime, Public Expenditure Minister Paschal Donohoe said on Friday, ahead of an independent review it commissioned into how multinationals pay their tax.

Headline: Ireland fully behind corporate tax regime ahead of review: minister
Text: The Irish government has decided to appeal a demand by the European Commission that Apple pay Dublin 13 billion euros in back taxes, although independent members of the coalition called for the review.

Headline: Ireland fully behind corporate tax regime ahead of review: minister
Text: "This government stands fully behind our corporate tax regime. It is absolutely essential that this system and this rate be maintained," Donohoe, a member of the main Irish coalition party, Fine Gael, told a news conference. REUTERS

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Delta Air Lines Inc <DAL.N> said its revenue for August was reduced by about $100 million due to an outage that led to the cancellation of 2,300 flights over three days.

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Passenger revenue per available seat mile (PRASM), a key measure of an airline's performance that measures sales against flight capacity, declined 9.5 percent in August from a year earlier, its biggest drop in nine months. [nPn9p2d6Ra]

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Excluding the impact of the outage, Delta's unit revenue was below expectations, J.P.Morgan's Jamie Baker wrote in a note.

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Baker said he expects Delta to cut its third-quarter operating margin to at least 17-19 percent from its current forecast of 19-21 percent.

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: The No. 2 U.S. airline by passenger traffic said last month a power outage hit its computer systems, leading to the flight cancellations. [nL3N1AR3TH]

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Delta in July forecast a drop of 4-6 percent in PRASM for the third quarter ending September. [nL1N1A00B2] REUTERS

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: WASHINGTON, Sept 2 - New orders for U.S. factory goods recorded their largest increase in nine months in July as demand increased broadly, in a hopeful sign for the embattled manufacturing sector.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: The Commerce Department said on Friday that new orders for manufactured goods rebounded 1.9 percent after a downwardly revised 1.8 percent decrease in June. It was the biggest rise since October 2015 and followed two straight months of declines.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: Economists polled by Reuters had forecast factory orders rising 2.0 percent in July after a previously reported 1.5 percent decline in June.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: The department also said orders for non-defense capital goods excluding aircraft increased 1.5 percent in July instead of the 1.6 percent rise it reported last month. These so-called core capital goods are seen as a measure of business confidence and spending plans on equipment.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: Core capital goods shipments, which are used to calculate business equipment spending in the gross domestic product report, fell 0.5 percent in July. They were previously reported to have slipped 0.4 percent in July.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: Manufacturing, which accounts for about 12 percent of the economy, remains constrained by the lingering effects of a strong dollar and weak global demand, which have crimped exports of factory goods.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: A collapse in oil drilling activity following a plunge in oil prices has also squeezed manufacturing by undermining business spending, leading to weak demand for heavy machinery.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: In addition, a U.S. inventory correction has resulted in factories receiving fewer orders. The Institute for Supply Management reported on Thursday

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: that its national factory activity index fell into contraction territory in August for the first time in six months.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: In July, orders for transportation equipment surged 10.6 percent, also the biggest gain since last October. Orders for motor vehicles and parts slipped 0.5 percent.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: Orders for machinery, which have been hurt by weak demand in the energy, mining and agricultural sectors, jumped 1.4 percent - the largest rise in six months.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: Orders for electrical equipment, appliances and components soared 3.7 percent, the biggest gain since June 2014. Orders for computers and electronic products rose 3.4 percent, the largest rise since March 2015.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: Inventories of factory goods edged up 0.1 percent after 12 straight monthly declines. Shipments slipped 0.2 percent. As a result, the inventories-to-shipments ratio was unchanged at 1.35 in July.

Headline: U.S. factory orders post largest increase in nine months
Text: Unfilled orders at factories decreased for a second straight month. REUTERS

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: KFC and Pizza Hut owner Yum Brands Inc <YUM.N> said Chinese investment firm Primavera Capital and an affiliate of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd <BABA.N> will buy a stake in Yum China for $460 million as Yum prepares to spin off the business.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The deal gives Primavera, a powerful China-focused private equity firm founded by an ex-Goldman Sachs banker, a significant stake in Yum's China business. It also further expands the reach of Ant Financial, which runs Alibaba's Alipay mobile payments platform and has been expanding into China's restaurant industry.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The investors will receive warrants to buy an additional 4 percent stake in Yum China in two tranches at valuations of $12 billion and $15 billion, the company said on Friday.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: A Yum spokesman said the use of the proceeds from the deal will be determined by the future Yum China board of directors.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Yum has signaled that part of the money could go toward expanding across China, as the company signaled last October that it hoped to nearly triple the amount of its restaurants in China to 20,000.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: KFC and Pizza Hut brands reaped the rewards of catering to China's booming economy, with patrons flooding the restaurants that offered fast Western food, a higher level of service and perceived food safety.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: But Yum's China business has hit road blocks in recent years, including a scandal at a minor meat supplier and bird flu outbreaks.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Yum, still the largest fast-food chain in China, has also been losing ground to McDonald's Corp <MCD.N>.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The Louisville, Kentucky-based company's move to separate its China business followed pressure last year from one of its largest investors, Corvex Management, the activist hedge fund run by Keith Meister. Meister is on Yum's board.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The spinoff is expected on Oct. 31, with Yum China to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange a day later, the company said on Friday.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Primavera will invest $410 million, while Ant Financial, which runs Alibaba's Alipay mobile payments platform, will put in $50 million. China's sovereign wealth fund and New York private equity firm KKR & Co were also in the hunt for a Yum China stake.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Primavera's founder, Fred Hu, will become non-executive chairman of Yum China's board.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Goldman Sachs is financial adviser, while Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are legal adviser to Yum Brands and Yum China. Simpson Thacher & Bartlett LLP and Fangda Partners are legal advisers to Primavera and Ant.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Yum shares were up 1 percent at $91.70 in morning trading. REUTERS

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: Traders of U.S. short-term interest rate futures trimmed expectations that the Federal Reserve could soon lift interest rates after a government report showed U.S. employers added fewer jobs than expected last month.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: Nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, the Labor Department said on Friday. Economists had expected a gain of 180,000.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: "It is not a compelling number for the Fed and it is not going to force their hand for a hike in September," said Thomas Simons, an analyst at Jefferies.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: The Fed is now seen as only slightly more likely to raise rates in December than to wait until next year before raising rates. Traders are all but ruling out a rate hike later this month.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: Before the report traders saw better than even odds of a December rate hike, based on trading in futures tied to the Fed's policy rate, and a one-in-four chance of a rate hike when the Fed meets Sept. 20-21. REUTERS

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: TORONTO - BlackBerry Ltd said on Friday that its encryption technology is being used to toughen a "spy-proof" Samsung tablet that is being used by German government agencies dealing with classified information.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: The device, a Samsung Galaxy Tab S2, includes a security card and encryption and certification software developed by BlackBerry's Secusmart, which locks down data stored on and transferred from the SecuTABLET, the Canadian company said in a statement.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: Knox, a Samsung security product, is also included.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: Canada's BlackBerry, a smartphone pioneer, has sought to build up its focus on security and productivity software and the management of more popular handsets as it trims its own money-losing phones.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: BlackBerry did not disclose the value of the deal with the German agencies.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: It unveiled its second Android-based handset in July. REUTERS

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: SINGAPORE — The share prices of M1, StarHub and Singtel plummeted on Friday (Sept 2) after the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) announced on Thursday it had received formal expressions of interest from three companies to become Singapore’s fourth mobile carrier.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: Shares in M1, which is especially vulnerable to a new player as its business model is the least diversified, fell as much as 6.8 per cent, while StarHub shares shed as much as 4.7 per cent and Singtel shares lost up to 3.3 per cent. Analysts said the plunge in the share prices was bigger than expected considering that preparations had been made for a fourth telco for some time.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “I think the market is overreacting a little. This (possibility for a fourth telco) is nothing really new; the news yesterday means it’s getting closer to a firm deal,” said Ms Margaret Yang, market analyst at CMC Markets Singapore. “As the news spreads, the selling could last for a couple of days. But eventually it would reach a balance point when people feel it’s oversold. It cannot fall forever.”

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: However, another analyst said the larger number of interested parties and the entrance of Australian stock exchange-listed TPG Telecom into the fray were key factors in the sell-off.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “The share reaction is justified as the three incumbent telcos’ share prices were bid up due to expectations that the potential bidders may fail to raise sufficient funding. The announcement of three bidders, which is more than expected, is also a surprise to investors. The bid from Australia-based TPG is especially surprising. That explained the sharp fall in share prices,” said Mr Bernard Aw, market strategist at financial services firm IG.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: At the close of trading on Friday, M1 shares were down 5.6 per cent at S$2.51, while StarHub shares lost 4.4 per cent to S$3.47 and Singtel shares fell 2.5 per cent to S$3.87.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: The IDA is looking to increase competition in the mobile services market and has said that a new entrant is likely to bring about a wider variety of innovative services and more competitive offerings to consumers.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: On Thursday, the IDA announced that MyRepublic, newly formed company airYotta, and TPG Telecom submitted their expressions of interest to become the fourth mobile operator in Singapore. A spectrum auction to determine the fourth mobile telco is expected by October, with the winning bidder rolling out its services as early as April next year.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “The introduction of a fourth telco is expected to shake up the stagnant and complacent sector. If the new competition is able to force the existing telcos to improve their offerings and services while keeping prices affordable and competitive, this is positive for consumers,” said Mr Aw.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: Analysts told TODAY they foresee competition among the incumbent telcos to intensify in the near term, with M1 to be the most affected by a new player and Singtel to be the least affected. “The cake will be cut by four, so everybody might get a smaller share ... Among these three players, M1 is relatively a small player and so is more susceptible to rising competition in this sector. For Singtel, more than 70 per cent (of its earnings) is from overseas, so it is less susceptible to a fourth telco player in the market,” said CMC Markets’ Ms Yang.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: M1 and StarHub said they are prepared for the upcoming competition, while Singtel declined to comment.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “M1 is not new to competition, and we will continue to compete to protect our market share,” said a company spokesperson.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “We’re always prepared for competition. Regardless of the number of operators in this saturated market, StarHub will keep our focus on ensuring our offerings remain attractive and relevant,” said a StarHub spokesperson.

Headline: Weak global economy, strong dollar weighing on U.S. factories: U.S. labor secretary
Text: WASHINGTON - U.S. Labor Secretary Thomas Perez said on Friday the U.S. economy was enjoying solid job and wage growth, but that a weak global expansion and strong U.S. dollar were hurting the factory sector.

Headline: Weak global economy, strong dollar weighing on U.S. factories: U.S. labor secretary
Text: "When you have the global economy not recovering the way our economy is and when you have that strong dollar, when you're making things to sell to other countries they are now more expensive and the demand for those products ... is not what it needs to be," Perez told CNBC. "Those are the headwinds that we're seeing in manufacturing." REUTERS

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: PARIS - Louis Vuitton has launched its first perfume range since the founding merger of its parent LVMH <LVMH.PA> in 1987, targeting middle-income shoppers amid a downturn in luxury spending.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: This week's launch is an important step for the French brand as it tries to strike the delicate balance between increasing its number of more affordable goods while retaining its cachet.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Until now, shoppers on more modest incomes have only been catered for by Louis Vuitton's key chains and very small leather goods, costing around 200-300 euros apiece.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: But the brand needs to boost sales growth after a sharp slowdown in the past three years, and with little sign of an industry recovery as security fears and geo-political uncertainty hit the tourism flows vital for luxury brands.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Louis Vuitton's collection of seven perfumes, with names including "turbulences" and "matiere noire" or "dark matter," are on sale for around 200 euros ($224) for a 100 ml bottle.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: That is close to the price of niche perfume brands such as By Kilian, which have been enjoying sales growth four to five times higher than big, traditional fragrance providers whose prices cost under 100 euros.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Perfume has been more resilient to the industry downturn than some parts of the luxury market, with global sales estimated to have risen 2.9 percent to about 15 billion euros last year. Within that, sales by niche brands jumped about 15 percent to around 1 billion euros.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: At first, Louis Vuitton will sell the perfumes in only about 180 of its 460 stores. Analysts estimate they could generate 60-80 million euros of sales in the first year.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: By comparison, luxury giants such as Chanel and LVMH's Dior, whose products are much more widely distributed, make about 2.5 billion euros a year from perfumes and cosmetics.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Louis Vuitton, which declined to say how much it has invested in the project, gave star industry "nose" Jacques Cavallier-Belletrud four years to prepare the launch.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: The perfumer, who worked for decades with fragrance producer Firmenich, created many commercially successful perfumes including L'Eau d'Issey for Issey Miyake and L'Oreal's <OREP.PA> Poeme for Lancome and Acqua di Gio for Armani.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Some industry analysts said Louis Vuitton took its time with the launch partly out of concern the move could exacerbate its ubiquity problem - the result of having opened too many shops, which dented its perceived exclusivity.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Since 2012, the brand has worked to remedy this by putting the brakes on expansion and elevating its market positioning by producing more expensive handbags, with many available only in limited numbers.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: ($1 = 0.8912 euros) REUTERS

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: WASHINGTON — Employers in the United States created fewer jobs than forecast in August after two straight months of robust gains, lowering the likelihood that the central bank will raise its key interest rate later this month.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: Non-farm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with hiring in manufacturing and construction sectors declining, the Labor Department said yesterday. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.9 per cent as more people entered the job market. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast payrolls rising 180,000 last month and the unemployment rate slipping one-tenth of a percentage point to 4.8 per cent.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: Wall Street opened higher yesterday after the data release, which comes more than two weeks before the Federal Reserve’s Sept 20-21 policy meeting. About five minutes after the opening bell in New York, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.5 per cent at 18,512. The greenback dropped 0.4 per cent to US$1.1240 per euro and fell at a similar pace to 102.87 yen.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: “We had a couple of above-average numbers in the last two months. This is a below-average number. All that suggests the job market is OK but it probably does put September off the table” for an interest rate rise, Mr Jeff Kleintop, chief global investment strategist at financial services firm Charles Schwab said on CNBC TV.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: The Fed has three more policy meetings this year. Fed funds futures data showed the probability of a rate hike in the September meeting falling to 12 per cent from the 27 per cent level before the job data. The likelihood of a rate increase by November fell to 21 per cent from 32 per cent, while the probability of such a move by December dropped to 52 per cent from 58 per cent.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: Analysts said despite the weaker-than-expected job creation, last month’s payrolls data could still be sufficient to push the Fed to tighten policy in December. The rise in payrolls reinforces views that the world’s largest economy has regained speed after almost stalling in the first half of the year.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: The central bank lifted its benchmark overnight interest rate to between 0.25 and 0.5 per cent at the end of last year for the first time in nearly a decade, but has held it steady since amid concerns over persistently low inflation. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last Friday that the case for raising borrowing costs had strengthened in recent months. With the labour market near full employment and the economy’s recovery from the 2007-09 recession showing signs of ageing, a slowdown in job growth is normal. Ms Yellen has said the economy needs to create just under 100,000 jobs a month to keep up with population growth.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: The timing of the next rate hike could also be determined by wage growth. Average hourly earnings increased three cents in August to US$25.73, or a 0.1 per cent rise, after a solid 0.3 per cent rise in July. The moderation in gains pulled down the year-on-year gain to 2.4 per cent from 2.6 per cent in July. AGENCIES

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: WASHINGTON - The U.S. trade deficit fell more than expected in July as exports rose to their highest level in 10 months, offering further evidence that economic growth picked up early in the third quarter.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: The Commerce Department said on Friday the trade gap narrowed 11.6 percent to $39.5 billion, declining after three straight months of increases. June's trade deficit was revised slightly up to $44.7 billion.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Economists polled by Reuters had forecast the trade gap decreasing to $42.7 billion in July after a previously reported $44.5 billion shortfall. When adjusted for inflation, the deficit dropped to $58.3 billion from $64.5 billion in June.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: The trade report added to upbeat reports on consumer spending, industrial production and residential construction that have suggested the economy has regained momentum after output increased 1.0 percent in the first half.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Despite July's increase, exports continue to be hobbled by the residual effects of the dollar's surge against the currencies of the United States' main trading partners between June 2014 and December.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Export growth could come under pressure. International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde told Reuters this week the IMF would likely downgrade its 2016 global growth forecast because of weak demand, flagging trade and investment.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Exports of goods and services rose 1.9 percent in July to $186.3 billion, the highest since September 2015. Exports to the European Union dropped 9.5 percent, with goods shipped to the United Kingdom falling 9.2 percent.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Exports to China increased 3.8 percent.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Imports of goods and services slipped 0.8 percent to $225.8 billion in July. Oil prices averaged $41.02 per barrel in July, the highest level since September 2015.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: It was the fifth consecutive month that oil prices increased.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Imports from China rose 2.4 percent. The politically sensitive U.S.-China trade deficit increased 1.9 percent to $30.3 billion in July. REUTERS

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia - Russia hopes to fetch more than $11 billion for a minority stake in the Kremlin's flagship oil producer Rosneft before the end of the year to plug budget holes caused by low crude prices, an industry source told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: The sale will be complicated by sanctions imposed on Moscow over its actions in Ukraine and by many investors' wariness of putting money into Russia as well as volatile commodity markets.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: But Russia is hoping to repeat the success of Rosneft's initial share offering a decade ago when it raised $11 billion in one of the world's biggest such sales, despite concerns that investors would be spooked by Rosneft's purchase of most of the assets of oil firm YUKOS, bankrupted by the Kremlin.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: On Friday, Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev said his ministry had received documents needed to kick start the sale of 19.5 percent in Rosneft, including a valuation and proposals on terms of sale.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: An industry source familiar with the sale process said the stake had been valued at over $11 billion. The documents were submitted this week by Rosneftegas, which controls Rosneft on behalf of the government. Italian bank Intesa is advising Rosneftegas on the sale.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: In comments to Russian news agencies later on Friday, Ulyukayev said estimates the stake would be valued at around $11 billion were close to reality.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: After privatization, the government will keep 50 percent plus one share in Rosneft, the world's largest oil firm by reserves among listed companies.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Rosneft produces over a third of Russia's total output of 10.7 million barrels per day - a figure making Russia the world's biggest producer on a par with Saudi Arabia and the United States.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Russian President Vladimir Putin said the sale of the stake should take place before the end of the year and should involve strategic investors.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: "I think we should be aiming precisely for that type of investment. We are getting ready and are planning to do it this year," Putin told Bloomberg News.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Oil major BP owns just under 20 percent in Rosneft following the purchase of BP's Russian joint venture TNK-BP by Rosneft for $50 billion in 2013.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Rosneft's own market value has fallen to $55 billion since then as a result of low oil prices and sanctions imposed on Russia, Rosneft and its chief executive Igor Sechin, one of Putin's closest allies.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: At its initial public offering (IPO), Rosneft was worth nearly $80 billion. Western majors will find it difficult to invest in Rosneft due to sanctions but their place could be taken by Asian investors, including from China and India, which have been seeking to develop resources in Russia.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Russia is effectively competing with many other resource rich countries for money from investors to compensate for low commodities prices.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: The world's largest non-listed oil firm by reserves and output, Saudi Aramco, is planning to list up to a 5 percent stake in the next two years, seeking an overall valuation of over $2 trillion.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: The industry source said Rosneftegas was asking the government to issue a decree guaranteeing a stable tax regime during the sale of the stake and beyond.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: "You cannot attract solid investors if the tax regime keeps changing," the source said. REUTERS

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: LONDON - Investors pulled billions of dollars out of cash in the latest week and turned towards an array of bond funds and equities -- notably bank stocks -- ahead of the keenly awaited August U.S. employment report, Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Friday.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Precious metals funds suffered their biggest weekly outflow of the year as expectations of higher U.S. interest rates by the end of the year strengthened, BAML said.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Flows into emerging market bond funds reached record levels in the week ending Aug. 31, while European equity funds chalked up a record-breaking 30th consecutive weekly outflow.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Economists expect non-farm payrolls report later on Friday to show 180,000 new jobs were created last month, a dip in the unemployment rate and continued wage growth. A strong report could set the seal on the Federal Reserve raising rates in December, maybe even before.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: "Banks are back," BAML said in a note titled "Banking on Payrolls".

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Financial equity funds drew in $1.2 billion, the biggest inflow in 10 months, although BAML cautioned that a stubbornly flat U.S. yield curve has yet to confirm a cyclical upturn in the sector.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Banks profit from a steeper yield curve, when the gap between long-term and short-term yields widens. The opposite, a flattening curve, is generally bad for banks and the U.S. curve is currently around its flattest since late 2007.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Money market funds posted an outflow of $16.7 billion in the week to Aug. 31, and precious metals funds an outflow of $600 million.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Investors pulled $1.1 billion out of European equity funds, marking the 30th consecutive weekly redemption, although the pace of outflows is slowing, BAML said.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Stocks in general, however, posted an inflow of $1.8 billion, led by U.S. and emerging market funds.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: So far this year, investors have withdrawn $132.3 billion from developed market equity funds, while emerging market stock funds are up $2.2 billion.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: In fixed income, emerging market bond funds attracted investment for a record ninth week in a row, although the $700 million inflow was the lowest in that time.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Investment grade corporate bond funds attracted a $2.3 billion inflow, the 25th inflow out of the past 26 weeks, while government bond funds posted their eighth consecutive outflow.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Bond funds in total have posted a net inflow of $148.6 billion so far this year, BAML said. REUTERS

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: TOKYO - Japan wants to boost its ability to secure natural resources, but the government was not considering an investment in Russian state-owned oil giant Rosneft, Trade Minister Hiroshige Seko said on Friday.

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: The Nikkei reported on Friday that the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) was considering investing as much as 1 trillion yen ($9.7 billion) to buy 10 percent of Rosneft through the government-backed Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corp, or JOGMEC.

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: The report came as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe prepared to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin on the sidelines of a business conference in Vladivostok to discuss closer cooperation in such areas as energy and technology.

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: Seko, the newly appointed minister for economic cooperation with Russia who will accompany Abe on the trip to Vladivostok, denied METI was considering an investment in Rosneft through JOGMEC.

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: He confirmed that cabinet is considering a bill to reinforce the ability of JOGMEC to secure supplies of natural resources, but said the move did not target any particular countries or deals.

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: Under current law, JOGMEC is able to support Japanese companies when they buy a stake in foreign mines and energy assets, but it is not able to offer support when they buy a stake in foreign resource companies and is not able to buy stakes in foreign companies itself.

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: The government may make it possible for JOGMEC to acquire stakes in foreign state-backed resource companies on its own, another METI official said.

Headline: Japan trade minister denies Rosneft investment report
Text: The move comes at a time when some oil producing countries are trying to privatize their oil companies to offset falling revenue in the face of slumping oil prices. REUTERS

Headline: Samsung Electronics will recall Galaxy Note 7 globally: Yonhap
Text: SEOUL - Tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd will announce a global recall of the Galaxy Note 7 smartphones following reports of the devices catching on fire, South Korea's Yonhap News Agency reported on Friday citing an unnamed source.

Headline: Samsung Electronics will recall Galaxy Note 7 globally: Yonhap
Text: Yonhap said Samsung will likely replace the batteries on Galaxy Note 7 smartphones through the recall, without citing a source. It was not clear how many phones would get a battery replacement. REUTERS

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: Heavy machinery maker Caterpillar Inc <CAT.N> said it could lay off about 2,000 employees at a plant in Belgium, as it considers shifting production to other facilities as part of a restructuring program announced last year.

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: The company, which manufactures construction equipment at the plant in Gosselies, Belgium said it may shift the production to its facility at Grenoble, France and other locations outside of Europe.

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: Caterpillar said in September 2015 that it will cut as many as 10,000 jobs through 2018 and also might close or consolidate more than 20 plants around the world as it grappled with the mining and energy downturn.

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: In July, Caterpillar said that global uncertainty, the vote in Britain to leave the European Union and the attempted coup in Turkey had heightened risks, especially in Europe. REUTERS

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: SINGAPORE — The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) intends to introduce by the fourth quarter legislative amendments aimed at boosting safeguards for wealthier investors.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: If passed by lawmakers, the central bank will aim to implement the changes to the so-called “accredited investor (AI)” regime next year, the MAS said in an e-mailed response to questions from Bloomberg on Friday (Sept 2).

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The timetable for the first parliamentary reading is in line with the central bank’s statement almost a year ago, when it said it would submit the proposals in 2016. The revisions are aimed at granting some wealthy individuals the option to choose protections available to retail investors. Singapore law assumes rich investors are better informed or have greater means to protect their own interests, and therefore exempts banks from having to provide certain disclosures about financial products that are made to retail investors.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: “Consistent with the practice in other major financial jurisdictions, the full suite of regulatory protection under the capital markets regulatory framework is aimed primarily at retail investors,” the MAS said.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: “The proposed refinements to the AI regime formed part of a package of proposals to enhance regulatory safeguards for investors in the capital markets.”

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: Under Singapore law, an individual accredited investor is a person who has more than S$2 million in personal assets including property, or made at least S$300,000 of income in the preceding 12 months. When dealing with accredited investors, banks and brokerages are exempt from certain requirements, such as having to provide a prospectus.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The proposed amendments will give such wealthy individuals the option to be treated as retail investors, thus extending relevant regulatory safeguards to them, the MAS said. The revision will also tighten the S$2 million net personal assets threshold so that an investor’s primary home can only contribute up to half that value, the MAS said.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: Some wealthy Singaporean investors are facing losses after a series of defaults among local dollar-denominated corporate bonds since November. Last month, energy services firm Swiber Holdings joined PT Trikomsel Oke and Pacific Andes Resources Development in defaulting on bond obligations.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: Private banks took up 49 per cent to 92 per cent of the unrated notes issued by the three companies in their sales from April 2013 to October 2014, according to a Bloomberg News analysis of figures from bond-sale arrangers and compiled by analysts.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: In its statement, the MAS called on private banks to consider their clients’ individual circumstances, investment portfolios and risk profiles in offering any investment product and services.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: “Notwithstanding the AI status of clients, private banks are expected to adopt fair business practices and act in the best interests of their clients,” the central bank said, adding that private banks are expected to adhere to the code of conduct “which sets out rigorous standards for dealing with their clients”.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The MAS also said it’s conducting “consumer testing” on a complexity-risk ratings framework for investment products, to determine whether such a measure would be useful in decision making by investors. The authority said it will issue a statement on the matter “at a later date.”

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The framework was among several proposals including the investor protection amendments unveiled in a July 2014 consultation paper by the central bank. The system will take into account various factors that drive a product’s complexity in assigning a risk rating, such as the number of layers between the investor and the underlying asset, and the extensiveness of derivatives usage. BLOOMBERG

Headline: Russian minister says $11 billion Rosneft stake valuation close to reality
Text: MOSCOW - Russian Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev said on Friday that a valuation of around $11 billion for the stake in Russian oil producer Rosneft that the government plans to privatize was close to reality, RIA news agency reported.

Headline: Russian minister says $11 billion Rosneft stake valuation close to reality
Text: Ulyukayev also said the Rosneft stake sale could happen at any moment from October and that the chances of its privatization this year were above 50 percent, RIA said. REUTERS

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: SAN FRANCISCO - Alphabet Inc’s <GOOGL.O> Google has suspended Project Ara, its ambitious effort to build what is known as a modular smartphone with interchangeable components, as part of a broader push to streamline the company's hardware efforts, two people with knowledge of the matter said.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: The move marks an about-face for the tech company, which announced a host of partners for Project Ara at its developer conference in May and said it would ship a developer edition of the product this autumn.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: The company’s aim was to create a phone that users could customize on the fly with an extra battery, camera, speakers or other components.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: A spokeswoman for Google declined to comment on the matter.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: While Google will not be releasing the phone itself, the company may work with partners to bring Project Ara’s technology to market, potentially through licensing agreements, one of the people with knowledge of the matter said.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Axing Project Ara is one of the first steps in a campaign to unify Google’s various hardware efforts, which range from Chromebook laptops to Nexus phones. Former Motorola president Rick Osterloh rejoined Google earlier this year to oversee the effort. Google sold Motorola Mobility to Lenovo Group in 2014.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Modular smartphones have generated great enthusiasm in the tech community for their potential to prolong the lifespan of a device and reduce electronic waste. But the devices are difficult to bring to market because their interchangeable parts make them bulky and costly to produce, said analyst Bob O’Donnell of TECHnalysis Research, adding that he was not surprised to see Google halt the project.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: “This was a science experiment that failed, and they are moving on,” he said.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Project Ara was one of the flagship efforts of Google’s Advanced Technology and Projects group, which aims to develop new devices, but it had various stops and starts.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Last year, the company shelved plans to sell the modular phone in Puerto Rico with Latin American carriers. REUTERS

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: SINGAPORE — All three telcos in Singapore have stopped sales of Samsung’s Galaxy Note7, after the South Korean company announced a global recall following reports of faulty batteries causing its latest flagship smartphone to catch fire.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Singtel, Singapore’s biggest telco, said on Friday (Sept 2): “Following official notification from Samsung, Singtel has suspended sales of Galaxy Note7 devices. We are working with Samsung on an exchange programme for customers who have purchased the device. We will keep our customers closely updated.” Likewise, StarHub and M1 said they have stopped sales in line with Samsung’s global halt and will provide updates on phone exchanges later.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: The Galaxy Note7, which was launched in Singapore on Aug 20, has been wildly popular with Android users who flocked to pre-order the device at the three major telcos, Samsung Experience stores, major consumer electronics stores Best Denki, Courts, Gain City, Hachi, and Harvey Norman as well as Lazada Singapore.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: However, a Samsung spokesperson told TODAY that “Samsung is unable to share any figures on Note7 units sold in Singapore”.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Reports have emerged worldwide of the Galaxy Note7 catching fire during charging, with several people posting images and videos of their charred devices online. The smartphone has been launched in 10 countries so far and Samsung said there have been 35 cases globally as of Thursday.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Samsung said it conducted a thorough investigation and found a battery problem but added it was “inappropriate to comment at this time which manufacturer’s battery cells were faulty”.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: “We are currently conducting a thorough inspection with our suppliers to identify possible affected batteries in the market. However, because our customers’ safety is an absolute priority at Samsung, we have stopped sales of the Galaxy Note7,” the company said. Customers who have bought the Note7 could get it replaced with a new one in the coming weeks, and instructions on the replacement process will be announced next week.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: “We acknowledge the inconvenience this may cause in the market but this is to ensure that Samsung continues to deliver the highest quality products to our customers. We are working closely with our partners to ensure the replacement experience is as convenient and efficient as possible,” the company said. Samsung did not reveal how many Galaxy Note7 phones will be recalled but said it would replace all phones sold to customers as well as retailers.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: The Galaxy Note7 recall is a blow to Samsung’s reputation and robs the company of momentum it had built in smartphones by capitalising on a lull in demand for Apple devices between new iPhone models.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Demand for the iris-reading Note7, which debuted to glowing reviews, and the release of the company’s biggest profit in two years had driven its share price to a record as analysts raised their price targets.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Shares of Samsung closed 0.6 per cent higher at 1,597,000 won on Friday before the recall was announced.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: “The unexpected recall would surely irritate buyers and the latest incident looks worrisome,” said Mr Lee Seung-woo, an analyst at IBK Securities in Seoul. He expects shipments of the Galaxy Note7 this year will shrink to 12 million units from a previous estimate of 14 million. He estimates the total number of handsets affected by the battery problem to be one million, with about 600,000 units sold outside South Korea.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Rival smartphone maker Apple has invited journalists to an event in San Francisco on Wednesday, where the world’s most valuable public company is expected to introduce next-generation versions of the iPhone and Apple Watch. AGENCIES

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: TOKYO - Japan has asked the European Aviation Safety Agency to ensure a problem with Rolls-Royce <RR.L> engines powering Boeing <BA.N> 787 Dreamliners does not repeat to cause flight disruptions or affect safety.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Japan's Ministry of Land Infrastructure Transport and Tourism said on Friday it issued the request after ANA Holdings <9202.T>, Japan's biggest carrier, canceled 18 flights last month to repair corroded turbine blades in the Rolls-Royce engines on some its Dreamliner fleet.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Officials at the EASA were not immediately available for comment.
