Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Since February, three ANA flights have experienced engine trouble, once on a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Tokyo, a second time in March on a jet traveling to Vietnam and most recently on a domestic route in August.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: The biggest operator of the carbon composite jet on Tuesday said it would replace the faulty turbine blades in all 100 engines on its 50 aircraft, an operation that could take as long as three years to complete.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Of around 450 Dreamliners in operation worldwide, two fifths use the Rolls-Royce engines. Carriers can choose either the Rolls-Royce engines or General Electric Co's <GE.N> GEnx engines for their Dreamliners. REUTERS

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: U.S. employment growth slowed more than expected in August after two straight months of robust gains and wage gains moderated, which could effectively rule out an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve this month.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: KEY POINTS:* Headline job growth at 151k vs 180k estimate

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: * Private sector adds 126k vs 178k estimate

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: * Unemployment rate steady at 4.9 percent

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: * Revisions: July up 20k to 275k; June down 21k to 271k

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: COMMENTS:QUINCY KROSBY, MARKET STRATEGIST, PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL, NEWARK, NEW JERSEY:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "With equity futures rising, the dollar weakening, gold strengthening, and the 10-year yield pulling back, the market has voted and says a September rate hike is off the table. While the report is solid and could be subject to a positive revision, it falls short of providing a resounding vote for a September move by the Fed. Although there will be a full parade of data before the meeting, there is a premium on the employment data. It was solid but not the stellar numbers needed to convince the market that September is in play."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: RANDY FREDERICK, MANAGING DIRECTOR, TRADING AND DERIVATIVES, CHARLES SCHWAB, AUSTIN, TEXAS:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "Nothing to surprise a whole lot of people in any of this. I think the non-farm payroll number was just a little bit weak but it's nothing to be alarmed about.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't think this particular report, given where it came in at, is enough to move the markets in any material way. Surprisingly the equity futures have responded fairly positively.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "It's not at all surprising to see us move a little higher given that we are at the low end of the range we have been in for the last six weeks. But is this going to be enough to push us out? I'd be very surprised if that happened."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: GREG PETERS,  SENIOR INVESTMENT OFFICER AT PRUDENTIAL FIXED INCOME,  NEWARK, NEW JERSEY:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "Today's payroll figure definitely pushes the September rate hike and it looks like we are data dependent even more so for the rest of the year. I think incoming economic data will create a little more volatility in the fourth quarter. Overall,  I can't believe that after 256 days since the December rate hike last year with hundreds of economic data releases since that time, it seems ludicrous that the Fed's decision is singularly predicated on one single data release that is known to be volatile and subject to significant revisions. Could this really be the case, or are the markets simply putting too much stock in selected events to create their own guideposts given the Fed's poor communication strategy? Either way, to me, this loudly speaks to their massive communication problem and why the markets are increasingly losing confidence in the institution as a consequence."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: TONY BEDIKIAN, HEAD OF GLOBAL MARKETS AT CITIZENS BANK, BOSTON:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "The number came in obviously a little bit below expectations, but still close to 150,000 new jobs. I think the Fed will still view that quite positively. The revisions the last two months were about flat, and I think the Fed is cognizant that the August number historically has had the greatest likelihood of being revised upward by roughly 70,000 jobs on average. So all in all, it looks like a fairly positive number here."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "The market would like to have seen a  200,000 plus payroll print to really get the Fed off the fence. There is still a possibility that the Fed does go in September, because overall the payroll trend has still been positive, the market has priced in about a 1 in 3 chance still of the Fed going later this month, and we still have a little bit more data, there are some inflation numbers to see between now and then, so if we do get some uptick in the inflation data, the CPI and PPI later this month prior to the Fed meeting on the 21st, then  the Fed could go. I think this number doesn't necessarily jog the Fed in the near-term."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: KEVIN LOGAN, CHIEF U.S. ECONOMIST, HSBC SECURITIES, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "At the margin it dissuades the Fed from moving in September. It's not a clincher. If they feel they want to go for other reasons they can. But this jobs report is not a compelling reason.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "The wage gains are very modest and that's important. The whole logic here is that a tighter labor market, means rising wages, means upward pressure on inflation – and for that reason they should reduce accommodation. But that's not happening, so this report does not compel them to move."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: HEIDI LEARNER, CHIEF ECONOMIST, SAVILLS STUDLEY, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't think it shifts the thinking, I do think it could be fifty-fifty. It's not surprising to see moderation in the three-month average is still OK. The only thing that was a little bit surprising to me was the slowdown in temporary help and employment services, which always makes me a little nervous. But there wasn't enough weakness in the report to derail the Fed, but similarly it would not be a mistake now if they waited until December rather than September."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: CRAIG BISHOP, LEAD STRATEGIST FOR U.S. FIXED INCOME, RBC WEALTH MANAGEMENT, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I think (the jobs data) points to continued hiring although some of the other numbers, what we refer to as the Yellen indicators - the measure of slack in the labor force, wages, labor force participation and underemployment –  really showed no progress, in fact wages were lower from a month ago. I think it points to continued hiring but not progress made on those measures that the Fed and Yellen look at to indicate a lessening of slack in the labor force. Looking at it in context of what it means for the September FOMC meeting."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I think it continues to point to a solid employment picture in the U.S., but it wasn't that big blowout number that in our opinion would've been needed to cause the Fed to tilt toward a September rate hike. I think you'll see that reflected in rate hike probabilities throughout the day. So we move on now to focusing on whether it's December or 2017."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: MOHAMED EL-ERIAN, CHIEF ECONOMIC ADVISER, ALLIANZ, NEWPORT BEACH, CALIFORNIA:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "This mixed jobs report puts the Fed in a tricky situation. It's not all around strong enough to assure a September interest rate hike. But it's solid enough to engender a heated policy discussion, especially given the unintended consequences and collateral damage of a prolonged period of ultra low interest rates."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: JASON CELENTE, SENIOR FIXED INCOME PORTFOLIO MANAGER, INSIGHT INVESTMENT, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't think it means much. Net of revisions the import statistics like the headline payroll number and the hourly earnings number were pretty much in line with consensus and trend. As far as the Fed is concerned, I don't think it's a number that is a major setback for what they ultimately want to achieve, which is that a slow and gradual pace for a rate normalization.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "If you look at the probabilities, the market is likely to trade with anticipation for changes in Fed policy, and if you look at what the market has been pricing for September and December respectively, I think those odds are  probably fairly accurate in our view and I don't think the numbers today really change those probabilities."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: SEAN LYNCH, CO-HEAD OF GLOBAL EQUITY STRATEGY, WELLS FARGO INVESTMENT INSTITUTE, OMAHA, NEBRASKA:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "People are taking a little bit of a relief that it wasn't a 200,000 plus print, certainly in the equity market. 151,000 is a good number, when you look at the last three months we are 230,000-plus on average. Our belief is that equity markets are going to give the Fed at least one rate increase but if they start to perceive a series of hikes coming and coming sooner than later, that is when equity markets will get a little nervous here. But the 150,000 number doesn't increase the odds of that at all."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't know about (September) wiped off the table because the Fed, some of the rhetoric we've seen has been pretty mixed the past couple of weeks. Our view is that they do hold off until later this year, possibly even December or early next year before raising rates. We think slow, steady growth until the end of the year is still a good backdrop for equities, but taking a sigh of relief that it wasn't a blowout number which really would have ratcheted up September and possibly other increases later this year."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: TOM PORCELLI, CHIEF US ECONOMIST, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "It was a middling report at best, particularly as it relates to the conversation on the Fed. There were no positive standouts here, the key underlying data were all pretty soft as well. I don't think this is the kind of the report that the Fed wanted to see ahead of a hike in September, the contours are just too squishy. This should put to rest the conversation on September."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: MARKET REACTION:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: STOCKS: U.S. equity index futures rise

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: BONDS: 2-year and 10-year Treasury yield curve steepens

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: RATE FUTURES: Fed funds futures prices rise across the term structure. September contract up 0.5 basis point; December up 2 basis points. Probability of a September hike dips to just 18 percent from around 24 percent before the release

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: FOREX: The dollar weakens against the euro and yen

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: (Americas Economics and Markets Desk; +1-646 223-6300) REUTERS

Headline: Samsung Elec says to hold Galaxy Note 7 briefing on Friday afternoon
Text: SEOUL - Tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd <005930.KS> said on Friday its mobile business chief Koh Dong-jin will hold a press briefing at 5 p.m. local time (0400 ET) on the findings of its investigation on the product quality of the Galaxy Note 7.

Headline: Samsung Elec says to hold Galaxy Note 7 briefing on Friday afternoon
Text: Samsung had said on Wednesday it stopped supplying the new smartphone to South Korea's top three carriers and was delaying shipments for additional quality control inspections following claims from some users that their phone caught fire while charging. REUTERS

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: TOKYO - Japan will propose a broad cooperation in the energy sector with Russia that could include a nearly $10 billion investment in Russian state-owned oil giant Rosneft, the Nikkei newspaper reported on Friday.

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: The report comes as Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin on the sidelines of a two-day business conference beginning Friday in Vladivostok.

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: The two are expected to discuss closer cooperation in such areas as energy and technology, with Japan hoping to strengthen economic ties and create a breakthrough in a decades-long territorial dispute.

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: The Nikkei said the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) is considering investing as much as 1 trillion yen ($9.7 billion) to buy 10 percent of Rosneft through the government-backed Japan Oil, Gas and Metals National Corp, or Jogmec.

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: In addition, Japan will consider joint surveys for oil and gas projects in Eastern Siberia and the Russian Far East. It will also seek technical cooperation in decommissioning the Fukushima Daiichi power plant, the site of the 2011 nuclear disaster, the paper said.

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: METI was not immediately available for comment.

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: METI Minister Hiroshige Seko, the newly appointed minister for economic cooperation with Russia, is accompanying Abe on the trip to Vladivostok.

Headline: Japan may invest $10 billion in Russian oil firm Rosneft: Nikkei
Text: ($1 = 103.1600 yen) REUTERS

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: DETROIT - Volkswagen AG <VOWG_p.DE> said on Thursday it has filed an appeal of a federal labor board decision on its dispute with the United Auto Workers union in Tennessee to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The National Labor Relations board on Aug. 26 sided with the UAW in the union's effort to get VW to negotiate wages and benefits for about 160 of the 1,500 hourly workers at a VW plant in Chattanooga, Tennessee.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: Thursday's filing was expected. The NLRB decision for the UAW in the dispute was highly anticipated, and VW had previously said it would appeal if the ruling went against the German-based company.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The union sought to represent only a portion of the plant's workers after it in February 2014 narrowly lost an election to represent all 1,500 hourly workers at the Chattanooga plant.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: In December 2015, the union handily won the right to represent about 160 skilled trades workers who maintain machinery at the plant.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The UAW has never been able to win an organizing vote at a foreign-owned auto assembly plant in the U.S. south. A victory, even for only a portion of workers at the VW plant, would give the union a stronger foothold in the south, where most foreign-owned auto plants are located.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: On Thursday, VW said in a statement that it "respects the right of all of our employees to decide the question of union representation. This is why we disagree with the decision to separate Volkswagen maintenance and production workers and will continue our effort to allow everyone to vote as one group on the matter of union representation."

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: UAW Secretary-Treasurer Gary Casteel said in a statement on Thursday evening that the union is "disappointed that Volkswagen is continuing to thumb its nose at the federal government. The federal courts have consistently upheld the NLRB labor standard that enabled the skilled-trades vote in Chattanooga."

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The UAW has for several years been assisted in its effort to organize workers in Tennessee by the powerful German union IG Metall, which has members on the VW Supervisory Board.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: Earlier on Thursday, the head of IG Metall, Joerg Hofman, demanded that VW enter talks with the UAW-represented workers.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: IG Metall in a statement said that Hofman "is calling for VW to no longer act contrary to American labor law, and to seek talks with UAW without delay." REUTERS

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: DUBLIN (Ireland) — Ireland’s fragile minority government meets for crunch talks to resolve a stalemate on Friday after an EU ruling on Apple that has divided the country and undermined a cornerstone of its economic policy.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Ireland needs to decide whether to appeal the ruling to take 13 billion euros (S$19.8 billion) in taxes from the US tech giant, with growing public pressure to use the money to ease the pain of years of austerity.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: The money is equivalent to around five per cent of Ireland’s gross domestic product last year and almost all of its annual healthcare budget.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Finance Minister Michael Noonan described the landmark European Commission verdict on Tuesday as “bizarre” and vowed to challenge the finding that Ireland had given Apple special treatment.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: But an emergency cabinet meeting on Wednesday that had been expected to fast-track the appeal to the European Court of Justice failed to reach a consensus.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Instead independent ministers in the coalition government have refused to agree, and sought an early recall of parliament to vote on the issue.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: The Irish Times newspaper described the EU Commission’s ruling as a “mini-earthquake”, saying that an inability to agree a common strategy could “end with the crumbling of the coalition” and cause early elections.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: ‘DO THE RIGHT THING’

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Ireland’s minority government, led by the Fine Gael party, includes a number of independents and relies on the support of the main opposition Fianna Fail party, which is likely to back an appeal against the EU ruling.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Some in the government believe Ireland cannot afford to undermine its tax policies, one of the main planks of a highly successful inward investment strategy that has consistently attracted the world’s top tech and pharma multinationals over the past three decades.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Others believe Ireland should take the money the European Commission says it is owed and spend it on services or build more affordable homes to deal with a housing crisis.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Ireland has two months to lodge an appeal against the ruling.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: The concern for government is that public opinion could strengthen against an appeal in the run-up to a tough budget scheduled for October, which will have to deal with the economic fall-out for Ireland from neighbouring Britain’s vote to leave the European Union.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: Fianna Fail technology spokesman James Lawless said Ireland had to appeal but admitted this would be difficult to explain to voters who wanted the money “gift-wrapped on their doorstep”.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: “I would be more interested in preserving Ireland’s sovereign tax status,” he said, accusing the European Commission of interfering in Ireland’s tax affairs.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: “Ireland has been caught in the crossfire between the United States and Europe,” he said.

Headline: Apple ruling pushes Irish government to the brink
Text: On Thursday, Apple chief Tim Cook turned up the heat further stating his belief that the Irish government “would do the right thing”. AFP

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE - President Barack Obama will likely have discussions with world leaders at the upcoming G20 meeting in China about controlling corporate tax avoidance and creating a more fair global tax system, the White House said on Thursday.

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: The EU ruled this week ruled that Apple must pay $13 billion euro ($14.5 billion) in back tax payments, a decision the Obama administration has criticized.

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said he did not expect headlines about progress on corporate tax avoidance from the G20 meeting of global economic leaders that runs Sunday through Monday.

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: "But I would anticipate that this is an issue that the President will engage in, in the context of discussions at the G20," Earnest said. REUTERS

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: HONG KONG - Private equity firms Carlyle Group <CG.O> and TPG Capital have teamed up with two separate Chinese state companies to bid for McDonald's <MCD.N> outlets in China and Hong Kong in a deal worth between $2 billion and $3 billion, four people familiar with the matter said.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: The sources said the global buyout firms are pairing up with strategic bidders that more closely fit the profile McDonald's has said it is looking for; long-term partners, rather than private equity firms, which typically cash out after a few years.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Carlyle is working with Chinese state conglomerate CITIC Group, and TPG has joined hands with Beijing Capital Agribusiness Group, to place binding bids ahead of the mid-September deadline, the people added. Beijing Capital Agribusiness is McDonald's current China partner.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Carlyle and TPG would have a large minority stake in their respective consortium, one of the people said.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Reuters previously reported that the Illinois-based fast-food giant, which has been hit by a series of food-supply scandals in China, had hired Morgan Stanley <MS.N> to run the sale of about 2,800 restaurants in China, Hong Kong and South Korea.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: The two private equity-backed groups are only bidding for China and Hong Kong outlets and will be pitted against China Cinda Asset Management Co <1359.HK>, Beijing Tourism Group and private Chinese technology and real estate firm Sanpower Group, one of the people added.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: China and Hong Kong account for more than 85 percent of the total 2,800 outlets up for grabs.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Separately, South Korea's Maeil Dairy Industry Co Ltd <005990.KQ> said it was considering bidding for McDonald's local outlets, which are expected to fetch about $268 million. The company declined to say whether it would seek a partner, but a South Korean media report said Maeil was likely to link up with Carlyle.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: CJ Corp and NHN Entertainment Corp were among the other South Korean companies that have previously shown interest in the fast food giant's business in the country.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: McDonald's is switching to a less capital-intensive franchise model and is offering a 20-year franchise to buyers, with a 10-year extension option.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: The franchise model has also been adopted by other fast-food operators, including arch rival Yum Brands <YUM.N>, which licences KFC and Pizza Hut outlets.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Carlyle, TPG, Sanpower and Cinda declined to comment, and CITIC and Beijing Capital Agribusiness Group did not reply to requests for comment.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: A McDonald's spokeswoman said no decisions had been made.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: "We are making progress as we look for long-term strategic partners with local relevance ... and who share our values and vision with a dedicated focus on accelerating growth initiatives," she said. REUTERS

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: Former shareholders of Good Technology Corp, a mobile software maker, are suing JPMorgan Chase & Co <JPM.N> for breach of fiduciary duty, according to a lawsuit filed on Thursday.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: JPMorgan was "self-interested" and "conflicted" in its dealings with Good Technology, which led the start-up to sell itself to BlackBerry Ltd <BB.TO> <BBRY.O> in 2015 at a "fire-sale" price of $425 million, the shareholders said in the amended lawsuit filed in Delaware Chancery Court.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: Good Technology was being advised by JPMorgan at the same time as the investment bank was advising BlackBerry, according to the lawsuit. JPMorgan prioritized its relationship with BlackBerry over its dealings with Good Technology, the complaint said.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The lawsuit valued Good Technology at over $1 billion.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: Blackberry and JPMorgan were not immediately available to comment on the issue.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The New York Times first reported the amended lawsuit earlier on Thursday. The complaint is part of a suit Good Technology shareholders originally filed in October 2015.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The suit already named Good Technology directors and executives as defendants and accused them of conflicts of interest.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The case is Good Technology Corporation Stockholder Litigation, Court of Chancery, State of Delaware C.A. No. 11580-VCL REUTERS

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: NEW YORK - Verizon Communications Inc <VZ.N> said on Thursday that its chief financial officer, Francis Shammo, plans to retire at the end of the year and will step down from his role on Nov. 1.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: Verizon said its board of directors appointed Matthew D. Ellis, who is currently senior vice president and CFO-operations finance, to succeed Shammo.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: Shammo, 55, will be leaving after 27 years with the company.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: He joined Verizon's predecessor company, Bell Atlantic, in 1989 and became Verizon CFO in 2010.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: During his tenure, Verizon agreed to pay $130 billion to buy Vodafone Group's stake in Verizon Wireless. It also acquired AOL Inc, the owner of the Huffington Post and TechCrunch, last year and agreed to buy web pioneer Yahoo Inc <YHOO.O> for $4.8 billion in July.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: Ellis, 45, joined Verizon in 2013 after 15 years at Tyson Foods Inc <TSN.N> in various roles. REUTERS

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: TIANJIN, China - By 2020, Beijing says automakers must meet tough new green standards to cut epic pollution in China's cities. As domestic firms bet heavily on electric cars to meet that goal, foreign peers are set to stay in a different, petrol-driven gear.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: In the latest sign of caution from global automakers in China, Germany's Audi last week unveiled a new factory for high-efficiency transmissions in Tianjin, to be used in petrol-powered cars. While Chinese firms go electric in the world's biggest auto market, Audi is intent on petrol engines that can run farther, cleaner, in tandem with hybrid technology.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: As China's electrified vehicle production booms, some international industry officials warn in private that the ambitious electric goals of domestic firms could prove too costly, too risky, too far from what consumers actually want - and not a good fit with their operations elsewhere. Still, China doled out $4.5 billion last year alone in green car subsidies.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: "In 2020, most cars we will sell will be combustion engines, so to fulfill (fuel consumption targets) you have to improve the consumption of each and every car of the Audi model range," Audi China chief Joachim Wedler said at the opening of the new plant. Wedler didn't comment on Chinese peers' electric car plans.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Automakers globally have struggled to agree on what a greener future will hold for the industry. In China, Beijing and state-linked automakers have thrown their weight behind electric vehicles - despite the fact that the electricity they need may be generated from burning coal.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Under Beijing's 2020 requirements, on average cars must consume less than 5 liters of petrol per 100 kilometers - nearly 30 percent below current standard levels.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Beijing has rolled out a raft of incentives to push domestic automakers - foreign brands generally aren't eligible - to build more electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, spurring a quadrupling in sales of these so-called "new energy vehicles" (NEVs) in 2015. Even with that surge, just 1.4 percent of cars sold in the first seven months of 2016 were NEVs, as concerns linger over driving range and home charging.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: HYBRID COMPROMISE

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: A powertrain manager at a major foreign automaker's China joint venture said domestic companies' smaller scale made them nimbler. Many are also state-linked, therefore obliged to support government policy, the manager said, declining to be named as he was not authorized to speak to the media.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: For example, Geely - controlled by Li Shufu, a member of the government's political consultative body - wants 90 percent of all sales to be NEVs by 2020. Meanwhile, state-backed GAC Motor plans to be able to produce up to 400,000 green energy cars annually by the end of this year.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Foreign automakers, who must form joint ventures with local partners to produce cars in China, have to consider a different dynamic - how manufacturing strategies on the mainland correlate with their traditional businesses and customers elsewhere.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: The powertrain manager said his company, like Audi, is focusing on a more gradual strategy, developing more efficient engines as well as plug-in petrol-electric hybrids: an interim solution that will please a government intent on cutting harmful emissions.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Of course, foreign automakers aren't avoiding NEVs entirely.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: General Motors' China venture last year pledged to spend $4 billion on electrification, developing 10 new energy models by 2020.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: In Tianjin, Audi China chief Wedler said the German firm and partner China FAW Group plan to launch their first locally produced plug-in hybrid vehicle this year, with a new imported car based on the same principle on the way next year.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: But Wedler acknowledged that as China's massive auto market evolves, automakers alone won't determine future directions.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: "The whole picture is driven by legislation," Wedler said.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: ($1 = 6.6791 Chinese yuan renminbi) REUTERS

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: A Pennsylvania regulator on Thursday reinstated a record $11.4 million fine against the popular ride-sharing service Uber Technologies Inc for operating illegally in the state in 2014.

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: By a 4-1 vote, the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission rejected Uber's arguments that the penalty, six times larger than any it had imposed, was unnecessary and excessive.

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: Uber, in a statement, said it intends to appeal to a Pennsylvania state court, and overturn what it called an "absurd" fine imposed for "technical violations."

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: The PUC, which regulates taxi services and Uber rivals such as Lyft, had sanctioned Uber for having from February to August 2014 provided 122,998 rides in Pennsylvania without prior approval, and obstructing a state probe into its operations.

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: It imposed the fine on April 21, reducing it from the $49.9 million ordered by two administrative law judges.

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: The PUC agreed in June to reconsider the payout at Uber's request, over the objection of state officials who called the fine an "appropriate response" to Uber's "lawless conduct."

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: Uber offered new evidence that its service benefited Pennsylvanians, and that any fine should be capped at $1,000 per day, or roughly $200,000, and not based on the number of trips.

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: But the PUC said in its 77-page decision that Uber "failed to set forth any new and novel arguments that appear to have been overlooked or not addressed in our prior determination."

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: In its statement, Uber said the decision sends a "troubling message that Pennsylvania is unwelcoming to technology and innovation," and shows why the state needs "permanent, statewide ride-sharing legislation as soon as possible."

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: Based in San Francisco, Uber has drawn criticism from taxi companies losing market share, regulators concerned about driver and passenger safety, and riders upset over high prices.

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: The PUC previously found that Uber had in 2014 posed a risk to public safety by offering rides without proof its drivers, vehicles and insurance provisions met state standards.

Headline: Pennsylvania reinstates Uber's record $11.4 million fine
Text: It also said Uber's contention that it served only a limited customer base at the time "rang hollow," given its "persistent claim" that it provide its service to meet overwhelming demand, despite two cease-and-desist orders. REUTERS

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: BRUSSELS - Other multinationals that do not employ as extreme Irish tax schemes as Apple Inc but shift profits via the country to tax havens could also be breaching EU rules, Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said on Thursday.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She handed the iPhone maker a record 13-billion-euro bill for Irish registered units that Dublin authorities accepted were liable to tax in no country on Tuesday.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She told Reuters in an interview that other firms' arrangements, which involve routing profits to Irish-registered subsidiaries tax resident in places like Bermuda, might fall foul of the Commission on similar grounds.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: "Taxes have been paid nowhere due to the Irish tax code," she said.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Asked if the bill would have been different if the head office of Apple's Irish unit been registered and paid tax in Bermuda, Vestager said: "not much."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Vestager said the core of the case against Apple was that it had an Irish registered company that booked most of the profits generated across Europe.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: However, since Ireland didn't deem the subsidiary tax resident there, the unit was able to report just a small taxable income at an Irish "branch."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Apple's chief executive, Tim Cook, and Washington have denounced the Commission ruling as an unjust raid on tax that should be paid in the United States. Apple's chief financial officer, Luca Maestri, told reporters on Tuesday that the assertion that Apple doesn't pay taxes anywhere on much of its profits is "simply wrong."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: "These are profits that are taxed in the United States, and for anybody that understands the U.S. worldwide tax system, this is very easy to understand," Maestri said. "We actually accrue those tax liabilities on our balance sheet on an ongoing basis and we've done it consistently over the years."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Vestager said if Washington chose to tax the profits reported by Apple's Irish operation, she would reduce her demand accordingly.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: The United States could do this by forcing Apple to have its Irish units pay more in fees to Apple in California for the right to license Apple patents.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: "If the U.S. tax authority found that the monies paid due to the cost-sharing agreement were too few ... so that they should pay more in the cost-sharing agreement, that would transfer more money to the States and that may change the books and the accounts in the States," Vestager said.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Vestager said, however, that the bill would not be affected if Apple next year moved funds from its Irish units to the United States by paying dividends, even though in this case, the dividends would be taxed.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She declined to discuss which other companies' affairs were being looked at by her staff beyond two publicly announced and outstanding investigations into Amazon <AMZN.O> and McDonald's <MCD.N> in Luxembourg.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She said that since being alerted to Apple's methods and other cases by a U.S. Senate probe in 2013, the Commission has been looking through about 1,000 such instances in the EU.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She dismissed accusations from Apple's Cook and others that her decision was politically motivated or driven by anti-American populism. While U.S. companies have been investigated, she said, most of 35 firms probed over tax in Belgium were from Europe, and those still being looked at were a broad sample. REUTERS

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: DOHA/BERLIN - The United States is poised to sell $7 billion worth of Boeing Co fighter jets to Qatar and Kuwait after years of delays, and it may start notifying U.S. lawmakers as early as next week, four U.S.- and Gulf-based sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: The sales had stalled amid concerns raised by Israel, Washington's closest Middle East ally, that equipment sent to equipment sent to Gulf Arab states would be used against it.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: U.S. officials have criticized Qatar for alleged ties to armed Islamist groups.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: Boeing said it was encouraged by continued progress and hoped to see movement on the two big arms sales soon. The State Department said it could not comment on any ongoing government-to-government arms sales requests.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: A senior U.S. administration official said it was U.S. policy not to comment on proposed U.S. defense sales until they had been formally notified to Congress, but Washington remained committed to the security and stability of the Gulf region.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: "For decades, we have demonstrated this commitment through continual efforts to enhance our diplomatic relationships and build defense capacity across the region, particularly through promotion of security agreements, foreign military sales, exercises, training, and exchanges," the official said.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: Delays in the process have caused frustration among U.S. defense officials and industry executives, who have warned that Washington's foot-dragging could cost them billions of dollars of business if buyers grow impatient and seek other suppliers.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: The expected approval of the fighter jet sales comes as the White House seeks to shore up relations with Gulf Arab allies who want to increase their military capabilities. They fear Washington is drawing closer to Iran, their arch-rival, after its nuclear deal with world powers earlier this year.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: "It is imminent. We expect a decision next week," said an official from Qatar's defense ministry, who declined to be named as he was not authorized to speak publicly.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: An adviser to Qatar's military also said the deal was moving ahead.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: Neither commented on the cost or number of jets that would be delivered.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: The Pentagon and the State Department have been considering the sale of 36 Boeing F-15 fighter jets to Qatar valued at around $4 billion. They are also considering the sale of 28 F/A- 18E/F Super Hornets, plus options for 12 more, to Kuwait in a deal valued at around $3 billion.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: Sources said officials at both agencies had largely agreed to the deals some time ago, but had been awaiting final approval from the White House, which is now on board.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: "A decision by the administration is very close," said one of the sources, who was not authorized to speak publicly.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: Once the White House gives its formal approval, U.S. officials will start to informally notify U.S. lawmakers before sending a formal notification to Congress 40 days later, at which point the deals will be publicly announced.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: A third deal, the sale of F-16 fighters built by Lockheed Martin Corp to Bahrain, remains under consideration, but approval is not as far along, said one of the sources.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: Qatar - home to the largest U.S. air base in the Middle East - and Kuwait have ramped up military spending after uprisings across the Arab World and amid rising tensions between Gulf Arab states and Iran.

Headline: Exclusive: U.S. set to approve sales of Boeing fighters to Qatar, Kuwait - sources
Text: Both Qatar and Kuwait are part of a 34-nation alliance announced by Saudi Arabia in December aimed at countering Islamic State and al Qaeda in Iraq, Syria, Libya, Egypt and Afghanistan. REUTERS

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: SINGAPORE/HONG KONG/CHICAGO - U.S. financial regulators gave over-the-counter (OTC) swap dealers an extra month to comply with new derivatives trading rules set to take effect on Thursday, after Asia's market ground to a near halt due to uncertainty about changes that could increase global funding costs by more than $500 billion.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The rules directly affect U.S. and Japanese banks, which will be required to post and collect collateral or "margin" against OTC trades, a development set to dramatically raise the cost of trading in the $500 trillion global swaps market.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) said it will not pursue disciplinary action before Oct. 3 against swap dealers that do not meet new requirements because some were unable to make necessary arrangements in time for Thursday's deadline. The agency said the delay was appropriate when dealers were making "diligent, good faith implementation efforts."

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: CFTC staff have heard that small and foreign dealers in particular, need more time, Chairman Timothy Massad said in a statement. They believe that "this situation has improved in the last few days,‎ and that the largest dealers may no longer face significant issues," he said.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Two groups representing swap dealers, the International Swaps and Derivatives Association and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, had requested the delay.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Regulators in Europe, Singapore, Hong Kong and Australia also recently delayed the implementation of margin rules amid fears their banks were not ready, a move some experts said has created an uneven playing field. India said it was delaying its margin rules on Thursday.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Priya Misra, head of global rates strategy at TD Securities in New York, said the CFTC's delay "might help smooth out some of the market dislocations that could have happened" if U.S. regulators had stuck to their original deadline.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: "Every client I spoke with was concerned about the impact of these rules on liquidity and bid-ask in the affected markets, particularly swaptions or cross-currency basis swaps," Misra told Reuters.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Traders and market insiders earlier told Reuters that some major banks in Asia had halted dealing in a range of OTC derivatives products, including foreign exchange non-deliverable forwards (NDFs) and interest rate swaps. They were not yet able to comply with the rules, first proposed by global regulators following the 2007-09 financial crisis, traders said.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: "There is a lot of confusion," said one interest rates trader in Singapore. "The margining is an issue. The big banks are covered under that rule, and some of them don't yet have systems and the back-end documentation processes in place."

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: 'REGULATORY ARBITRAGE'

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Following the financial crisis, global regulators drew up rules to increase transparency and reduce risks in the OTC derivatives market, which was largely responsible for the collapse of Lehman Brothers and bringing insurance giant AIG to its knees.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: These included pushing some OTC trades onto exchange-like platforms and through clearing houses, which guarantee payment in the event either party defaults.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The margin rules aim to secure trades that are too complex or illiquid for exchanges and clearing houses to handle. The global cost of funding the margin rules is likely to ultimately exceed $500 billion, according to U.S and European regulators.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Large U.S. and Japanese banks have been scrambling to prepare for the first phase of the margin rules, which require changes to risk models, legal documents, and custody arrangements.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The new rules will not be enforced in Europe until mid-2017, after the European Commission announced earlier this year that it would delay implementation.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: In practice, European banks had been working toward the Sept. 1 U.S. and Japanese deadline, according to the International Swaps and Derivatives Association.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Still, banks from Europe, Singapore, Hong Kong and Australia have stopped trading OTC products with U.S. and Japanese banks, lest they are forced to post collateral to trade with them, said Kishore Ramakrishnan, a director at PricewaterhouseCoopers Consulting in Hong Kong.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: "This regulatory arbitrage won't change until we have a level regulatory playing field next summer," Ramakrishnan said. REUTERS

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: SEOUL — Samsung Electronics is expected to announce a global recall of the large-screen smartphone Note 7 because of faulty batteries that catch fire, Yonhap reported, citing an unidentified company official.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: The world’s largest smartphone maker will announce the results of an investigation and a plan to deal with the issue as soon as this weekend, according to the news agency.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: “We are conducting a thorough inspection with our partners. We will share the findings and corrective measures as soon as possible. Samsung is fully committed to providing the highest quality products to our consumers,” said a Samsung spokesperson in Singapore in response to TODAY’s queries, declining to comment further on the issue.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: Samsung had gambled that positive reviews for the new device, which features iris-reading technology, would lead to robust sales. Analysts, who were growing increasingly bullish over Samsung’s smartphone sales amid slowing demand for Apple’s iPhones, have been raising their price targets for the company after it reported second-quarter profits above projections in July.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: The Galaxy smartphone maker said on Wednesday (Aug 31) that it delayed shipments of its new devices to mobile carriers, citing more testing needed for quality checks without elaborating on the cause. A series of reports since last week said that the Note7 had caught fire while charging and some customers uploaded pictures of their burned-out devices on the internet.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: Shares of Samsung Electronics declined 2 per cent to 1,587,000 won (S$1,930) Thursday, while its battery affiliate, Samsung SDI, lost 6.1 per cent to 108,500 won. BLOOMBERG

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: WASHINGTON - Years of stubbornly low interest rates and expectations they will remain low for years to come have prompted U.S. banks to shift their balance sheets in ways that put them at risk if rates suddenly spike, regulators are warning.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Banks have been stocking up on long-term loans, often tied to real estate and property development that promise higher yields than the miniscule returns on short-term debt.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: However, the widening gap between long-term loans and mostly short-term funding means higher interest rates could trap banks in a corner: forcing them to pay more to cover their immediate financing needs than they earn on their loans.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The dynamic "raises the interest rate risk issue that we are very focused on," Martin Gruenberg, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation(FDIC), said this week.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Banks are broadly positioned according to the signals the Federal Reserve has been sending — that it will lift rates only gradually and spread the increases over a long period.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Regulators point out, though, that central banks can move quickly too, even if that now appears unlikely. Short-term rates could also climb in a weakening economy, they say.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "(There) could be impacts on the economy apart from monetary policy," Gruenberg said.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The Office of Financial Research, an independent watchdog within the Treasury Department, says banks could be tested by a surprise upheaval like the recent Brexit vote.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "Investors (are) open to heavy losses from large jumps in interest rates, whether from surprises in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy or other shocks," the OFR wrote in a recent report.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency also counts interest rate risk among market perils.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: This week, Boston Fed president Eric Rosengren warned that banks might already be too exposed to long-term, commercial real estate that could sour and hit the broader economy.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The savings and loan crisis of the 1980s and the early 1990s was the most prominent U.S. example how a spike in short-term rates could wreak havoc in the financial industry.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: When the Fed pushed its benchmark rate above 19 percent in the early 1980s, many lenders switched to riskier credits to keep up with a spike in costs. Those loans later soured and contributed to the collapse of hundreds of lenders.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Most recently, banks got a glimpse of the risks of rate swings in June 2013 when then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke suggested that the central bank could start scaling back its government debt purchases. As bond yields whipsawed in response, banks saw their long term assets briefly lose billions of dollars in value.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Even so, banks have been extending the duration of their loans since the Fed pegged its rates near zero in late 2008, assuming that rates will stay low for some time.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: FDIC data shows roughly a quarter of the loans on bank balance sheets will not mature for at least five years – a record level - and many lenders remain comfortable offering long-term loans to bolster earnings. (Graphic: http://tmsnrt.rs/2bnEjZA)

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "We are relatively convinced that we may not be this low forever, but...our expectation is lower for longer," Wells Fargo's finance chief, John Shrewsberry, said last month.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Regulators do not require banks to set aside capital for potential losses if interest rates rise and let them use their own models to calcuate risks, so approaches vary across the industry.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: While JPMorgan Chase & Co <JPM.N>, the nation's largest lender, has lately increased its protection against rising rates, Bank of America Corp <BAC.N>, the nation's No. 2 lender, has been steadily paring it back.(Graphic: http://tmsnrt.rs/2bVLmXk)

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: CRYING WOLF?

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Analysts say it is difficult to tell whether regulators see risks that banks do not or whether they are just doing their job - worrying about a threat that may never materialize.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Government-backed lenders, though, have also been nudging banks to better prepare for eventual rate hikes.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "We've had eight years of low rates. And the bank model - relying on core deposits - has not been tested," said Robert Dozier of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Atlanta.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Analysts point to Bank of America as a lender bearing the brunt of low rates.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: But as the bank has delved deeper into long-term assets, the lender has shrunk its book of certain interest rate derivatives to below $400 billion from $1 trillion in the last three years, according to FDIC data. Bank of America says that any hit it takes on a rate spike would quickly be offset by new loans made at higher rates.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Lazard Ltd <LAZ.N>, the investment bank that advised SolarCity Corp <SCTY.O> on its $2.6 billion sale to Tesla Motors Inc <TSLA.O>, made an error in its analysis that discounted the value of the U.S. solar energy company by $400 million, a regulatory filing by Tesla showed on Wednesday.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: While the purchase price was within the valuation range that Lazard came up with for SolarCity even after accounting for the miscalculation, the error illustrates how even leading investment banks can make mistakes on some of the highest-profile deals.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: The mistake came after Tesla and SolarCity co-founder Elon Musk, who is the largest shareholder in both companies, went out of his way to create processes and structures, including a special board committee at SolarCity, aimed at alleviating concerns that he used his influence to force the two companies into a deal.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: An analysis by Lazard for SolarCity that indicated an equity value of between $14.75 and $34.00 per share was wrong because it double-counted some of the company's projected indebtedness, according to Tesla's filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: This was the result of a computational error "in certain SolarCity spreadsheets setting forth SolarCity’s financial information that Lazard used in its discounted cash flow valuation analyses," according to the filing.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: The error was not included in the valuation analysis performed by Tesla and its financial adviser, Evercore Partners Inc <EVR.N>, the filing said.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: After becoming aware of the mistake on Aug. 18, more than two weeks after the signing of the deal, Lazard realized the accurate valuation range was $18.75 to $37.75 per share.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: SolarCity and Tesla agreed however that the error would not change their view of the deal, according to the filing. The purchase price, to be paid with Tesla stock, equated to $25.37 per share.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Lazard, SolarCity and Tesla declined to comment.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Lazard ranks No. 10 in the Thomson Reuters Americas M&A league table so far this year, down two spots on where it was last year.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: This is not the first time a major investment bank has made a miscalculation on a big deal. An erroneous share count in the leveraged buyout of Tibco Software in 2014 by its financial adviser, Goldman Sachs Group Inc <GS.N>, led to a Tibco shareholder lawsuit that was settled earlier this year.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Goldman discovered it had overstated the number of Tibco's fully diluted shares only after the company agreed to sell itself to private equity firm Vista Equity.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: This had the effect of lowering the sale price to $4.14 billion from the $4.24 billion used in Goldman's fairness opinion. Nevertheless, Tibco decided not to ask Vista to pay the additional $100 million.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Goldman and Vista agreed to pay $30 million to the Tibco shareholders as part of the settlement, the Wall Street Journal reported at the time. REUTERS

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: NEW YORK - A team of former Wall Street oil traders have won a partial victory in their continuing legal dispute with oil major BP PLC over how to properly run a remote eastern Canadian refinery, according to court documents filed Thursday.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: The legal fight, first reported by Reuters in March, stems from allegations leveled by BP that equity-backed NARL Refining violated its crude and product supply agreement when the refiner failed to maximize yields at the 115,000 barrel-per-day refinery in Come by Chance, Newfoundland.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: Among other things, BP alleged that NARL ran the refinery at high rates when it was not economical, in order to exploit a unique clause in their contract that allowed NARL to earn a higher profit on oil refined in excess of 90,000 barrels.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: The arbitration panel ruled late in August that NARL had no contractual obligation to run the refinery to the mutual benefit of both parties and tossed out that part of BP’s allegations.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: “There are no words of any kind requiring to maximize refinery margins for the benefit of BP,” the ruling says of the refiner, which is operated by SilverPeak Financial Partners, formed by a group of Wall Street veterans.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: However, the panel agreed to move forward with BP’s other allegation that NARL failed to provide required information, such as economic models, and to discuss possible crude slates, court documents show. Without that information, BP could not evaluate whether the refinery was running optimally.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: Geoff Morrell, a senior vice president of U.S. communications and external affairs at BP, said the arbitration process has a long way to go and the company is confident that it will prevail on the remaining issues.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: NARL declined comment.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: Arbitration proceedings are typically private affairs, but the ruling was temporarily posted Thursday on a New York federal court website, before it was taken down at the request of BP. The judge overseeing the case has postponed any decisions on a related case brought by NARL until the arbitration proceedings have concluded.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: At issue is a routine "tolling" arrangement for independent refineries that lack the trading operations and credit lines necessary to operate in the global market. BP supplied the crude to the refinery and took back roughly 82 percent of the refined fuels, such as gasoline, diesel and jet fuel, paying NARL a fixed “toll” of $9.45 per barrel on the first 90,000 barrels of oil put through each day. NARL could earn more than the toll revenue on barrels produced in excess of that figure.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: The oil company alleges NARL ran the refinery at more than 90,000 bpd to capitalize on the incentive - a charge the arbitrators rejected.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: In a counterclaim, NARL alleges that BP made only lesser grades of crude available, resulting in "significant and long-term damage" to refinery equipment, including a vacuum tower that had to be shut down abruptly.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: The refinery owners have formed their own crude supply desk ahead of the expiration, sources have told Reuters.

Headline: Ex-oil traders win partial victory over BP in Canada dispute
Text: The small commercial desk will rely largely on the spot crude market, but will also ink term deals, the two sources said. REUTERS

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: The United Auto Workers (UAW) urged Volkswagen <VOWG_p.DE> to accept the National Labor Relations Board's (NLRB) latest order that requires the carmaker to collectively bargain with UAW local union as the representative of a portion of workers at its Tennessee plant.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: The NLRB on Aug. 26 ordered Volkswagen Group of America Inc among other things to recognize and bargain with UAW, Local 42, as the exclusive collective-bargaining representative of the employees in the bargaining unit. (http://bit.ly/2bTYSf7)

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: "This unanimous decision makes it clear that the company has been operating in violation of federal law by refusing to come to the bargaining table," said Gary Casteel, UAW secretary-treasurer, in a statement.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: "We urge Volkswagen to accept the NLRB order and bargain with the local union at the earliest possible date."

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Volkswagen has filed an appeal against the National Labor Relations Board's order in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, the company said in an email to Reuters.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Volkswagen has said earlier that it will go to a U.S. federal appeals court in an effort to keep the UAW union from representing a portion of the company's plant workers in Chattanooga.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Late last year, a majority of the maintenance, or skilled trades, workers at VW's plant in Chattanooga, Tennessee, voted to be represented by the UAW.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: The vote marked a rare victory for the union in the U.S. South, where it has fought many unsuccessful battles to organize non-unionized auto plants.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Volkswagen was at one time welcoming to the UAW at Chattanooga. But that was before the union lost a closely contested election open to all of the plant's 1,500 workers in February 2014. REUTERS

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "We constantly evaluate the trade-offs between earnings, interest rate risk, capital and liquidity," said spokesman Jerome Dubrowski.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Bank of America could save about $20 billion over the next two years now that it has dropped some of those hedges, according to Rob Pratt of Harbor Derivatives who brokers some of those same swaps.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: But the lender may wish that it had held onto those hedges if interest rates do climb quickly, said David Hendler, a bank analyst with Viola Risk Advisors of New York.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The bank can buy more of those swaps later but they might be more costly.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "That's the thing about insurance: you'll pay more when you need it most," said Hendler. REUTERS

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: SINGAPORE — The increase in hotel room supply coupled with a weak corporate demand outlook will continue to present operating challenges to the hospitality industry in Singapore for the rest of the year, said analysts at OCBC Investment Research, which is keeping a “Neutral” rating on the sector.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “Given the weak RevPAR (revenue per available room) performance across the board … we remain pessimistic about the operating performance of hospitality assets for the second half of this year,” analysts Deborah Ong and Andy Wong wrote in a research report.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “There are two key reasons for this underperformance: First, the overhang of supply from 2015, and second, weak macroeconomic conditions, especially in the commodities and finance sector, which has taken a hit on corporate demand.”

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: Hospitality real estate investment trusts under the research firm’s coverage — Ascott Residence Trust, CDL Hospitality Trusts, Far East Hospitality Trust and OUE Hospitality Trust (OUEHT) — are currently trading at yields of about 7 per cent. Second-quarter distribution per unit growth ranged from 1.9 per cent to minus 39.5 per cent on a year-on-year unadjusted basis, and from minus 0.9 per cent to 19.1 per cent, after adjusting for one-off items and equity financing.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: RevPAR contracted between 2.1 per cent (to S$83 for Global Premium Hotels) and 9.2 per cent (to S$157 for CDL Hospitality Trust’s Singapore assets) in the second quarter from the corresponding period last year, with OUEHT’s Crowne Plaza posting the least negative performance.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “While OUEHT’s results were among the most resilient in the first quarter of 2016, its five-star Mandarin Orchard posted an 8.3 per cent drop in RevPAR this quarter. Other REITs continue to cite poor corporate demand, which contributed to low to mid single-digit drops in their average room rates (ARR) and average occupancy rates (AOR),” said the analysts.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: Total hotel room stock surged 6.5 per cent to 60,908 last year, far outpacing the 0.9 per cent increase in tourist arrivals, they noted, saying they believed this contributed to last year’s decline in AOR, ARR, and RevPAR, which fell by 0.5 per cent, 4.8 per cent and 5.3 per cent, respectively.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “Going forward, we believe the room supply injection will not be adequately matched by a growth in demand. The room supply is expected to increase another 4.7 per cent to 63,800 rooms this year. Even though visitor days has shown a healthy start (up 4.5 per cent from January to June this year), the outlook for corporate demand remains weak, especially for corporates in the oil & gas and financial sectors. As such, we expect this supply overhang to worsen this year, contributing to downward pressures on RevPAR,” the analysts warned.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: Amid economic uncertainty and regional competition, the Singapore Tourism Board is aiming to increase tourism receipts by 2 per cent this year to S$22.4 billion, and arrivals by 3 per cent to 15.7 million visitors.
