Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: However, its efforts are now being complicated by the Zika outbreak in Singapore: Australia, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Kingdom and United States have issued advisories against visiting Singapore, saying that pregnant women or those trying to get pregnant should avoid the city-state.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: NEW YORK - U.S. stocks were flat on Thursday, with gains in the tech sector offseting sluggish factory activity data and lower oil prices, as investors exercised caution ahead of a key payrolls report on Friday.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: A report from the Institute of Supply Management showed U.S. factory activity contracted for the first time in six months in August as new orders and production tumbled, but data on the labor market pointed to a pickup in third-quarter economic growth.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: "The ISM data was, in a word, disappointing, because many investors and market participants were expecting to see a more robust number, something more in line with recent trend," said Peter Kenny, senior market strategist at Global Markets Advisory Group, in New York.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: "It has forced investors to reconsider the landscape, not go blindly into the narrative that spells out a certainty about interest rates being bumped up in September."

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: Energy shares <.SPNY>, down 0.3 percent, also weighed as oil prices declined on worries about a supply glut. U.S. crude <CLc1> settled off 3.5 percent at $43.16 a barrel while Brent <LCOc1> settled 3.1 percent lower at $45.45.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: But gains in tech companies such as Hewlett Packard Enterprise <HPE.N>, up 3.2 percent, and Apple <AAPL.O>, up 0.6 percent, helped keep losses in check. A 4.5-percent gain in Charter Communications <CHTR.O> also helped lift the Nasdaq after S&P Dow Jones Indices said the cable services company would replace EMC Corp <EMC.N> in the S&P 500 after the close of trading on Sept. 7.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: The economic data comes ahead of Friday's monthly nonfarm payrolls data, which could influence the Fed's decision on the timing of the next interest rate hike.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: Solid performance in the labor market has spurred hawkish comments from some Fed officials in recent weeks. On Thursday, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said the U.S. labor market is at full strength and the Federal Reserve needs to be on a path of gradual interest rate increases.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: Traders have priced in a 27-percent chance of a hike in September, up slightly from the 24 percent probability in the prior session. The odds for a hike in December stand at 54.4 percent, edging up from 53.6 percent on Wednesday, according to the CME Group's FedWatch tool.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: The Dow Jones industrial average <.DJI> rose 18.42 points, or 0.1 percent, to 18,419.3, the S&P 500 <.SPX> lost 0.09 points to 2,170.86, and the Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> added 13.99 points, or 0.27 percent, to 5,227.21.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones on the NYSE by a 1.10-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 1.14-to-1 ratio favored advancers.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: The S&P 500 posted 15 new 52-week highs and 2 new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 113 new highs and 28 new lows.

Headline: Wall Street flat as tech offsets manufacturing data
Text: About 6.36 billion shares changed hands in U.S. exchanges, compared with the 5.98 billion daily average over the last 20 sessions. REUTERS

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: BERLIN - Germany's Transport Ministry has asked the European Commission to investigate exhaust emissions of Fiat Chrysler <FCHA.MI> vehicles for potential illegal manipulation devices, German government documents showed on Thursday.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: Germany's motor vehicle authority KBA began testing the vehicles of several manufacturers, including Fiat, after Volkswagen's <VOWG_p.DE> admission in September last year that it had cheated emissions tests with motor-management software.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: The direct approach to the European Union executive comes after the German transport ministry raised concerns over Fiat vehicles with Italian authorities earlier this year and a subsequent rejection by Italian authorities of claims that Fiat and Chrysler vehicles used illegal exhaust manipulation devices.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: This week's letter to the European Commission, which was seen by Reuters, said that tests by German authorities on the Fiat 500X, Fiat Doblo and Jeep Renegade could prove the "illegal use of a device to switch off exhaust treatment systems" and urged the Commission to consult with Italian authorities to resolve the issue.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: A Fiat spokeswoman said on Thursday that the company's cars conform to current emissions rules and do not contain defeat devices.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: The Commission, meanwhile, said that it is the responsibility of the Italian authorities to remedy wrongdoings.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: "It is first and foremost a dialogue between the two member states concerned, with an obligation to keep the Commission informed and the possibility for the Commission to facilitate a solution if no agreement can be found," the Commission said in a statement.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: A source at the Italian infrastructure ministry, which includes the national motor vehicle authority, said Italy had not received any communication from the German government on the matter.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: The source said Italian tests had shown Fiat 500 cars conformed to emissions rules and did not contain defeat devices, adding that the KBA had never said it disagreed with Italy's findings.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: As part of a widening clampdown on health-threatening nitrogen oxide (NOx) pollution levels in the wake of the VW scandal, the KBA tested 53 different vehicles and found that carmakers were making liberal use of what they described as a “thermal window”.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: This refers to the time when carmakers are allowed to throttle back exhaust emissions management systems to protect engines from potential damage from condensation when cars are started in very cold conditions.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: During their investigations, the KBA found that a very wide range of temperatures was used by carmakers for thermal windows. REUTERS

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: DETROIT - U.S. auto sales fell 4.2 percent in August as some major automakers said a long-expected decline due to softer consumer demand had begun, possibly sparking a shift to juicer customer incentives and slower production.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: The top three sellers, General Motors Co <GM.N>, Ford Motor Co <F.N> and Toyota Motor Corp <7203.T><TM.N> on Thursday reported declines of at least 5 percent.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Of the seven top manufacturers by sales, only Fiat Chrysler Automobiles <FCAU.N><FCHA.MI> reported a gain versus a year ago, when sales were restated to about 11,000 fewer than originally reported.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Monthly spending on new cars and trucks is closely watched as the U.S. auto industry accounts for about one-fifth of U.S. retail sales.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: August sales, said Autodata Corp, totaled 1.51 million vehicles, or 16.98 million vehicles at a seasonally adjusted annualized rate, versus a surprisingly strong 17.88 million vehicles in July.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Ford Chief Economist Bryan Bezold said sales had hit a plateau after steadily rising following the 2008-2009 recession. The auto industry outperformed the overall U.S. economy in those years largely due to pent-up demand that has now played out, he said.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Wall Street has pressured automaker shares all year amid expectations of falling sales at some point.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: GM shares dipped 0.4 percent while Ford was off 1.4 percent in afternoon trading. Fiat Chrysler dropped 1.2 percent in New York trading.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: In late July, Ford was the first major automaker to confirm the lofty sales gains achieved since 2010 were at an end, even though they are still about 65 percent higher than the lowest sales year in 2009.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Mark LaNeve, Ford's U.S. sales chief, said on Thursday the company will ring up fewer sales in 2017 than this year. Results in 2016 are expected to fall short of last year's record high sales of 17.47 million vehicles, according to Autodata.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: GM on Thursday forecast 2016 sales at 17.3 million vehicles.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Ford, whose sales tumbled 8.4 percent, said its U.S. inventory was at 81 days of supply versus 61 days a year earlier, suggesting Ford may have to cut production, increase profit-eroding incentives, or boost fleet sales.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: "Now the automakers' focus will shift from simple growth to market share and managing inventories," said analyst Karl Brauer of Kelley Blue Book. "The use of incentives and fleet sales as a counter to plateauing retail sales will be the statistics to watch going forward.”

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Ford's LaNeve said the company will manage supply with demand, but when asked if production will be slowed or plants shut down to accomplish that goal, he declined to say.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: The trend toward SUVs and trucks and away from sedans and hatchbacks continued in August. Autodata figures show passenger car sales fell 12.6 percent while SUV and truck sales rose 2.4 percent.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: While GM said this year's sales will not top results of 2015, the slide was moderate, and results remained sharply above those in the 2008-2009 recession and in the years immediately after.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: “All the economic factors continue to point toward a strong second half of the year and another potential record year for the industry,” said Mustafa Mohatarem, GM’s chief economist.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Sales of the No. 1 selling model in the United States, the Ford F-Series pickup truck, fell 6 percent, but Ford said retail sales for the trucks were robust.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Retail sales cover individuals and are generally more lucrative than volume fleet sales to rental car agencies, businesses and government. Rental car sales are particularly low-profit.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: GM has boasted all year that it has significantly cut its sales to rental agencies. However, GM's retail sales fell about 5 percent, in line with its wider total sales decline.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Fiat Chrysler said in July it has revised more than five years of monthly U.S. vehicle sales figures amid a U.S. investigation into claims of inflated figures.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Nissan Motor Co <7201.T> sales were off 6.5 percent, but its Rogue midsize SUV saw a rise of 19 percent.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Honda Motor Co <7267.T> was down 3.8 percent as Accord sales tumbled 26 percent. Honda-brand car sales fell 10 percent overall while truck and SUV sales rose 4.5 percent. REUTERS

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: SINGAPORE — Seven months into his new role as CEO of International Enterprise (IE) Singapore, Lee Ark Boon is streamlining efforts at the trade development agency to prioritise high-growth companies over those with low growth, a move he says will boost the Republic’s economy in the medium term.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: “We are going to focus more attention downstream on what is the economic value captured back to Singapore. Traditionally, we have always helped everyone who comes to IE, but with a growing demand, with limited resources, we need to prioritise and sharpen our focus,” said Mr Lee in an update on the agency’s streamlining efforts yesterday.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: “We need companies that are growing. The national average is about 6 per cent growth for companies, what we are hoping is for the companies that we work with to punch above 6 per cent.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: “We want to work more with companies that are growing at close to double-digit or above double-digit rates … We need to accord higher priority to the companies that can bring back the most value to the Singapore economy and bring back the most value in creating skilled jobs.”

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: The high-growth sectors include financial services, infrastructure, legal, accounting, logistics, and advanced manufacturing, he said, adding that the new focus will likely lead to a significant positive impact on Singapore’s gross domestic product in about 10 years.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: Currently, IE Singapore is working with more than 1,000 companies with high-growth performance.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: More companies have come to IE Singapore for help, with the agency providing 34,000 instances of assistance last year, up from 28,000 in 2014.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: However, some economists cautioned against too narrow an approach that could lead to some unpolished gems — such as those in the low growth retail and food & beverage sectors — being bypassed.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: UOB economist Francis Tan said: “We have to be careful, as even some companies from low- growth sectors have the potential to become high-growth companies. All industries do have potential, and a lot may fall through the cracks. Take BreadTalk, for example. They are a bakery from a low-growth industry and could have fallen through the cracks in today’s assessment.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: “It will be hard to determine which company has potential and which doesn’t. If the agency gives support to a company from a high-growth industry … and the company is not performing well, it will also be wasted resources.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: “Also, some companies are low-growth and if there is no help given to them, how can they become high-growth?

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: “They would logically want to place their bet on the fastest racing horse. But if someone has no track record, IE would have to assess them and operationally everything would seem to be back to what it used to do be.”

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: As it fosters tighter relationships with high-growth companies, IE Singapore will also streamline its internal operations, so that one manager can work on both strategy planning and grants assistance, compared with two previously.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: There will be continued assistance for low-growth companies through partnerships with the trade associations and chambers (TACs) as well as continued support through schemes such as the Market Readiness Assistance, Local Enterprise and Association Development and the International Marketing Activities programmes.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: The trade development agency is exploring working with TACs to set up overseas centres to provide the support.

Headline: IE to focus on firms with high-growth potential
Text: For companies that have already gone overseas, IE Singapore will continue to provide assistance regardless of their growth potential.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: RIO DE JANEIRO - Federal prosecutors in Brazil rejected a $328.2 million (247.34 million pounds) deal on Thursday allowing Dutch oil-ship lesser SBM Offshore NV <SBMO.AS> to avoid prosecution for corruption related to its contracts with state-led oil company Petrobras.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The decision was made by a federal prosecutor review board, which said numerous problems needed to be addressed before the deal could be approved.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: SBM officials did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The deal failed to provide authorities with enough data, documents and other information to assist in further investigations of corruption at Petrobras, the board said.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: A series of widening investigations that began in 2014 have shown that Petrobras <PETR4.SA> officials conspired with major contractors to fix prices or arrange bribes, in a sweeping kickback scheme that has engulfed a vast swath of Brazil's political class and business elites.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: SBM, was one of the first companies to get caught up in the scandal.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: SBM is the largest lesser of floating oil production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessels. The company has been accused of paying bribes to officials of Petroleo Brasileiro SA <PETR4.SA>, or Petrobras to win FPSO lease contracts.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: Petrobras operates the largest fleet of FPSOs in the world. Without the deal, Petrobras might be forced to cancel contracts with SBM that could cut output by 15 percent between 2016 and 2020 and cost Petrobras $12.7 billion in revenue, Brazil's transparency, regulation and control ministry (TRCM), said in a statement on Thursday.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The deal rejected on Thursday, known as a lenience accord, was completed in negotiations between SBM and the TRCM in July. It offered SBM immunity from prosecution in exchange for an admission of guilt, the provision of information and evidence that could help further an ongoing corruption investigation at Petrobras.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: It also included a $163 million fine, of which Petrobras will receive $149.2 million. Petrobras would be further compensated by SBM reducing the value of its contracts by $179 million. Another $13.6 million would be paid to prosecutors to help finance additional corruption investigations.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The review panel said prosecutors were giving up too much in exchange for the fines to be paid by SBM. It also said the company had been more forthcoming with prosecutors in the United States and Europe about crimes in Brazil than it had with authorities in the South American country.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The board sent the deal back to prosecutors in Rio de Janeiro, where Petrobras is based. REUTERS

Text: The board sent the deal back to prosecutors in Rio de Janeiro, where Petrobras is based. REUTERS

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Duke Energy Corp's <DUK.N> board must face a shareholder lawsuit over its abrupt 2012 firing of its newly installed chief executive, a Delaware judge has ruled.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: In a decision on Wednesday, Delaware Vice Chancellor Sam Glasscock denied Duke's bid to end the case, finding the shareholder plaintiffs plausibly argued that the defendants might have concealed information about their actions from the public and regulators.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: As part of its $18 billion deal to acquire Progress Energy, Duke had agreed to install Progress head William Johnson as CEO of the combined company. But within hours of the acquisition's closing in July 2012, the new Duke board met and fired Johnson, reinstating former Duke CEO James Rogers, in a vote along company lines.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Johnson left with a pre-negotiated $44 million severance package. Shareholders almost immediately sued Duke, arguing the decision to terminate him was reached in May 2012 and concealed from the public, investors and regulators. Duke's share price subsequently fell and the S&P lowered the company's credit rating.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Duke and the executives and directors named in the lawsuit strongly deny the lawsuit's allegations and any wrongdoing related to the CEO change after the 2012 merger, Duke said in a statement on Thursday.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Duke said the company, executives and directors would continue to vigorously defend themselves in the litigation.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: In his decision, Glasscock said the plaintiffs plausibly alleged the holdover Duke board members had second thoughts about Johnson in the 18 months between the deal's announcement and its closing. According to the lawsuit, the board decided to conceal its plan to oust Johnson because it did not want to risk trying to renegotiate the merger terms or face further questions from state regulators that could delay its approval.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: They chose instead to wait until a meeting after the acquisition closed to say Johnson was not a good fit to lead the combined company, the lawsuit alleged.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: The abrupt CEO change brought other federal and state claims in North Carolina and an investigation by the state utilities regulator in North Carolina, where Duke and Progress were headquartered.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: A settlement with regulators formalized Rogers' exit in 2013. Duke in 2015 settled a securities class action related to the merger in North Carolina federal court for $146 million. Duke and the named executives and directors denied the class allegations of misrepresentations related to the CEO change. REUTERS

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co (HPE) <HPE.N> is in talks with buyout firm Thoma Bravo LLC to sell its software division, hoping it can fetch between $8 billion and $10 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: The negotiations come as HPE Chief Executive Meg Whitman seeks to focus the U.S. company's strategy on networking, storage, data centers and related technology services, after its separation last year from computer and printer maker HP Inc <HPQ.N>.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: HPE has received offers for the software unit of as much as $7.5 billion in a sale process managed by investment bank Goldman Sachs Group Inc <GS.N>, the sources said this week.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: Thoma Bravo has made the highest offer for the assets among the private equity firms that held discussions with HPE, though significant discrepancies in valuation expectations persist and no deal is certain, the people said.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: Other private equity firms that made offers for the software assets include Vista Equity Partners Management LLC, Carlyle Group LP <CG.O> and TPG Capital LP, the people said. It was still possible that HPE would turn to a buyout firm other than Thoma Bravo to pursue a deal, or that Thoma Bravo would buy only some of the assets, the people said.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: A sale of HPE's entire software division to a single private equity firm would be easier if the latter already owns some related companies, the people said. Thoma Bravo owns several software companies, including Dynatrace LLC and Compuware Corp, which could produce cost savings and efficiencies if combined with some of HPE's software assets, the people added.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: The sources asked not to be identified because the negotiations are confidential. HPE, Goldman Sachs, Thoma Bravo, Vista Equity, Carlyle and TPG declined to comment.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: HPE shares rose as much as 4 percent on the news and ended Thursday's New York trading up 3.2 percent at $22.16, giving the company a market capitalization of $36.8 billion.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: HPE's software unit generated $3.6 billion in net revenue in 2015, down from $3.9 billion in 2014. The company has said revenue growth in its software unit has been challenged by a market shift toward cloud subscription offerings.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: HPE acquired part of its software portfolio as a result of its ill-fated $10.3 billion acquisition of Autonomy Corp in 2011 and the $4.5 billion acquisition of Mercury Interactive in 2006.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: The software assets also include Vertica, a big data analytics platform, ArcSight, a cyber security firm as well as products for IT operations management.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: HPE is the latest technology company looking to slim down a large portfolio of noncore software assets that are struggling to generate growth. In June, Dell Inc [DI.UL] agreed to sell its software division to buyout firm Francisco Partners and the private equity arm of activist hedge fund Elliott Management Corp for more than $2 billion.

Headline: Exclusive: HP Enterprise in talks to sell software unit to Thoma Bravo - sources
Text: In May, HPE agreed to merge its IT services and outsourcing unit with Computer Sciences Corp <CSC.N> to create a $9 billion company in a tax-free all-stock transaction known as a Reverse Morris Trust. REUTERS

Headline: Harley-Davidson says plans to cut about 200 jobs
Text: Harley-Davidson Inc <HOG.N> plans to cut about 200 positions as the company adjusts production plans to align with its 2016 motorcycle shipment guidance, a company spokeswoman said on Thursday.

Headline: Harley-Davidson says plans to cut about 200 jobs
Text: In July, the motorcycle manufacturer lowered its 2016 full-year shipment guidance to a range of 264,000 to 269,000 motorcycles. The company had previously estimated it would ship 269,000 to 274,000 motorcycles. REUTERS

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: SINGAPORE — Businesses and other entities such as non-profit organisations and associations will be able to use a single corporate digital identity instead of multiple login IDs to perform e-Government transactions when the Singapore Corporate Access (CorpPass) is launched on September 15.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: To be rolled out in phases till the end of 2017, the CorpPass portal will progressively replace SingPass, Easy (E-Services Authorisation System) and agency-issued login IDs for local entities with a Unique Entity Number (UEN) and foreign entities who wish to access Government-to-business e-services in Singapore.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: More than 200 government digital services managed by about 60 government agencies will require CorpPass as a login method by December 2017. The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore, Ministry of Trade and Industry, National Environment Agency and Singapore Customs will be in the first phase.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: Individuals (e.g. taxi drivers, hawkers) and local entities (e.g. trust funds, joint ventures) without an UEN will be able to continue to use their SingPass to transact with the Government.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: CorpPass was set up in response to feedback from employees that SingPass should be used for personal transactions, and not corporate transactions. Concerns were raised over the sharing of SingPass ID accounts of individuals for performing business transactions like filing corporate tax.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: With CorpPass, employers will be able appoint administrators to oversee the services without sharing their personal SingPass accounts. Access can also be set by the employer on specific digital services per user.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: Mr Chan Cheow Hoe, assistant chief executive, Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore, said: “CorpPass marks the first time that the Government is rolling out a single corporate digital identity.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: “This creates opportunities for even more services and transactions to be provided online conveniently and securely. More than 1,500 business users have successfully registered and activated their CorpPass accounts since our trial started in April this year. We encourage businesses to sign up early for CorpPass as this will be a required login method for most Government digital services by end of next year.” Angela Teng

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: NEW YORK - Oil prices fell more than 3 percent on Thursday, heading for their sharpest weekly slide since January as investors brushed aside talk that OPEC might freeze production and focused on a growing glut from U.S. crude stockpiles.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Energy monitoring service Genscape's report of a 714,282-barrel drawdown at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery point for U.S. crude futures during the week ended on Aug. 30 did little to bolster sentiment, traders who saw the report said.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Investors focused instead on Wednesday's government data showing a 2.3 million-barrel build in U.S. crude stocks in the last week, more than double what the market had expected. Inventories of distillates, which include diesel and heating oil, rose nearly 10 times as much as forecast, the data from the U.S. Energy Information Administration showed. [EIA/S]

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Brent crude futures ended the session at $45.45 per barrel, down $1.44 or 3.07 percent.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: U.S. crude's West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures closed down $1.54 or 3.45 percent at $43.16 a barrel.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Both Brent and WTI were down about 9 percent week-to-date for their biggest decline since mid-January.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Technical pressure has also increased on oil, with WTI edging toward a test of its Aug. 11 low of $41.10. That low had been a crucial support for U.S. crude futures, which rallied to above $48 less than a week later.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: "Basically it's a retest of that breakout," Andreas Wunder at Alphatrade Asset Management in Austin, Texas, said, noting the move lower appeared as forceful as the one higher.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: A Reuters poll of 34 analysts and economists forecast Brent would average $45.44 a barrel in 2016, slightly lower than last month's forecast of $45.51. [O/POLL]

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: It was the first downward revision in prices on the poll in six months, and came amid reduced prospects for output curbs by the world's largest oil producers.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Oil prices rose as much 11 percent in August, posting their biggest monthly rise since April, on speculation the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and other producers might agree to freezing production during Sept. 26-28 talks in Algeria.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: That speculation has since fizzled, although Saudi Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said on Thursday that OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers were moving toward a common position on output.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: "Talk is cheap," Harry Tchilinguirian, global head of commodity markets strategy at BNP Paribas, told the Reuters Global Oil Forum. "Reality will set in, and the market will realize that the agendas of various OPEC producers are not aligned." REUTERS

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: LEXINGTON, Ky. - The U.S. labor market is at full strength and the Federal Reserve needs to be on a path of gradual interest rate increases, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said on Thursday.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "It seems like a gradual increase from a very low interest rate that we are at now is pretty compelling to me," Mester told reporters in Lexington, Kentucky, without saying whether she would support an increase at the Fed's policy meeting later this month.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Her comments reinforced the signals sent from some policymakers of a growing readiness to raise interest rates if data shows the economy is gathering strength.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last week she thought the case had grown stronger in recent months for an interest rate increase and Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer said Yellen's remarks were consistent with a view that the U.S. central bank might raise rates at its Sept. 20-21 policy meeting.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Mester, a voting member on the Fed's policy-setting committee, had earlier in the day told a philanthropy conference that the U.S. economy probably needs to generate between 75,000 and 150,000 jobs per month to keep the jobless rate stable.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Hiring has been stronger than that this year and the U.S. jobless rate is currently at 4.9 percent.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "The economy is basically at full employment," Mester said.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: The U.S. Labor Department's monthly employment report on Friday is expected to show the economy added 180,000 jobs in August <USNFAR=ECI>, according to the median forecast in a Reuters poll.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Mester said she said she did not share the view labor activists delivered to Fed officials last week that low interest rates could help resolve racial income and employment gaps in America.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "I do not believe that at this point in the business cycle the current very low level of interest rates is an effective solution to these longer-run issues," she said.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Mester said last week it makes sense for the Fed to start raising rates. REUTERS

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: SINGAPORE — Lost in a shopping mall or need to find your way to the promotions or products you are looking for? Let your smartphone talk to the lights around and they will show you the way.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: That is visual light communications (VLC) — a LED-based indoor positioning technology that could be deployed by Philips Lighting in one of CapitaLand’s malls here by the end of the year.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: All the shopper needs to do is launch an app and allow the front camera on the smartphone to pick up a unique light frequency emanating from the Philips lights in the mall. The shopper’s location in the mall will be identified, and he or she can find the way around. Meanwhile, retailers are also able to use the location-based service to attract shoppers with targeted marketing messages.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: Philips said yesterday it is conducting the world’s first pilot of the technology in a mall, where VLC is being used to enable communications between the Dutch technology giant’s light fixtures and shoppers’ smartphones in a CapitaLand mall. Philips has so far tested this technology in supermarkets such as Carrefour in France and Aswaaq in Dubai.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: It did not disclose the name of the mall in which the new technology is being piloted, but said the technology could be deployed by year’s end depending on the outcome of the pilot. CapitaLand will decide later whether to roll it out at more malls.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: “We are talking to several retailers and we expect that those looking at providing innovative experiences to their customers will be interested … Connected lighting is poised to serve as the backbone of the smart city, where LED light points can be connected, be managed wirelessly in the Internet of Things,” said Ms Patricia Yim, market leader, Asean Pacific, Philips Lighting. Lighting has proven to be an ideal platform for systems and software that allow individual structures and entire cities to operate more efficiently and sustainably than before, she added.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: The announcement was made at Philips Lighting opening yesterday of its new Lighting Application Centre (LAC) at its APAC Centre in Toa Payoh. The LAC, spanning 5,296sqf or about the size of six four-room HDB flats, was built at an investment of S$1.8 million.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: Besides the VLC pilot, CapitaLand and Philips Lighting have joined hands in three other pilots, including the cloud-based Philips ActiveSite for remote management and maintenance of facade lighting without the need to be present in the building’s control room; the power-over-Ethernet lighting system that offers office workers the flexibility to control lighting of their workspaces through an app in their smartphones; and a green parking system, which delivers light where and when it is needed based on motion sensing, generating energy savings while ensuring a safe level of lighting in the car park.

Headline: Lost in the mall? Count on the guiding light
Text: Apart from CapitaLand, Philips Lighting is also collaborating with Toll Global Logistics as well as Temasek Polytechnic and Admiralty Secondary School to drive the next wave of innovation. Rumi Hardasmalani

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: BEIJING - China's commerce ministry will launch an anti-monopoly probe into Comcast Corp's <CMCSA.O> planned purchase of DreamWorks Animation after receiving unspecified complaints that the U.S. media deal could hurt competition in the Chinese market.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: The investigation comes as China's anti-trust watchdog has hardened its stance on companies striking deals without seeking its clearance, with the body naming, shaming and fining almost a dozen firms over the past year for "gun-jumping".

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: Comcast, owner of NBCUniversal, said in April it would pay $3.8 billion to buy DreamWorks, the producer of the "Kung Fu Panda" and "Shrek" franchises, which was also one of the first Hollywood names to open a production studio in China.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: "Recently MOFCOM received complaints regarding Comcast's decision to buy out DreamWorks, claiming that the deal would hurt competition in the Chinese market," Shen Danyang, spokesman for the Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) said on Friday. Shen didn't say exactly what the complaints were, nor who made them.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: China's film market, the world's second largest, is a magnet for film producers looking to tap the country's 1.4 billion people, even though there are signs that stellar box office growth may be starting to slow.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: Reuters was unable to reach Comcast or DreamWorks for immediate comment out of regular U.S. business hours.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: Separately, China's commerce ministry said on Friday it would investigate the planned merger of ride-hailing firm Didi Chuxing and the Chinese unit of U.S. rival Uber over anti-monopoly concerns. REUTERS

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: SINGAPORE — The micro-hotel, a concept that first gained traction in Europe with brands like Yotel and CitizenM at airports and in urban centres, is becoming more popular with travellers.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Yotel, which opened its first micro-hotel in London’s Gatwick Airport in 2007 and has others in Amsterdam and New York City, plans to expand in Singapore and Geneva, as well as in San Francisco, Boston and Miami.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Yotel, whose rooms at its New York City property are about 170 sq ft each, is expected to open its first flagship property in Asia next year with the launch of Yotel Singapore in Orchard Road. The 610-room hotel, to be located next to the Thai Embassy, is looking to charge S$200 to S$240 a night, its general manager Brendan Daly was reported by travel industry portal TTG as saying. This will be followed by another micro-hotel in Changi Airport the following year.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “Disruptions from short-term rentals are creating a whole new supply channel,” said Mr Scott Berman, principal in the hospitality and leisure division at PricewaterhouseCoopers.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: As hotels seek to blunt the appeal of accommodation portal Airbnb and court younger and more independent travellers, some are choosing to go the micro-hotel way. These micro-hotels blend elements from cruise ships and hostels and are characterised by compact guest rooms, an embrace of technology and an oversized communal lounge.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: It is not just specialty chains that are drawn to the concept. Lured by the profit potential of squeezing more rooms into the same amount of space, and possibly reducing the overall cost of construction, larger chains are also planning micro-hotel projects.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Hilton Hotels & Resorts is introducing Tru, which will have an average room size of 225 sq ft, compared with the typical room size of about 350 sq ft at Hampton Inn, which is owned by Hilton. Marriott International, which introduced Moxy in Milan, is creating a guest room in the United States that is expected to be about 180 sq ft. A room at a Courtyard by Marriott, by contrast, is about 300 sq ft.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “There’s a higher acceptance of the small rooms,” said Mr Mark van Stekelenburg, a managing director at CBRE Hotels. He said that guests saw value if the hotel offered significant amenities.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Technology is a big draw, especially when deployed in creative ways. Yotel, for example, dispensed with bellhops in its New York micro-hotel, relying instead on a robotic arm to store and retrieve luggage.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: At CitizenM, a tablet computer controls the blinds and turns on the lights and the television. Moxy uses motion sensors to light the way into the private bathroom.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: For working, Hilton anticipates having private spaces and built-in alcoves instead of traditional business centres.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “There’s much less labour than in a traditional hotel,” said Ms Stephani Robson, a senior lecturer at the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: The focal point of these microhotels is their oversized common areas with sections for working, eating, drinking and playing. A recreation area might include a chess set or a foosball table.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “Travellers want friends and guests to meet them there and feel good about it,” said Mr Hubert Viriot, chief executive of Yotel. AGENCIES

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: NEW YORK - U.S. and European stocks ended mostly flat and the dollar fell on Thursday after a report showing weakness in U.S. manufacturing last month weighed on shares as investors eyed Friday's monthly U.S. jobs data, while oil prices tumbled.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The Institute for Supply Management said its index of national factory activity fell to 49.4 in August, below expectations of economists polled by Reuters for a dip to just 52.0. It was the first contraction in manufacturing since February.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The data hurt sentiment amid an already nervous investor environment ahead of Friday's U.S. employment report for August. Federal Reserve Vice Chair Stanley Fischer said last week that the central bank would consider the jobs data when discussing when to next raise interest rates.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: Employers are expected to have added 180,000 jobs in August, according to a Reuters poll of economists.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The benchmark U.S. S&P 500 <.SPX> fell as much as 0.7 percent after the ISM data before stabilizing. The tech-heavy Nasdaq <.IXIC> rose, boosted by Charter Communications <CHTR.O>, which gained 4.5 percent.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The weak U.S. ISM data also stifled European shares. Stocks in the region had earlier climbed to two-week highs.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: "The ISM data was, in a word, disappointing," said Peter Kenny, senior market strategist at Global Markets Advisory Group in New York. "It has forced investors to reconsider the landscape, not go blindly into the narrative that spells out a certainty about interest rates being bumped up in September.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: "Oil prices extended Wednesday's declines, with the market focused for a second straight day on U.S. government data showing a rise in U.S. crude stocks in the latest week.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: MSCI's all-country world equity index <.MIWD00000PUS> was last up 0.8 point, or 0.19 percent, at 417.41.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The Dow Jones industrial average <.DJI> ended up 18.42 points, or 0.1 percent, at 18,419.3. The S&P 500 <.SPX> ended down 0.09 point, or flat, at 2,170.86. The Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> gained 13.99 points, or 0.27 percent, at 5,227.21.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: Europe's broad FTSEurofirst 300 index <.FTEU3> closed down 0.08 percent, at 1,351.17.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: Brent crude <LCOc1> settled down $1.44, or 3.07 percent, at $45.45 a barrel. U.S. crude <CLc1> settled down $1.54, or 3.45 percent, at $43.16 a barrel.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The dollar index <.DXY>, which measures the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, pulled back from Wednesday's more than three-week high of 96.255 and was last down 0.42 percent at 95.620 after the ISM data cast doubts on the strength of the U.S. economy.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: U.S. Treasury yields were little changed ahead of Friday's U.S. jobs data. Benchmark 10-year yields <US10YT=RR> were last at 1.570 percent, compared with 1.568 percent late on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: "The scenario that the market is not ready for is for a strong number tomorrow and for the Fed to guide toward a rate hike in September," said Subadra Rajappa, head of U.S. rates strategy at Societe Generale. The dollar's weakness helped spot gold <XAU=> recover after touching a more than two-month low of $1,301.91 an ounce. U.S. gold futures <GCcv1> settled up 0.4 percent at $1,317.10. REUTERS

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: SAN FRANCISCO - Even if a report due Friday shows U.S. companies kept up their rapid pace of hiring in August, there is still enough resistance among policymakers at the Federal Reserve to delay an interest-rate hike at the bank's September meeting.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Reuters polling forecasts that 180,000 jobs were added last month, well above the 100,000 Fed Chair Janet Yellen says is needed to absorb newcomers to the labor market. At that rate, 2016 would be on pace for more than 2 million new jobs.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Despite those strong gains that have pushed the unemployment rate down to 4.9 percent, some at the Fed are not convinced of the need to move yet. Among them is Fed Board Governor Lael Brainard, who has warned of downside risks to the economy and said the rate hike path needs to be "shallow."

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Governor Jerome Powell, who last week called for "caution" on rate hikes, and Governor Daniel Tarullo, who has signaled he wants to see more evidence that inflation is on the rise, are also skeptical of the need to move soon.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: And even Yellen, who said last week that an improving labor market and signs that inflation are firming have strengthened the case for a rate hike, has said nothing on the timing, even though her more hawkish Vice Chair Stanley Fischer ignited rate hike expectations when he spoke after Yellen.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Despite the strong labor market gains, the economy's performance by other measures has been tepid. The most recent estimates put growth in the second quarter at just 1.1 percent, far less than the 2 percent in the quarter prior to last December's rate hike. The Fed's preferred inflation measure remains stuck at 1.6 percent, well below its 2-percent target.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Weakness in productivity persists as well, an increasing concern for the Federal Reserve as lower productivity will crimp the future potential rate of growth for the economy as a whole.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Reports released Thursday showed U.S. factory activity contracted in August for the first time in six months, pointing to weakness in manufacturing. Annual business investment as a proportion of gross domestic product has been running a full percentage point below its pre-recession readings.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: A working paper published this week on the San Francisco Fed's website added to a gloomy view of longer-term growth prospects in the world's largest economy.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Economist John Fernald -- whose work on productivity is frequently cited by Fed policymakers including Yellen -- estimated the U.S. economy will probably only grow 1.6 percent a year over the next decade or so. That's well below the 2 percent that many Fed policymakers and economists currently expect.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: "For policymakers, it suggests a low 'speed limit' for the economy," Fernald said.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: IF NOT SEPTEMBER, THEN DECEMBER?

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Still, some Fed officials worry that persisting with low rates to edge the unemployment rate down further could lead to uncomfortably strong upward price pressure or feed destabilizing asset bubbles.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: To these policymakers, who include the reliably hawkish heads of the Cleveland and Kansas City Feds, Loretta Mester and Esther George, as well as the usually dovish chief of the Boston Fed, Eric Rosengren, raising interest rates slowly but soon is key to keeping the U.S. economy from overheating.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: "If we stay too loose for too long, bad things can happen," said Barclays' economist Michael Gapen, summing up the view he sees as winning the day at the Fed.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: The Fed last raised rates in December of last year, after keeping them near zero since the 2007-2009 financial crisis to encourage investment and hiring.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Several regional Fed presidents do appear to favor a near-term rate hike.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: So even if September passes without a rate hike, an increase in 2016 is still very much on the table.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Financial markets also seem primed for December. Traders of Fed funds futures see a 24 percent chance of a hike this month, with a better than even chance of a move in December <0#FF:> <FFZ6>. REUTERS

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: SINGAPORE — Singapore has maintained its position as the largest foreign exchange (FX) centre in the Asia-Pacific region and the third largest globally after London and New York, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said yesterday.

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: The average daily forex trading volume in Singapore was US$517 billion (S$705 billion) in April, up 35 per cent from US$383 billion in April 2013, when the Bank for International Settlements last conducted its Triennial Central Bank Survey of Foreign Exchange and Derivatives Market Activity.

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: Singapore’s share of global forex volumes has also grown to 7.9 per cent in 2016, from 5.7 per cent three years ago. Globally, trading in forex markets averaged US$5.1 trillion per day in April, down from US$5.4 trillion in April 2013.

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: “Singapore is building on its role as the pre-eminent marketplace in Asia for global and regional banks, non-bank financial institutions and corporate treasurers to manage their FX risks. MAS is working with the industry to further enhance price discovery, liquidity and transparency in our FX market by strengthening electronic trading capabilities and anchoring market infrastructure,” said Ms Jacqueline Loh, Deputy Managing Director of MAS in a statement.

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: ROME - Italy has received no communication from the German transport ministry over emissions tests used by carmaker Fiat Chrysler <FCHA.MI>, a source at Italy's infrastructure ministry said on Thursday.

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: Germany's transport ministry has asked the European Commission to investigate exhaust emissions of Fiat Chrysler vehicles for potential illegal manipulation devices, German government documents showed.

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: The Italian ministry source said the relevant authorities had been in contact and Germany's KBA motor vehicle authority had never disagreed with the Italian ministry's finding that Fiat vehicles complied with emissions rules.

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: A Fiat spokeswoman said the cars complied with the rules and do not contain so-called defeat devices. REUTERS

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: TORONTO - Canadian yoga wear retailer Lululemon Athletica Inc <LULU.O> reported comparable sales growth that fell short of analyst estimates, sending shares down nearly 9 percent on Thursday even as earnings were in line with expectations.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Second-quarter sales online and at stores open at least a year rose 5 percent, excluding exchange rate fluctuations. Analysts polled by research firm Consensus Metrix had expected a 5.9 percent increase.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Baird Equity Research analyst Mark Altschwager said the comparable sales miss would likely "fuel investor anxiety" given high expectations and the strong performance of Lululemon's stock. Before earnings, shares were up 46 percent year to date.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: On a conference call, Chief Financial Officer Stuart Haselden reminded analysts and investors that Lululemon had an online promotion in the second quarter of last year. Excluding the impact of that sale, he said, comparable sales would have increased about 2 more percentage points.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: "We did see traffic continue to be a headwind for us in the second quarter," said Haselden, adding that customers did make larger purchases, offsetting that trend. "I think we are not immune to what's happening from a macro standpoint."

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: U.S. retail sales were unexpectedly flat in July as consumers cut back on discretionary spending.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: The Vancouver-based company forecast fiscal third-quarter earnings between 42 and 44 cents a share. Analysts, on average, had expected earnings of 44 cents for that quarter, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Once a market darling thanks to its successful move into the U.S. market, a feat few Canadian retailers accomplish, the company has struggled with embarrassing product recalls and inventory problems in recent years.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Inventory levels fell 1 percent in the quarter, to $277.3 million.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: The company helped bring pricey women's yoga pants into the fashion mainstream before expanding into running and other sports. It now makes men's clothing, and its Ivivva line offers athletic clothing for younger clientele.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: It competes with Nike Inc <NKE.N> and Under Armour Inc <UA.N>, as well as mainstream clothing retailers from Gap Inc <GPS.N> to Nordstrom <JWN.N>.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Net income rose to $53.6 million, or 39 cents a share, from $47.7 million, or 34 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 14 percent to $514.5 million. Excluding a tax and related interest adjustment, earnings were 38 cents a share.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: On average, analysts had been expecting earnings of 38 cents a share and revenue of $515.5 million, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Shares dropped 8.6 percent to $70.07 in after-market trading. REUTERS

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: WASHINGTON — International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Ms Christine Lagarde said the institution will likely downgrade its 2016 global growth forecast yet again as economic prospects are dimmed by weak demand, as well as flagging trade and investment.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: In an interview with Reuters published on Friday (Sept 2), she said that G20 leaders need to do far more to spur demand, bolster the case for trade and globalisation, and fight growing inequality.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: And while some major threats to the global economy have yet to materialise, such as the feared recession from Britain’s vote to leave the European Union or a collapse in Chinese growth, she described the overall outlook as fragile, weak and certainly not fuelled by trade.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: “You could argue that Brexit is not really delivering the massive crisis that we had expected, you could argue that the Chinese transition is proceeding reasonably well, and you could argue that low commodity prices have gone up a little bit. However, when you look deep down at the economic growth prospects, at the growth potential, at the productivity, we are not getting very good signals, and we will probably be revising down our forecast for growth in 2016,” she warned.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: The IMF is due to revise its World Economic Outlook forecasts in early October ahead of its annual meetings with the World Bank. Another cut would be the IMF’s sixth straight growth markdown in about 18 months. Citing global uncertainty over the June 23 Brexit vote, the IMF had in July cut global gross domestic product growth estimates to 3.1 per cent for 2016 and 3.4 per cent for 2017 — down about a tenth of a point for each year.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: Ms Lagarde said she will warn G20 leaders meeting in Hangzhou in China on Sunday and Monday that further reductions in growth potential and more obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, capital and people would hurt all of their economies. She said people harmed by trade and innovation need to be helped by policies to allow them to retrain and acquire new skills and job mobility.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: The IMF said in a briefing note to the G20 summit that falling trade volumes have contributed to lower GDP growth and urged them to make a stronger case for the benefits of trade. REUTERS

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: LEXINGTON, Ky. - The U.S. labor market is at full strength and the Federal Reserve needs to be on a path of gradual interest rate increases, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said on Thursday.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "It seems like a gradual increase from a very low interest rate that we are at now is pretty compelling to me," Mester told reporters without saying whether she would support an increase at the Fed's policy meeting later this month. REUTERS

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: LONDON/SINGAPORE - Manufacturers across Asia and Europe showed few signs of returning to health in August, as demand remained fitful at best, although British factories bucked the global trend, surveys showed on Thursday.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Britain's manufacturing rebounded from the shock of June's vote to leave the European Union, helped by a boost to exports from sterling's post-Brexit slump [GB/PMIM].

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Recent data have shown consumer demand holding up, and Thursday's survey suggests manufacturing, which accounts for 10 percent of Britain's economy, is weathering the impact of the vote better than feared.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: "The plunge in sterling is boosting the UK's competitiveness, which is helping to support export orders, while the aggressive stimulus from the Bank of England and the smooth transition of political leadership has also helped calm immediate fears for the economy," said James Knightley at ING.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: "Nonetheless, the risks of recession have not disappeared and with surveys still suggesting a significant pullback on hiring and investment intentions we remain concerned about the prospect of a weaker performance around the turn of the year."

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: The UK Markit/CIPS Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) jumped to a 10-month high of 53.3 in August after tumbling to a three-year low in July following the referendum. A reading above 50 indicates growth.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: August's monthly surge was the joint largest in the manufacturing survey's near 25-year history and beat all forecasts in a Reuters poll of economists. After the release, the pound jumped over a cent to $1.3250, putting it on course for its best day in two weeks. [GBP/]

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: However, survey compiler Markit said reduced sales to Britain were partly to blame for slowdown in orders in the neighboring euro zone. [EUR/PMIM]

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Manufacturing growth in the currency bloc slowed during August. Much of the expansion remained focused in the north, and the survey hinted at a further slowdown this month.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Germany, the Netherlands and Austria again provided the main power. France and Italy showed declines, Greece stagnated and both Spain and Ireland saw their worst growth since mid-2013.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Markit's PMI for the bloc dipped to 51.7 in August from 52.0, below a flash estimate of 51.8. An index measuring output came in at 53.3, below July's 53.9.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Manufacturing growth in the United States also eased last month, data are expected to show later on Thursday. reuters://realtime/verb=Open/url=cpurl://apps.cp./Apps/econ-polls?RIC=USPMI%3DECI

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: STORM CLOUDS

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Coming a week after the U.S. posted sluggish second-quarter growth, the uninspiring manufacturing surveys may give Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen pause before a Fed meeting on Sept. 20-21 to decide whether to raise interest rates.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: In China, the world's second-biggest economy the official PMI ticked up to 50.4 in August, compared with the previous month's 49.9. But the private Caixin PMI, which covers a greater share of smaller firms, showed activity stagnated last month.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: "While it is encouraging that manufacturing activity appears to be stabilizing, there is a risk that this is a 'calm before the storm' moment for the sector," said Danae Kyriakopoulou at Cebr.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: With central banks almost exhausting their monetary policy support, governments have increased fiscal stimulus. Underlying demand in many of Asia's export-reliant economies remains weak, however.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: In Japan, manufacturing showed signs of steadying, but the IHS Markit/Nikkei PMI was still in contraction at 49.5 in August. Although output increased for the first time in six months, export orders continued to fall, bolstering expectations the Bank of Japan will need to offer more stimulus.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: The pressure on Japanese policy makers was underscored by separate data showing Japanese business expenditure fell in April-June from the previous quarter.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: Conditions were even gloomier in South Korea, a bellwether for global demand. An extended slide in exports has hit manufacturers in Asia's fourth-largest economy, with the August PMI contracting at its fastest pace in a year.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: "Given Korea acts as a harbinger for the rest of Asia, we believe Asia's cycle is now headed for another down-move," said Vaninder Singh, Asia economist at RBS in a note to clients.

Headline: Manufacturing falters as global demand weakens
Text: There were some encouraging signs in India. August factory activity expanded at its fastest pace since mid-2015, but investors will have to square that with data released on Wednesday that showed economic growth slipped to its lowest in more than a year in the three months from April to June. REUTERS

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: NEW YORK - Wall Street's biggest banks are sticking to bets that the U.S. Federal Reserve will raise interest rates once this year, and the increase would most likely occur in December after a tepid employment report for August quashed most talk of a move as early as this month.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Economists for 13 out of 14 primary dealers who responded to a Reuters poll on Friday said they expect the Fed to lift the targeted range for its benchmark short-term interest rate by a quarter-percentage point to a median level of 0.63 percent by year end. The current mid-point for the federal funds rate is 0.38 percent.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Friday's outcome is broadly in line with the results of a poll one month ago. Then, 14 of 21 primary dealers, or firms that do business directly with the Fed, had forecast a year-end federal funds rate of 0.63 percent.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Economists in Friday's poll assigned a median probability for a rate hike at the Sept. 20-21 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy-setting body, of just 35 percent. That probability rises to 63 percent by year end.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: By contrast, market-based forecasting tools, such as federal funds futures, imply a less-than 25 percent probability of the Fed hiking this month and just over 50 percent by December.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: The economists were polled following Friday's monthly payrolls report, which showed U.S. employers added fewer-than-expected workers in August.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with hiring in manufacturing and construction sectors declining, the Labor Department said on Friday. Analysts had expected payrolls to rise by 180,000.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: The unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.9 percent as more people flocked to the labor market.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Of the 13 banks forecasting a rate rise this year, just three - Goldman Sachs, BNP Paribas and Societe General - see it occurring as early as this month.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: For Goldman Sachs and Societe General, that represented an acceleration in their view of the Fed's next tightening move, even as the U.S. employment report for August came in well below target.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Goldman Sachs Chief Economist Jan Hatzius said in a note that while the August employment report featured some soft elements, it still would be "just enough" to induce the Fed to move later this month. He placed a 55 percent probability on the Fed raising its rate at its next meeting compared with just a 30 percent probability in the prior poll.

Headline: Wall Street still sees Fed on pace for one rate hike, in December: Reuters poll
Text: Looking beyond December, nine of the 12 economists forecast at least two rate increases next year, with a median forecast for the rate by December 2017 of 1.13 percent. REUTERS

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: SAN FRANCISCO - Alphabet Inc’s <GOOGL.O> Google has suspended Project Ara, its ambitious effort to build what is known as a modular smartphone with interchangeable components, as part of a broader push to streamline the company's hardware efforts, two people with knowledge of the matter said.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: The move marks an about-face for the tech company, which announced a host of partners for Project Ara at its developer conference in May and said it would ship a developer edition of the product this autumn.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: The company’s aim was to create a phone that users could customize on the fly with an extra battery, camera, speakers or other components.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: A spokeswoman for Google declined to comment on the matter.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: While Google will not be releasing the phone itself, the company may work with partners to bring Project Ara’s technology to market, potentially through licensing agreements, one of the people with knowledge of the matter said.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Axing Project Ara is one of the first steps in a campaign to unify Google’s various hardware efforts, which range from Chromebook laptops to Nexus phones. Former Motorola president Rick Osterloh rejoined Google earlier this year to oversee the effort. Google sold Motorola Mobility to Lenovo Group in 2014.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Modular smartphones have generated great enthusiasm in the tech community for their potential to prolong the lifespan of a device and reduce electronic waste.
