But the devices are difficult to bring to market because their interchangeable parts make them bulky and costly to produce, said analyst Bob O’Donnell of TECHnalysis Research, adding that he was not surprised to see Google halt the project.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: “This was a science experiment that failed, and they are moving on,” he said.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Project Ara was one of the flagship efforts of Google’s Advanced Technology and Projects group, which aims to develop new devices, but it had various stops and starts.

Headline: Exclusive: Google shelves plan for phone with interchangeable parts - sources
Text: Last year, the company shelved plans to sell the modular phone in Puerto Rico with Latin American carriers. REUTERS

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: NEW YORK - Oil settled up nearly 3 percent on Friday after a weak U.S. jobs report hurt the dollar and boosted commodities, but crude prices still ended the week sharply lower on concerns about oversupply.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: U.S. employment growth eased more than expected in August after two straight months of robust gains, the report showed.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: That initially led to doubts that the Federal Reserve would hike interest rates at its Sept. 20-21 meeting. The dollar, however, rose later in the day on bets that a September rate hike remained on the cards. [FRX/]

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: Crude prices were also supported by a steadying U.S. oil rig count.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: After being unchanged last week, the oil rig count provided by industry firm Baker Hughes rose by just one this week as crude prices held below the key $50-a-barrel mark that analysts and drillers said made drilling more viable. [RIG/U]

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: "Notwithstanding today's dollar-driven rally, September is usually a weak time for oil with demand coming off the peak summer period. So if the rig count stays steady, we could finish the year at about $50," said Jay Hatfield of New York-based InfraCap MLP EFT, which invests in U.S. energy projects.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: Brent crude futures <LCOc1> settled up $1.38, or 3 percent, at $46.83 a barrel. For the week, Brent was down 6 percent, its biggest drop in five weeks.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: U.S. West Texas Intermediate futures <CLc1> rose $1.28, also 3 percent, to settle at $44.44. WTI fell nearly 7 percent on the week, its largest decline in eight weeks.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: "It's quite likely oil will hold at mid-$40 levels," said Carl Larry Director, director of business development for oil & gas at Frost & Sullivan. "More telling of how oil performs will be the rig count in coming weeks and OPEC gestures to support prices."

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: In early trading on Friday, oil rose after Russian President Vladimir Putin said in a Bloomberg interview that he supported attempts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to implement an output freeze with other oil producers.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: OPEC, led by Saudi Arabia and other big Middle East crude exporters, will meet non-member producers led by Russia at informal talks in Algeria from Sept. 26 to 28 to discuss an output freeze.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: If OPEC fails to strike a deal in Algeria, the cartel is expected to try other measures to support oil prices during its policy meeting in Vienna on Nov. 30.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: Many analysts remain skeptical that it would be successful.

Headline: Oil up 3 pct as U.S. jobs data hits dollar; tumbles on week
Text: "The oil price will remain volatile over the coming weeks," said Hans van Cleef, senior oil economist at ABN Amro. REUTERS

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: NEW YORK - U.S. stocks advanced on Friday as a weaker-than-expected payrolls report tamped down expectations for a September rate hike from the U.S. Federal Reserve, although hawkish comments from another Fed official kept expectations for one this year intact.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: U.S. nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs in August after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with job cuts in manufacturing and construction, the Labor Department said. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast payrolls rising by 180,000 last month.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Traders trimmed the probability of a Fed rate hike this month to 21 percent from the 24-percent chance on Thursday, according to CME Group's FedWatch program. However, the odds for a December rate increase edged up to 54.2 percent from 53.6 percent the previous day.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: "People are taking a little bit of a relief that it wasn’t a 200,000-plus print, certainly in the equity market," said Sean Lynch, co-head of global equity strategy at Wells Fargo Investment Institute in Omaha.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: "Equity markets are going to give the Fed at least one rate increase but if they start to perceive a series of hikes coming, and coming sooner than later, that is when equity markets will get a little nervous here."

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Despite the soft report, Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker on Friday said the U.S. economy appears strong enough to warrant significantly higher interest rates. Lacker argued that a range of economic analysis suggests the Fed's benchmark overnight interest rate is too low.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Several Fed officials have made hawkish comments about a rate hike in recent weeks, leaving investors unable to rule out the possibility of an increase at the central bank's next meeting, scheduled for Sept. 20-21.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The dollar index <.DXY>, which measures the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, bounced back after touching a one-week low to trade up 0.22 percent.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The Dow Jones industrial average <.DJI> rose 72.66 points, or 0.39 percent, to 18,491.96, the S&P 500 <.SPX> gained 9.12 points, or 0.42 percent, to 2,179.98 and the Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> added 22.69 points, or 0.43 percent, to 5,249.90.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: For the week, both the Dow and S&P 500 rose 0.5 percent and the S&P gained 0.6 percent.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The energy sector <.SPNY>, up 0.8 percent, helped pace gains as both WTI <CLc1> and Brent <LCOc1> oil prices settled up 3 percent, but crude prices still ended the week with sharp losses on oversupply concerns.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Utilities <.SPLRCU>, which benefit from low interest rates, were up 1.2 percent, the best performing of the 10 major S&P sectors.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Lululemon Athletica <LULU.O> lost 10.6 percent, its worst day since early December, at $68.57 after the Canadian yoga wear retailer reported quarterly comparable-sales growth below expectations.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Broadcom <AVGO.O> fell 2.2 percent to $173.11 after the chipmaker's revenue in its largest segment stalled in the latest quarter. The stock was the biggest drag on the S&P and the Nasdaq.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the NYSE by a 4.23-to-1 ratio; on Nasdaq, a 2.25-to-1 ratio favored advancers.

Headline: Wall Street advances as U.S. payrolls report falls short
Text: The S&P 500 posted 41 new 52-week highs and 2 new lows; the Nasdaq Composite recorded 151 new highs and 18 new lows. REUTERS

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: SINGAPORE — The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) intends to introduce by the fourth quarter legislative amendments aimed at boosting safeguards for wealthier investors.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: If passed by lawmakers, the central bank will aim to implement the changes to the so-called “accredited investor (AI)” regime next year, the MAS said in an e-mailed response to questions from Bloomberg on Friday (Sept 2).

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The timetable for the first parliamentary reading is in line with the central bank’s statement almost a year ago, when it said it would submit the proposals in 2016. The revisions are aimed at granting some wealthy individuals the option to choose protections available to retail investors. Singapore law assumes rich investors are better informed or have greater means to protect their own interests, and therefore exempts banks from having to provide certain disclosures about financial products that are made to retail investors.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: “Consistent with the practice in other major financial jurisdictions, the full suite of regulatory protection under the capital markets regulatory framework is aimed primarily at retail investors,” the MAS said.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: “The proposed refinements to the AI regime formed part of a package of proposals to enhance regulatory safeguards for investors in the capital markets.”

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: Under Singapore law, an individual accredited investor is a person who has more than S$2 million in personal assets including property, or made at least S$300,000 of income in the preceding 12 months. When dealing with accredited investors, banks and brokerages are exempt from certain requirements, such as having to provide a prospectus.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The proposed amendments will give such wealthy individuals the option to be treated as retail investors, thus extending relevant regulatory safeguards to them, the MAS said. The revision will also tighten the S$2 million net personal assets threshold so that an investor’s primary home can only contribute up to half that value, the MAS said.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: Some wealthy Singaporean investors are facing losses after a series of defaults among local dollar-denominated corporate bonds since November. Last month, energy services firm Swiber Holdings joined PT Trikomsel Oke and Pacific Andes Resources Development in defaulting on bond obligations.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: Private banks took up 49 per cent to 92 per cent of the unrated notes issued by the three companies in their sales from April 2013 to October 2014, according to a Bloomberg News analysis of figures from bond-sale arrangers and compiled by analysts.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: In its statement, the MAS called on private banks to consider their clients’ individual circumstances, investment portfolios and risk profiles in offering any investment product and services.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: “Notwithstanding the AI status of clients, private banks are expected to adopt fair business practices and act in the best interests of their clients,” the central bank said, adding that private banks are expected to adhere to the code of conduct “which sets out rigorous standards for dealing with their clients”.

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The MAS also said it’s conducting “consumer testing” on a complexity-risk ratings framework for investment products, to determine whether such a measure would be useful in decision making by investors. The authority said it will issue a statement on the matter “at a later date.”

Headline: MAS aims to boost safeguards for wealthier investors
Text: The framework was among several proposals including the investor protection amendments unveiled in a July 2014 consultation paper by the central bank. The system will take into account various factors that drive a product’s complexity in assigning a risk rating, such as the number of layers between the investor and the underlying asset, and the extensiveness of derivatives usage. BLOOMBERG

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: SHANGHAI/HONG KONG - The Chinese government said on Friday it was investigating two high-profile takeover proposals involving U.S. companies, the latest sign of its growing influence on whether deals are approved - even those appearing to have little impact in China.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The Commerce Ministry said at a briefing on Friday it was probing ride-hailing giant Didi Chuxing's planned acquisition of U.S. rival Uber Technologies Inc's <UBER.UL> China unit and Comcast Corp's <CMCSA.O> purchase of movie studio DreamWorks Animation.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The scrutiny, announced the day before world leaders descend on China's eastern city of Hangzhou for a meeting of the Group of 20, underscores the ministry's increasingly tough stance on companies that strike deals without seeking its approval.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The Chinese are increasingly using their regulatory might to gain influence in the global economy, according to one expert in international relations.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "DreamWorks and Comcast barely touch China, but it's a way to assert their new position in the world. They want to remind us, 'We're big and you have to pay attention to us,'" said Jim Lewis, of Washington’s Center for Strategic and International Studies think tank.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: A representative of the U.S. Department of State declined comment and referred queries to China's Commerce Ministry.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: There had not been a filing for the Didi-Uber deal, the ministry said last month. Comcast already said it had completed the deal for DreamWorks, which may indicate it did not think it needed to wait for Chinese approval.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry requires companies to notify it of transactions before they close if those merging have combined global turnover in the previous year exceeding 10 billion yuan ($1.5 billion) or their combined China income exceeds 2 billion yuan ($300 million).

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Didi said its deal did not trigger these thresholds, while lawyers said they were surprised that the DreamWorks deal was being probed given its small China footprint.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "With the DreamWorks-Comcast deal, I was kind of surprised," said Wendy Yan, Shanghai-based partner at Faegre Baker Daniels.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry said it had launched the investigation into the takeover following unspecified complaints that the combination of Comcast, one of the largest U.S. cable and broadcasting groups, with the movie studio could hurt competition in the Chinese market.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "I'd be interested to know who made such complaints and how exactly the (Comcast-DreamWorks) merger would affect the China market because they are not in a dominant position," added Yan.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: A representative for Comcast declined to comment on the Chinese probe.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Comcast, owner of NBCUniversal, said in April it would buy DreamWorks, the producer of the "Kung Fu Panda" and "Shrek" franchises, for $3.8 billion. DreamWorks was one of the first Hollywood names to open a production studio in China and NBCUniversal in 2014 announced plans to open a $3.3-billion Universal theme park in Beijing.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: China's film market, the world's second largest, is a magnet for movie producers looking to tap the country's 1.4 billion people, even though there are signs that stellar box office growth may be starting to slow.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Comcast announced the completion of the DreamWorks deal last week. The ministry has the power to fine companies it believes should have sought clearance, and can also force them to sell assets to get approval, or even to unwind transactions

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "If (Comcast) didn't file and they should have filed, this will be resolved with a fine and a press release," said Bruce McDonald, a veteran of the U.S. Department of Justice, now at law firm Jones Day. "Is this China just being tough on a U.S. company? I don't think so, it might be them being sticklers for following Chinese filing rules."

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: CONSUMER ANGER

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Lawyers said that the Didi deal to buy Uber's China unit had caused a stir among local consumers and rivals. The two ride-hailing firms were already the number one and two top players together controlling around 90 percent of the market.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry had signaled its discontent with the two companies last month because they had not filed a merger application to the regulator.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: A representative for Uber referred questions to Didi. A Didi spokeswoman said: "We are in communication with the authorities."

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Consumer groups and rivals have warned that fares could rise steeply if the two companies join forces. Both Uber and Didi had spent billions of dollars subsidizing fares in a price war to lure riders and drivers.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Marc Waha, head of the antitrust practice at Norton Rose Fulbright in Hong Kong, said a key concern for the ministry would be the elimination of Uber as a competitor to Didi.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "If the market is considered to only comprise those two car hailing services, the transaction could be seen as a merger from two-to-one, which is likely to be problematic, however small the target is."

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "Very often a small target acts as a maverick on the market, leading to low prices," he added.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: The ministry has developed a reputation globally as a tough regulator, but it has only blocked two transactions since China's antimonopoly law came into force in 2008, compared with 1,447 unconditional clearances, Norton Rose data shows.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: Faegre Baker Daniels's Yan added, however, Chinese regulators could end up with a deluge of new deals to work through if the latest probes were a sign of things to come.

Headline: China's government flexes muscles with Uber, DreamWorks probes
Text: "If the China government reaches out its hands too far they may need to deal with things they are not able to do and they need to have the manpower to review all these global mergers which may not have China implications," she said. REUTERS

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: NEW YORK - U.S. shares inched higher and European shares rallied on Friday after weaker-than-expected U.S. jobs data gave the Federal Reserve more leeway to stand pat on interest rates, while the dollar gained and longer-dated Treasury yields edged up.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: U.S. nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs in August after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with job cuts in manufacturing and construction, the Labor Department said. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast payrolls rising 180,000 last month.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Fed funds futures on Friday suggested traders saw a 21-percent probability of a Fed rate hike later this month, down from Thursday's probability of 24 percent, according to CME Group's FedWatch program.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Rate hike probabilities for September and December had risen after last Friday's remarks by Fed Chair Janet Yellen that the case for raising rates had strengthened in recent months.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: U.S. and European share markets cheered the jobs figures' implication that the Fed may wait until December to act.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: "People are taking a little bit of a relief that it wasn’t a 200,000 plus print, certainly in the equity market," said Sean Lynch, co-head of global equity strategy at Wells Fargo Investment Institute in Omaha, Nebraska.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: MSCI's all-country world equity index <.MIWD00000PUS> was last up 2.94 points, or 0.7 percent, at 420.29.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: The Dow Jones industrial average <.DJI> closed up 72.66 points, or 0.39 percent, at 18,491.96. The S&P 500 <.SPX> ended up 9.12 points, or 0.42 percent, at 2,179.98. The Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> closed up 22.69 points, or 0.43 percent, at 5,249.90. [nL1N1BE1KT]

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Europe's broad FTSEurofirst 300 index <.FTEU3> closed up 2.06 percent, at 1,378.94.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: For the week, the S&P 500 rose 0.5 percent to mark its first positive week in three, while the FTSEurofirst 300 posted its second straight week of gains and its biggest since mid-July, at 1.9 percent.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Despite the jobs data not clearly reinforcing a September rate hike, the dollar gained on the prospect of a December rate increase.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: The dollar index <.DXY>, which measures the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, was last up 0.21 percent at 95.850 after hitting a one-week low of 95.189 immediately after the data. [nL1N1BE1BU]

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Safe-haven U.S. Treasuries prices initially rallied on the U.S. jobs data, with two-year yields <US2YT=RR> falling to their lowest in 10 days of 0.746 percent and benchmark 10-year yields hitting a one-week low of 1.543 percent <US10YT=RR>.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: But yields reversed that drop later in the session, with two-year yields last little changed at 0.794 percent and 10-year yields last at 1.601 percent, compared with a 10-year yield of 1.570 percent late on Thursday. [nL1N1BE1ET]

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: "We’re in a low-expectation environment and these numbers are still positive," said Ellis Phifer, market strategist at Raymond James in Memphis, Tennessee, in reference to the U.S. jobs data.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: The dollar's initial weakness helped prompt gains in oil prices, though despite the day's rise, crude prices still ended the week sharply lower on concerns about oversupply.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: Brent crude <LCOc1> settled up $1.38, or 3.04 percent, at $46.83 a barrel. U.S. crude <CLc1> settled up $1.28, or 2.97 percent, at $44.44 a barrel.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: For the week, Brent fell 6 percent, its biggest drop in five weeks, while U.S. crude fell nearly 7 percent to mark its largest decline in eight weeks.

Headline: Global stocks cheered by potential dovish Fed; dollar gains
Text: U.S. gold futures <GCcv1> settled up 0.7 percent at $1,326.70. [nL8N1BE20K] REUTERS

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: WASHINGTON - The U.S. trade deficit fell more than expected in July as exports rose to their highest level in 10 months, offering further evidence that economic growth picked up early in the third quarter.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: The Commerce Department said on Friday the trade gap narrowed 11.6 percent to $39.5 billion, declining after three straight months of increases. June's trade deficit was revised slightly up to $44.7 billion.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Economists polled by Reuters had forecast the trade gap decreasing to $42.7 billion in July after a previously reported $44.5 billion shortfall. When adjusted for inflation, the deficit dropped to $58.3 billion from $64.5 billion in June.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: The trade report added to upbeat reports on consumer spending, industrial production and residential construction that have suggested the economy has regained momentum after output increased 1.0 percent in the first half.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Despite July's increase, exports continue to be hobbled by the residual effects of the dollar's surge against the currencies of the United States' main trading partners between June 2014 and December.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Export growth could come under pressure. International Monetary Fund Managing Director Christine Lagarde told Reuters this week the IMF would likely downgrade its 2016 global growth forecast because of weak demand, flagging trade and investment.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Exports of goods and services rose 1.9 percent in July to $186.3 billion, the highest since September 2015. Exports to the European Union dropped 9.5 percent, with goods shipped to the United Kingdom falling 9.2 percent.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Exports to China increased 3.8 percent.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Imports of goods and services slipped 0.8 percent to $225.8 billion in July. Oil prices averaged $41.02 per barrel in July, the highest level since September 2015.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: It was the fifth consecutive month that oil prices increased.

Headline: U.S. trade deficit narrows as exports hit 10-month high
Text: Imports from China rose 2.4 percent. The politically sensitive U.S.-China trade deficit increased 1.9 percent to $30.3 billion in July. REUTERS

Headline: Ireland fully behind corporate tax regime ahead of review: minister
Text: DUBLIN - Ireland's government stands fully behind its corporate tax regime, Public Expenditure Minister Paschal Donohoe said on Friday, ahead of an independent review it commissioned into how multinationals pay their tax.

Headline: Ireland fully behind corporate tax regime ahead of review: minister
Text: The Irish government has decided to appeal a demand by the European Commission that Apple pay Dublin 13 billion euros in back taxes, although independent members of the coalition called for the review.

Headline: Ireland fully behind corporate tax regime ahead of review: minister
Text: "This government stands fully behind our corporate tax regime. It is absolutely essential that this system and this rate be maintained," Donohoe, a member of the main Irish coalition party, Fine Gael, told a news conference. REUTERS

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: FRANKFURT - Former Volkswagen <VOWG_p.DE> manager Wolfgang Schreiber is suing the carmaker for hundreds of millions of euros in royalty payments for his role in developing a dual clutch gearbox, Der Spiegel reported.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: The German magazine, citing a lawsuit over patents filed in a Munich court, said Schreiber had turned down 20 million euros ($22 mln) in compensation and was seeking "adequate" compensation.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: The dual clutch gearbox is in use in millions of VW-branded passenger cars.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: A Volkswagen spokesman confirmed Schreiber had formally demanded compensation from VW, but declined to comment on details such as the amount being sought, given that it is an ongoing and unresolved dispute.

Headline: Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Ex Volkswagen manager seeks millions of euros in patent royalties: Der Spiegel
Text: ($1 = 0.8966 euros) REUTERS

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: TORONTO - BlackBerry Ltd said on Friday that its encryption technology is being used to toughen a "spy-proof" Samsung tablet that is being used by German government agencies dealing with classified information.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: The device, a Samsung Galaxy Tab S2, includes a security card and encryption and certification software developed by BlackBerry's Secusmart, which locks down data stored on and transferred from the SecuTABLET, the Canadian company said in a statement.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: Knox, a Samsung security product, is also included.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: Canada's BlackBerry, a smartphone pioneer, has sought to build up its focus on security and productivity software and the management of more popular handsets as it trims its own money-losing phones.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: BlackBerry did not disclose the value of the deal with the German agencies.

Headline: BlackBerry teams with Samsung for 'spy-proof' tablet for Germany
Text: It unveiled its second Android-based handset in July. REUTERS

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: SINGAPORE — The increase in hotel room supply coupled with a weak corporate demand outlook will continue to present operating challenges to the hospitality industry in Singapore for the rest of the year, said analysts at OCBC Investment Research, which is keeping a “Neutral” rating on the sector.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “Given the weak RevPAR (revenue per available room) performance across the board … we remain pessimistic about the operating performance of hospitality assets for the second half of this year,” analysts Deborah Ong and Andy Wong wrote in a research report.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “There are two key reasons for this underperformance: First, the overhang of supply from 2015, and second, weak macroeconomic conditions, especially in the commodities and finance sector, which has taken a hit on corporate demand.”

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: Hospitality real estate investment trusts under the research firm’s coverage — Ascott Residence Trust, CDL Hospitality Trusts, Far East Hospitality Trust and OUE Hospitality Trust (OUEHT) — are currently trading at yields of about 7 per cent. Second-quarter distribution per unit growth ranged from 1.9 per cent to minus 39.5 per cent on a year-on-year unadjusted basis, and from minus 0.9 per cent to 19.1 per cent, after adjusting for one-off items and equity financing.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: RevPAR contracted between 2.1 per cent (to S$83 for Global Premium Hotels) and 9.2 per cent (to S$157 for CDL Hospitality Trust’s Singapore assets) in the second quarter from the corresponding period last year, with OUEHT’s Crowne Plaza posting the least negative performance.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “While OUEHT’s results were among the most resilient in the first quarter of 2016, its five-star Mandarin Orchard posted an 8.3 per cent drop in RevPAR this quarter. Other REITs continue to cite poor corporate demand, which contributed to low to mid single-digit drops in their average room rates (ARR) and average occupancy rates (AOR),” said the analysts.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: Total hotel room stock surged 6.5 per cent to 60,908 last year, far outpacing the 0.9 per cent increase in tourist arrivals, they noted, saying they believed this contributed to last year’s decline in AOR, ARR, and RevPAR, which fell by 0.5 per cent, 4.8 per cent and 5.3 per cent, respectively.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: “Going forward, we believe the room supply injection will not be adequately matched by a growth in demand. The room supply is expected to increase another 4.7 per cent to 63,800 rooms this year. Even though visitor days has shown a healthy start (up 4.5 per cent from January to June this year), the outlook for corporate demand remains weak, especially for corporates in the oil & gas and financial sectors. As such, we expect this supply overhang to worsen this year, contributing to downward pressures on RevPAR,” the analysts warned.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: Amid economic uncertainty and regional competition, the Singapore Tourism Board is aiming to increase tourism receipts by 2 per cent this year to S$22.4 billion, and arrivals by 3 per cent to 15.7 million visitors.

Headline: Hotel room glut, soft corporate demand to hit hospitality sector
Text: However, its efforts are now being complicated by the Zika outbreak in Singapore: Australia, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Kingdom and United States have issued advisories against visiting Singapore, saying that pregnant women or those trying to get pregnant should avoid the city-state.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: HONG KONG - Private equity firms Carlyle Group <CG.O> and TPG Capital have teamed up with two separate Chinese state companies to bid for McDonald's <MCD.N> outlets in China and Hong Kong in a deal worth between $2 billion and $3 billion, four people familiar with the matter said.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: The sources said the global buyout firms are pairing up with strategic bidders that more closely fit the profile McDonald's has said it is looking for; long-term partners, rather than private equity firms, which typically cash out after a few years.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Carlyle is working with Chinese state conglomerate CITIC Group, and TPG has joined hands with Beijing Capital Agribusiness Group, to place binding bids ahead of the mid-September deadline, the people added. Beijing Capital Agribusiness is McDonald's current China partner.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Carlyle and TPG would have a large minority stake in their respective consortium, one of the people said.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Reuters previously reported that the Illinois-based fast-food giant, which has been hit by a series of food-supply scandals in China, had hired Morgan Stanley <MS.N> to run the sale of about 2,800 restaurants in China, Hong Kong and South Korea.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: The two private equity-backed groups are only bidding for China and Hong Kong outlets and will be pitted against China Cinda Asset Management Co <1359.HK>, Beijing Tourism Group and private Chinese technology and real estate firm Sanpower Group, one of the people added.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: China and Hong Kong account for more than 85 percent of the total 2,800 outlets up for grabs.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Separately, South Korea's Maeil Dairy Industry Co Ltd <005990.KQ> said it was considering bidding for McDonald's local outlets, which are expected to fetch about $268 million. The company declined to say whether it would seek a partner, but a South Korean media report said Maeil was likely to link up with Carlyle.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: CJ Corp and NHN Entertainment Corp were among the other South Korean companies that have previously shown interest in the fast food giant's business in the country.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: McDonald's is switching to a less capital-intensive franchise model and is offering a 20-year franchise to buyers, with a 10-year extension option.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: The franchise model has also been adopted by other fast-food operators, including arch rival Yum Brands <YUM.N>, which licences KFC and Pizza Hut outlets.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: Carlyle, TPG, Sanpower and Cinda declined to comment, and CITIC and Beijing Capital Agribusiness Group did not reply to requests for comment.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: A McDonald's spokeswoman said no decisions had been made.

Headline: Carlyle, TPG form separate teams to bid for McDonald's North Asia stores: sources
Text: "We are making progress as we look for long-term strategic partners with local relevance ... and who share our values and vision with a dedicated focus on accelerating growth initiatives," she said. REUTERS

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: NEW DELHI/DETROIT - Ford Motor Co <F.N> has shelved plans to produce a new compact car family designed mainly for emerging markets like India and China, industry sources said, reflecting disappointing sales of mainstream models in the world's fastest growing car markets.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: India and China were expected to be the main manufacturing hubs for the new B500 range, slated to begin production in 2018 and to include a premium sedan, hatchback and sport utility vehicle (SUV), two sources with direct knowledge of Ford's plans told Reuters.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The automaker had also planned to build its new models in Brazil, Russia and Thailand, one of the sources said.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford's decision, communicated to its suppliers in July, follows a similar move by General Motors <GM.N> to postpone the launch in India of a new $5 billion family of compact vehicles.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford is now planning to redesign the EcoSport, Figo and Figo Aspire in India in 2020-2021, according to two separate U.S. sources familiar with Ford's plans.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Its more ambitious B500 program, though, is on ice because of muted demand for some small and mid-sized hatchbacks and sedans in India and China, where SUVs and "crossovers" combining the hatchback and SUV have proved increasingly popular.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The cost of upgrading plants to produce the new cars would also be prohibitively high, the first sources said.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: All of the sources declined to be named as they have not been cleared to discuss the plans publicly.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford declined to comment on the development.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "We are constantly evaluating opportunities to better meet the needs of consumers and do not comment on speculation about future product programmes," a Ford spokesman said in a statement.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: SHIFT TO SUVS

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: That said, Ford has invested over $2 billion in India and plans to spend more to set up a global engineering center in the southern city of Chennai that will help tweak products for the local market and more swiftly adapt to changing consumer trends.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The carmaker is also ramping up exports, including to Europe, to maximize usage of its two plants in India.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "India is a key market for us in Asia Pacific," said the spokesman, adding that the carmaker is committed to introducing new products and technologies in the South Asian nation.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: But instead of the bigger plan for the key markets of India and China, Ford will focus on updating existing models and develop and build more SUVs and crossovers, moving away from sedans and hatchbacks, the U.S. sources said.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: That would allow the carmaker to boost profit margins.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "The global shift to crossovers makes competing in small cars a tough proposition for GM and Ford," said Sam Fiorani, vice president of global vehicle forecasting at U.S.-based AutoForecast Solutions.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: "It makes more sense for them to refresh older products now, harness lower development costs in China in the mid-term, and move toward small crossovers over the long haul."

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Chinese buyers have flocked to SUVs, as they grow wealthier and are often restricted to one vehicle in major cities, at the expense of contracting sedan sales.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: SUV sales rose 52 percent last year, although a glut of new model launches in the segment is already leading to discounts and lower margins.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Growing competition in the small SUV segment from local Chinese carmakers is also putting more pressure on pricing.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: SETBACK FOR "MAKE IN INDIA"

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: The retreat by Ford and GM is a setback for India's "Make in India" push to become a global manufacturing powerhouse, including in the auto sector.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Retooling the assembly line to build the B500 vehicles at Ford's plant in Gujarat, Prime Minister Narendra Modi's home state, would have meant an investment of more than $100 million and created manufacturing jobs as it cranked out more cars.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Ford and GM have struggled to crack emerging markets in Asia, where competition from Japanese, South Korean and now Chinese automakers is fierce.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: GM shut production in Indonesia owing to its modest market share, and Ford also plans to close its operations in the Southeast Asian nation, as well as in Japan and Australia.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Dearborn-based Ford is now looking at each country in the region in terms of long-term profitability opportunities, said another source familiar with Ford's plans, while noting India remains a tough place to make money.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: WASHINGTON — International Monetary Fund (IMF) managing director Ms Christine Lagarde said the institution will likely downgrade its 2016 global growth forecast yet again as economic prospects are dimmed by weak demand, as well as flagging trade and investment.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: In an interview with Reuters published on Friday (Sept 2), she said that G20 leaders need to do far more to spur demand, bolster the case for trade and globalisation, and fight growing inequality.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: And while some major threats to the global economy have yet to materialise, such as the feared recession from Britain’s vote to leave the European Union or a collapse in Chinese growth, she described the overall outlook as fragile, weak and certainly not fuelled by trade.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: “You could argue that Brexit is not really delivering the massive crisis that we had expected, you could argue that the Chinese transition is proceeding reasonably well, and you could argue that low commodity prices have gone up a little bit. However, when you look deep down at the economic growth prospects, at the growth potential, at the productivity, we are not getting very good signals, and we will probably be revising down our forecast for growth in 2016,” she warned.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: The IMF is due to revise its World Economic Outlook forecasts in early October ahead of its annual meetings with the World Bank. Another cut would be the IMF’s sixth straight growth markdown in about 18 months. Citing global uncertainty over the June 23 Brexit vote, the IMF had in July cut global gross domestic product growth estimates to 3.1 per cent for 2016 and 3.4 per cent for 2017 — down about a tenth of a point for each year.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: Ms Lagarde said she will warn G20 leaders meeting in Hangzhou in China on Sunday and Monday that further reductions in growth potential and more obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, capital and people would hurt all of their economies. She said people harmed by trade and innovation need to be helped by policies to allow them to retrain and acquire new skills and job mobility.

Headline: IMF likely to cut growth outlook again
Text: The IMF said in a briefing note to the G20 summit that falling trade volumes have contributed to lower GDP growth and urged them to make a stronger case for the benefits of trade. REUTERS

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: India's passenger car market, where sales rose 7 percent last fiscal year to 2.8 million units, is dominated by Maruti Suzuki <MRTI.NS> and Hyundai Motor Co <005380.KS> with their extensive line-up of cars and vast dealer networks.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Maruti and Hyundai control two-thirds of the market whereas Ford's share in India, set to be the world's third-largest car market by 2020, has stagnated at about 3 percent.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: Until Ford finalizes an alternative plan, the shift in strategy could leave gaps in its car portfolio in India, that today sits at the two ends of the price and size spectrum.

Headline: Ford shelves compact car program for emerging markets, setback for India
Text: In the meantime, Ford is increasing its focus on driving down costs by sourcing more parts locally and using more common features across models to achieve economies of scale. REUTERS

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: WASHINGTON - U.S. employment growth slowed more than expected in August after two straight months of robust gains and wages were tepid, which could effectively rule out an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve this month.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with hiring in manufacturing and construction sectors declining, the Labor Department said on Friday. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.9 percent as more people flocked to the labor market.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The report came on the heels of news on Thursday that the manufacturing sector contracted in August for the first time in six months, which had already cast a shadow on a rate hike at the Fed's Sept. 20-21 policy meeting.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Last month's jobs gains, however, could still be sufficient to push the U.S. central bank to tighten policy in December.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: "It reduces the likelihood that the Fed will raise rates in September, but the labor market remains strong enough to

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: support a rate hike in December," said John Silvia, chief economist at Wells Fargo Securities in Charlotte, North Carolina.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Economists had forecast payrolls increasing 180,000 last month and the unemployment rate slipping one-tenth of a percentage point to 4.8 percent. The payrolls rise reinforces views the economy has regained speed after almost stalling in the first half of the year.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Rate hike probabilities for both the September and December meetings rose after remarks last Friday by Fed Chair Janet Yellen that the case for raising rates had strengthened in recent months.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Financial markets on Friday were pricing in a roughly 21 percent chance of a rate hike this month and a 54.2 percent probability in December, according to the CME Fedwatch tool.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: A Reuters survey of the big banks that do business directly with the Fed showed 13 of the 14 so-called primary dealers expect a rate increase this year, with only three anticipating the move this month.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The Fed lifted its benchmark overnight interest rate at the end of last year for the first time in nearly a decade, but has held it steady since amid concerns over low inflation.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The dollar rose against a basket of currencies, while prices for U.S. government bonds fell. U.S. stocks ended higher.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Even though substantial labor market slack has been reduced, millions of Americans remain unemployed, a source of frustration that could weigh on the minds of some voters in the November presidential election.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's campaign team said the jobs numbers were a sign of a disappointing economic performance tied to what a senior campaign adviser called "Clinton globalist policies."

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: But the Democratic National Committee said the employment report was further proof of the sound economic policies of the Obama administration. The DNC said its presidential candidate, Hillary Clinton, was ready to build on that momentum and create an economy that "works for everyone, not just those at the top."

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: CALENDAR QUIRKS RESTRAIN PAYROLLS, WAGES

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The step-down in employment growth comes after the economy created a total of 546,000 jobs in June and July.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: With the labor market near full employment and the economy's recovery from the 2007-09 recession showing signs of aging, a slowdown in job growth is normal. According to Yellen, the economy needs to create just under 100,000 jobs a month to keep up with population growth.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The smaller-than-expected rise in payrolls also likely reflects difficulties adjusting the data for seasonal fluctuations related to school calendars. Over the last several years, the government's initial August payrolls estimates have been weak only to be subsequently revised higher.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: "As the August numbers have tended to come in on the softer side in the past, we think that this mostly reflects seasonal adjustment problems rather than underlying weakness," said Harm Bandholz, chief economist at UniCredit Research in New York.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The timing of the next rate hike could also be determined by wage growth. Average hourly earnings increased three cents or 0.1 percent in August after a solid 0.3 percent rise in July.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The moderation in gains, which reflects a calendar quirk, pulled down the year-on-year gain to 2.4 percent from an upwardly revised 2.7 percent in July, which was the largest rise in seven years.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Americans worked fewer hours last month, with the average workweek dipping 0.1 hour to 34.3 hours. Other details of the report showed the labor force participation rate, or the share of working-age Americans who are employed or at least looking for a job, unchanged at 62.8 percent last month.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The participation rate remains near multi-decade lows, in part reflecting demographic changes, partially explaining why wage growth has been sluggish.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Still, the payrolls gain added to July consumer spending, residential construction and durable goods orders in suggesting a pickup in economic growth after output rose 1.0 percent in the first half of the year.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: A second report from the Commerce Department on Friday showed the trade deficit fell 11.6 percent to $39.5 billion in July as soybean sales buoyed exports to a 10-month high, in another boost to the growth outlook for the third quarter.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: The Atlanta Fed is forecasting gross domestic product rising at a 3.5 percent annual rate in the third quarter.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Last month, manufacturing sector employment fell 14,000 after rising for two straight months. Construction payrolls slipped 6,000, while mining shed a further 4,000 jobs in August.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Professional and business services added 22,000 jobs last month after creating 80,000 positions in July. Retail sector employment increased by 15,100 jobs and payrolls in the leisure and hospitality sector rose 29,000.

Headline: Slower U.S. payrolls growth dims September Fed rate hike prospects
Text: Temporary-help jobs, a harbinger of future hiring, fell 3,100. Government payrolls rose 25,000 in August, extending the streak of job gains in the public sector to four months. REUTERS

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: SINGAPORE — All three telcos in Singapore have stopped sales of Samsung’s Galaxy Note7, after the South Korean company announced a global recall following reports of faulty batteries causing its latest flagship smartphone to catch fire.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Singtel, Singapore’s biggest telco, said on Friday (Sept 2): “Following official notification from Samsung, Singtel has suspended sales of Galaxy Note7 devices. We are working with Samsung on an exchange programme for customers who have purchased the device. We will keep our customers closely updated.” Likewise, StarHub and M1 said they have stopped sales in line with Samsung’s global halt and will provide updates on phone exchanges later.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: The Galaxy Note7, which was launched in Singapore on Aug 20, has been wildly popular with Android users who flocked to pre-order the device at the three major telcos, Samsung Experience stores, major consumer electronics stores Best Denki, Courts, Gain City, Hachi, and Harvey Norman as well as Lazada Singapore.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: However, a Samsung spokesperson told TODAY that “Samsung is unable to share any figures on Note7 units sold in Singapore”.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Reports have emerged worldwide of the Galaxy Note7 catching fire during charging, with several people posting images and videos of their charred devices online. The smartphone has been launched in 10 countries so far and Samsung said there have been 35 cases globally as of Thursday.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Samsung said it conducted a thorough investigation and found a battery problem but added it was “inappropriate to comment at this time which manufacturer’s battery cells were faulty”.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: “We are currently conducting a thorough inspection with our suppliers to identify possible affected batteries in the market. However, because our customers’ safety is an absolute priority at Samsung, we have stopped sales of the Galaxy Note7,” the company said. Customers who have bought the Note7 could get it replaced with a new one in the coming weeks, and instructions on the replacement process will be announced next week.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: “We acknowledge the inconvenience this may cause in the market but this is to ensure that Samsung continues to deliver the highest quality products to our customers. We are working closely with our partners to ensure the replacement experience is as convenient and efficient as possible,” the company said. Samsung did not reveal how many Galaxy Note7 phones will be recalled but said it would replace all phones sold to customers as well as retailers.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: The Galaxy Note7 recall is a blow to Samsung’s reputation and robs the company of momentum it had built in smartphones by capitalising on a lull in demand for Apple devices between new iPhone models.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Demand for the iris-reading Note7, which debuted to glowing reviews, and the release of the company’s biggest profit in two years had driven its share price to a record as analysts raised their price targets.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Shares of Samsung closed 0.6 per cent higher at 1,597,000 won on Friday before the recall was announced.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: “The unexpected recall would surely irritate buyers and the latest incident looks worrisome,” said Mr Lee Seung-woo, an analyst at IBK Securities in Seoul. He expects shipments of the Galaxy Note7 this year will shrink to 12 million units from a previous estimate of 14 million. He estimates the total number of handsets affected by the battery problem to be one million, with about 600,000 units sold outside South Korea.

Headline: Singtel, StarHub, M1 stop Samsung Galaxy Note7 sales after global recall
Text: Rival smartphone maker Apple has invited journalists to an event in San Francisco on Wednesday, where the world’s most valuable public company is expected to introduce next-generation versions of the iPhone and Apple Watch. AGENCIES

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: DETROIT - Volkswagen AG <VOWG_p.DE> said on Thursday it has filed an appeal of a federal labor board decision on its dispute with the United Auto Workers union in Tennessee to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The National Labor Relations board on Aug. 26 sided with the UAW in the union's effort to get VW to negotiate wages and benefits for about 160 of the 1,500 hourly workers at a VW plant in Chattanooga, Tennessee.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: Thursday's filing was expected. The NLRB decision for the UAW in the dispute was highly anticipated, and VW had previously said it would appeal if the ruling went against the German-based company.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The union sought to represent only a portion of the plant's workers after it in February 2014 narrowly lost an election to represent all 1,500 hourly workers at the Chattanooga plant.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: In December 2015, the union handily won the right to represent about 160 skilled trades workers who maintain machinery at the plant.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The UAW has never been able to win an organizing vote at a foreign-owned auto assembly plant in the U.S. south. A victory, even for only a portion of workers at the VW plant, would give the union a stronger foothold in the south, where most foreign-owned auto plants are located.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: On Thursday, VW said in a statement that it "respects the right of all of our employees to decide the question of union representation. This is why we disagree with the decision to separate Volkswagen maintenance and production workers and will continue our effort to allow everyone to vote as one group on the matter of union representation."

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: UAW Secretary-Treasurer Gary Casteel said in a statement on Thursday evening that the union is "disappointed that Volkswagen is continuing to thumb its nose at the federal government. The federal courts have consistently upheld the NLRB labor standard that enabled the skilled-trades vote in Chattanooga."

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: The UAW has for several years been assisted in its effort to organize workers in Tennessee by the powerful German union IG Metall, which has members on the VW Supervisory Board.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: Earlier on Thursday, the head of IG Metall, Joerg Hofman, demanded that VW enter talks with the UAW-represented workers.

Headline: VW appeals labor board decision on UAW with federal court
Text: IG Metall in a statement said that Hofman "is calling for VW to no longer act contrary to American labor law, and to seek talks with UAW without delay." REUTERS

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: WASHINGTON - Years of stubbornly low interest rates and expectations they will remain low for years to come have prompted U.S. banks to shift their balance sheets in ways that put them at risk if rates suddenly spike, regulators are warning.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Banks have been stocking up on long-term loans, often tied to real estate and property development that promise higher yields than the miniscule returns on short-term debt.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: However, the widening gap between long-term loans and mostly short-term funding means higher interest rates could trap banks in a corner: forcing them to pay more to cover their immediate financing needs than they earn on their loans.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The dynamic "raises the interest rate risk issue that we are very focused on," Martin Gruenberg, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation(FDIC), said this week.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Banks are broadly positioned according to the signals the Federal Reserve has been sending — that it will lift rates only gradually and spread the increases over a long period.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Regulators point out, though, that central banks can move quickly too, even if that now appears unlikely. Short-term rates could also climb in a weakening economy, they say.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "(There) could be impacts on the economy apart from monetary policy," Gruenberg said.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The Office of Financial Research, an independent watchdog within the Treasury Department, says banks could be tested by a surprise upheaval like the recent Brexit vote.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "Investors (are) open to heavy losses from large jumps in interest rates, whether from surprises in the Federal Reserve's monetary policy or other shocks," the OFR wrote in a recent report.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency also counts interest rate risk among market perils.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: This week, Boston Fed president Eric Rosengren warned that banks might already be too exposed to long-term, commercial real estate that could sour and hit the broader economy.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: The savings and loan crisis of the 1980s and the early 1990s was the most prominent U.S. example how a spike in short-term rates could wreak havoc in the financial industry.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: When the Fed pushed its benchmark rate above 19 percent in the early 1980s, many lenders switched to riskier credits to keep up with a spike in costs. Those loans later soured and contributed to the collapse of hundreds of lenders.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Most recently, banks got a glimpse of the risks of rate swings in June 2013 when then-Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke suggested that the central bank could start scaling back its government debt purchases. As bond yields whipsawed in response, banks saw their long term assets briefly lose billions of dollars in value.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Even so, banks have been extending the duration of their loans since the Fed pegged its rates near zero in late 2008, assuming that rates will stay low for some time.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: FDIC data shows roughly a quarter of the loans on bank balance sheets will not mature for at least five years – a record level - and many lenders remain comfortable offering long-term loans to bolster earnings. (Graphic: http://tmsnrt.rs/2bnEjZA)

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "We are relatively convinced that we may not be this low forever, but...our expectation is lower for longer," Wells Fargo's finance chief, John Shrewsberry, said last month.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Regulators do not require banks to set aside capital for potential losses if interest rates rise and let them use their own models to calcuate risks, so approaches vary across the industry.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: While JPMorgan Chase & Co <JPM.N>, the nation's largest lender, has lately increased its protection against rising rates, Bank of America Corp <BAC.N>, the nation's No. 2 lender, has been steadily paring it back.(Graphic: http://tmsnrt.rs/2bVLmXk)

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: CRYING WOLF?

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Analysts say it is difficult to tell whether regulators see risks that banks do not or whether they are just doing their job - worrying about a threat that may never materialize.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Government-backed lenders, though, have also been nudging banks to better prepare for eventual rate hikes.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: "We've had eight years of low rates. And the bank model - relying on core deposits - has not been tested," said Robert Dozier of the Federal Home Loan Bank of Atlanta.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: Analysts point to Bank of America as a lender bearing the brunt of low rates.

Headline: U.S. banks need better defenses against rates shock, regulators warn
Text: But as the bank has delved deeper into long-term assets, the lender has shrunk its book of certain interest rate derivatives to below $400 billion from $1 trillion in the last three years, according to FDIC data. Bank of America says that any hit it takes on a rate spike would quickly be offset by new loans made at higher rates.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: ALPBACH, Austria - Multinationals like coffee chain Starbucks <SBUX.O> and online retailer Amazon <AMZN.O> pay less tax in Austria than one of the country's tiny sausage stands, the republic's center-left chancellor lamented in an interview published on Friday.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: Chancellor Christian Kern, head of the Social Democrats and of the centrist coalition government, also criticized internet giants Google <GOOGL.O> and Facebook <FB.O>, saying that if they paid more tax subsidies for print media could increase.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "Every Viennese cafe, every sausage stand pays more tax in Austria than a multinational corporation," Kern was quoted as saying in an interview with newspaper Der Standard, invoking two potent symbols of the Austrian capital's food culture.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "That goes for Starbucks, Amazon and other companies," he said, praising the European Commission's ruling this week that Apple <AAPL.O> should pay up to 13 billion euros ($14.5 billion) in taxes plus interest to Ireland because a special scheme to route profits through that country was illegal state aid.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: Apple has said it will appeal the ruling, which Chief Executive Tim Cook described as "total political crap". Google, Facebook and other multinational companies say they follow all tax rules.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: Kern criticized EU states with low-tax regimes that have lured multinationals - and come under scrutiny from Brussels.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "What Ireland, the Netherlands, Luxembourg or Malta are doing here lacks solidarity towards the rest of the European economy," he said.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: He stopped short of saying that Facebook and Google would have to pay more tax but underlined their significant sales in Austria, which he estimated at more than 100 million euros each, and their relatively small numbers of employees - a "good dozen" for Google and "allegedly even fewer" for Facebook.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: "They massively suck up the advertising volume that comes out of the economy but pay neither corporation tax nor advertising duty in Austria," said Kern, who became chancellor in May.

Headline: Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Starbucks, Amazon pay less tax than a sausage stand, Austria says
Text: ($1 = 0.8965 euros) REUTERS

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: SEOUL - Samsung Electronics Co Ltd has recalled all Galaxy Note 7 smartphones equipped with batteries it has found to be fire-prone and halted their sales in 10 markets, denting a revival of the firm's mobile business.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Koh Dong-jin, head of the South Korean company's smartphone business, declined to comment on how many phones needed to be replaced, but said Samsung had sold 2.5 million of the premium devices so far.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Speaking at a news conference on Friday, Koh expressed regret over the recall, which will affect markets including South Korea and the United States. Models in China feature a different battery and are not being recalled by Samsung, the world's biggest smartphone vendor.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The recall comes just over two weeks after the company launched its latest premium phone, which features an outsized screen and high-resolution camera. It follows reports of the 988,900 won ($885) phone igniting while charging.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The manufacturer plans to replace not only phones with faulty batteries sold to consumers, but also retailer inventories and units in transit. Nomura estimated that more than 1 million units have been sold to end consumers.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: "I can't comment on exactly how much the cost will be, but it pains my heart that it will be such a big number," Koh said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: Strategy Analytics said the combined cost of the recall and lost sales would lop $5 billion off Samsung's smartphone revenue this year and cut smartphone profit margin by 1.5 percent.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The scale of the recall is unprecedented for Samsung, which prides itself on its manufacturing prowess. While recalls in the smartphone industry do happen, including for rival Apple Inc, the nature of the problem for the Galaxy Note 7 is a serious blow to Samsung's reputation, analysts said.

Headline: Samsung recalls Galaxy Note 7 phones after battery fires
Text: The company should act quickly to minimize damage to its smartphone recovery, after a string of product successes had reversed a fall in market share, they added.
