Text: Samsung had said on Wednesday it stopped supplying the new smartphone to South Korea's top three carriers and was delaying shipments for additional quality control inspections following claims from some users that their phone caught fire while charging. REUTERS

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: PARIS - Louis Vuitton has launched its first perfume range since the founding merger of its parent LVMH <LVMH.PA> in 1987, targeting middle-income shoppers amid a downturn in luxury spending.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: This week's launch is an important step for the French brand as it tries to strike the delicate balance between increasing its number of more affordable goods while retaining its cachet.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Until now, shoppers on more modest incomes have only been catered for by Louis Vuitton's key chains and very small leather goods, costing around 200-300 euros apiece.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: But the brand needs to boost sales growth after a sharp slowdown in the past three years, and with little sign of an industry recovery as security fears and geo-political uncertainty hit the tourism flows vital for luxury brands.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Louis Vuitton's collection of seven perfumes, with names including "turbulences" and "matiere noire" or "dark matter," are on sale for around 200 euros ($224) for a 100 ml bottle.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: That is close to the price of niche perfume brands such as By Kilian, which have been enjoying sales growth four to five times higher than big, traditional fragrance providers whose prices cost under 100 euros.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Perfume has been more resilient to the industry downturn than some parts of the luxury market, with global sales estimated to have risen 2.9 percent to about 15 billion euros last year. Within that, sales by niche brands jumped about 15 percent to around 1 billion euros.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: At first, Louis Vuitton will sell the perfumes in only about 180 of its 460 stores. Analysts estimate they could generate 60-80 million euros of sales in the first year.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: By comparison, luxury giants such as Chanel and LVMH's Dior, whose products are much more widely distributed, make about 2.5 billion euros a year from perfumes and cosmetics.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Louis Vuitton, which declined to say how much it has invested in the project, gave star industry "nose" Jacques Cavallier-Belletrud four years to prepare the launch.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: The perfumer, who worked for decades with fragrance producer Firmenich, created many commercially successful perfumes including L'Eau d'Issey for Issey Miyake and L'Oreal's <OREP.PA> Poeme for Lancome and Acqua di Gio for Armani.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Some industry analysts said Louis Vuitton took its time with the launch partly out of concern the move could exacerbate its ubiquity problem - the result of having opened too many shops, which dented its perceived exclusivity.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: Since 2012, the brand has worked to remedy this by putting the brakes on expansion and elevating its market positioning by producing more expensive handbags, with many available only in limited numbers.

Headline: Louis Vuitton targets middle-income shoppers with perfume launch
Text: ($1 = 0.8912 euros) REUTERS

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: RIO DE JANEIRO - Federal prosecutors in Brazil rejected a $328.2 million (247.34 million pounds) deal on Thursday allowing Dutch oil-ship lesser SBM Offshore NV <SBMO.AS> to avoid prosecution for corruption related to its contracts with state-led oil company Petrobras.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The decision was made by a federal prosecutor review board, which said numerous problems needed to be addressed before the deal could be approved.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: SBM officials did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The deal failed to provide authorities with enough data, documents and other information to assist in further investigations of corruption at Petrobras, the board said.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: A series of widening investigations that began in 2014 have shown that Petrobras <PETR4.SA> officials conspired with major contractors to fix prices or arrange bribes, in a sweeping kickback scheme that has engulfed a vast swath of Brazil's political class and business elites.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: SBM, was one of the first companies to get caught up in the scandal.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: SBM is the largest lesser of floating oil production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessels. The company has been accused of paying bribes to officials of Petroleo Brasileiro SA <PETR4.SA>, or Petrobras to win FPSO lease contracts.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: Petrobras operates the largest fleet of FPSOs in the world. Without the deal, Petrobras might be forced to cancel contracts with SBM that could cut output by 15 percent between 2016 and 2020 and cost Petrobras $12.7 billion in revenue, Brazil's transparency, regulation and control ministry (TRCM), said in a statement on Thursday.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The deal rejected on Thursday, known as a lenience accord, was completed in negotiations between SBM and the TRCM in July. It offered SBM immunity from prosecution in exchange for an admission of guilt, the provision of information and evidence that could help further an ongoing corruption investigation at Petrobras.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: It also included a $163 million fine, of which Petrobras will receive $149.2 million. Petrobras would be further compensated by SBM reducing the value of its contracts by $179 million. Another $13.6 million would be paid to prosecutors to help finance additional corruption investigations.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The review panel said prosecutors were giving up too much in exchange for the fines to be paid by SBM. It also said the company had been more forthcoming with prosecutors in the United States and Europe about crimes in Brazil than it had with authorities in the South American country.

Headline: Brazil prosecutors reject SBM leniency deal for Petrobras graft
Text: The board sent the deal back to prosecutors in Rio de Janeiro, where Petrobras is based. REUTERS

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: DETROIT - U.S. auto sales fell 4.2 percent in August as some major automakers said a long-expected decline due to softer consumer demand had begun, possibly sparking a shift to juicer customer incentives and slower production.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: The top three sellers, General Motors Co <GM.N>, Ford Motor Co <F.N> and Toyota Motor Corp <7203.T><TM.N> on Thursday reported declines of at least 5 percent.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Of the seven top manufacturers by sales, only Fiat Chrysler Automobiles <FCAU.N><FCHA.MI> reported a gain versus a year ago, when sales were restated to about 11,000 fewer than originally reported.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Monthly spending on new cars and trucks is closely watched as the U.S. auto industry accounts for about one-fifth of U.S. retail sales.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: August sales, said Autodata Corp, totaled 1.51 million vehicles, or 16.98 million vehicles at a seasonally adjusted annualized rate, versus a surprisingly strong 17.88 million vehicles in July.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Ford Chief Economist Bryan Bezold said sales had hit a plateau after steadily rising following the 2008-2009 recession. The auto industry outperformed the overall U.S. economy in those years largely due to pent-up demand that has now played out, he said.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Wall Street has pressured automaker shares all year amid expectations of falling sales at some point.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: GM shares dipped 0.4 percent while Ford was off 1.4 percent in afternoon trading. Fiat Chrysler dropped 1.2 percent in New York trading.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: In late July, Ford was the first major automaker to confirm the lofty sales gains achieved since 2010 were at an end, even though they are still about 65 percent higher than the lowest sales year in 2009.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Mark LaNeve, Ford's U.S. sales chief, said on Thursday the company will ring up fewer sales in 2017 than this year. Results in 2016 are expected to fall short of last year's record high sales of 17.47 million vehicles, according to Autodata.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: GM on Thursday forecast 2016 sales at 17.3 million vehicles.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Ford, whose sales tumbled 8.4 percent, said its U.S. inventory was at 81 days of supply versus 61 days a year earlier, suggesting Ford may have to cut production, increase profit-eroding incentives, or boost fleet sales.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: "Now the automakers' focus will shift from simple growth to market share and managing inventories," said analyst Karl Brauer of Kelley Blue Book. "The use of incentives and fleet sales as a counter to plateauing retail sales will be the statistics to watch going forward.”

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Ford's LaNeve said the company will manage supply with demand, but when asked if production will be slowed or plants shut down to accomplish that goal, he declined to say.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: The trend toward SUVs and trucks and away from sedans and hatchbacks continued in August. Autodata figures show passenger car sales fell 12.6 percent while SUV and truck sales rose 2.4 percent.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: While GM said this year's sales will not top results of 2015, the slide was moderate, and results remained sharply above those in the 2008-2009 recession and in the years immediately after.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: “All the economic factors continue to point toward a strong second half of the year and another potential record year for the industry,” said Mustafa Mohatarem, GM’s chief economist.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Sales of the No. 1 selling model in the United States, the Ford F-Series pickup truck, fell 6 percent, but Ford said retail sales for the trucks were robust.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Retail sales cover individuals and are generally more lucrative than volume fleet sales to rental car agencies, businesses and government. Rental car sales are particularly low-profit.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: GM has boasted all year that it has significantly cut its sales to rental agencies. However, GM's retail sales fell about 5 percent, in line with its wider total sales decline.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Fiat Chrysler said in July it has revised more than five years of monthly U.S. vehicle sales figures amid a U.S. investigation into claims of inflated figures.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Nissan Motor Co <7201.T> sales were off 6.5 percent, but its Rogue midsize SUV saw a rise of 19 percent.

Headline: August U.S. auto sales fall; carmakers say industry has peaked
Text: Honda Motor Co <7267.T> was down 3.8 percent as Accord sales tumbled 26 percent. Honda-brand car sales fell 10 percent overall while truck and SUV sales rose 4.5 percent. REUTERS

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: LONDON - Investors pulled billions of dollars out of cash in the latest week and turned towards an array of bond funds and equities -- notably bank stocks -- ahead of the keenly awaited August U.S. employment report, Bank of America Merrill Lynch said on Friday.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Precious metals funds suffered their biggest weekly outflow of the year as expectations of higher U.S. interest rates by the end of the year strengthened, BAML said.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Flows into emerging market bond funds reached record levels in the week ending Aug. 31, while European equity funds chalked up a record-breaking 30th consecutive weekly outflow.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Economists expect non-farm payrolls report later on Friday to show 180,000 new jobs were created last month, a dip in the unemployment rate and continued wage growth. A strong report could set the seal on the Federal Reserve raising rates in December, maybe even before.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: "Banks are back," BAML said in a note titled "Banking on Payrolls".

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Financial equity funds drew in $1.2 billion, the biggest inflow in 10 months, although BAML cautioned that a stubbornly flat U.S. yield curve has yet to confirm a cyclical upturn in the sector.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Banks profit from a steeper yield curve, when the gap between long-term and short-term yields widens. The opposite, a flattening curve, is generally bad for banks and the U.S. curve is currently around its flattest since late 2007.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Money market funds posted an outflow of $16.7 billion in the week to Aug. 31, and precious metals funds an outflow of $600 million.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Investors pulled $1.1 billion out of European equity funds, marking the 30th consecutive weekly redemption, although the pace of outflows is slowing, BAML said.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Stocks in general, however, posted an inflow of $1.8 billion, led by U.S. and emerging market funds.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: So far this year, investors have withdrawn $132.3 billion from developed market equity funds, while emerging market stock funds are up $2.2 billion.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: In fixed income, emerging market bond funds attracted investment for a record ninth week in a row, although the $700 million inflow was the lowest in that time.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Investment grade corporate bond funds attracted a $2.3 billion inflow, the 25th inflow out of the past 26 weeks, while government bond funds posted their eighth consecutive outflow.

Headline: Bank stocks are back as investors dash from cash: BAML
Text: Bond funds in total have posted a net inflow of $148.6 billion so far this year, BAML said. REUTERS

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: SINGAPORE/HONG KONG/CHICAGO - U.S. financial regulators gave over-the-counter (OTC) swap dealers an extra month to comply with new derivatives trading rules set to take effect on Thursday, after Asia's market ground to a near halt due to uncertainty about changes that could increase global funding costs by more than $500 billion.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The rules directly affect U.S. and Japanese banks, which will be required to post and collect collateral or "margin" against OTC trades, a development set to dramatically raise the cost of trading in the $500 trillion global swaps market.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) said it will not pursue disciplinary action before Oct. 3 against swap dealers that do not meet new requirements because some were unable to make necessary arrangements in time for Thursday's deadline. The agency said the delay was appropriate when dealers were making "diligent, good faith implementation efforts."

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: CFTC staff have heard that small and foreign dealers in particular, need more time, Chairman Timothy Massad said in a statement. They believe that "this situation has improved in the last few days,‎ and that the largest dealers may no longer face significant issues," he said.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Two groups representing swap dealers, the International Swaps and Derivatives Association and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association, had requested the delay.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Regulators in Europe, Singapore, Hong Kong and Australia also recently delayed the implementation of margin rules amid fears their banks were not ready, a move some experts said has created an uneven playing field. India said it was delaying its margin rules on Thursday.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Priya Misra, head of global rates strategy at TD Securities in New York, said the CFTC's delay "might help smooth out some of the market dislocations that could have happened" if U.S. regulators had stuck to their original deadline.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: "Every client I spoke with was concerned about the impact of these rules on liquidity and bid-ask in the affected markets, particularly swaptions or cross-currency basis swaps," Misra told Reuters.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Traders and market insiders earlier told Reuters that some major banks in Asia had halted dealing in a range of OTC derivatives products, including foreign exchange non-deliverable forwards (NDFs) and interest rate swaps. They were not yet able to comply with the rules, first proposed by global regulators following the 2007-09 financial crisis, traders said.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: "There is a lot of confusion," said one interest rates trader in Singapore. "The margining is an issue. The big banks are covered under that rule, and some of them don't yet have systems and the back-end documentation processes in place."

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: 'REGULATORY ARBITRAGE'

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Following the financial crisis, global regulators drew up rules to increase transparency and reduce risks in the OTC derivatives market, which was largely responsible for the collapse of Lehman Brothers and bringing insurance giant AIG to its knees.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: These included pushing some OTC trades onto exchange-like platforms and through clearing houses, which guarantee payment in the event either party defaults.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The margin rules aim to secure trades that are too complex or illiquid for exchanges and clearing houses to handle. The global cost of funding the margin rules is likely to ultimately exceed $500 billion, according to U.S and European regulators.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Large U.S. and Japanese banks have been scrambling to prepare for the first phase of the margin rules, which require changes to risk models, legal documents, and custody arrangements.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: The new rules will not be enforced in Europe until mid-2017, after the European Commission announced earlier this year that it would delay implementation.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: In practice, European banks had been working toward the Sept. 1 U.S. and Japanese deadline, according to the International Swaps and Derivatives Association.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: Still, banks from Europe, Singapore, Hong Kong and Australia have stopped trading OTC products with U.S. and Japanese banks, lest they are forced to post collateral to trade with them, said Kishore Ramakrishnan, a director at PricewaterhouseCoopers Consulting in Hong Kong.

Headline: U.S. gives swap dealers more time on margin rules, Asia trading stumbles
Text: "This regulatory arbitrage won't change until we have a level regulatory playing field next summer," Ramakrishnan said. REUTERS

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: SINGAPORE — Manufacturing activity in the Republic shrank for the 14th straight month in August, although the pace of contraction slowed as the electronics sector posted its first expansion in more than a year.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: The Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) came in at 49.8 last month, 0.5 point higher than in July, showed data from the Singapore Institute of Purchasing and Materials Management. The 50-point mark separates expansion and contraction. The improvement was due to higher new orders and new exports, as well as higher factory output and employment.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: The electronics sub-index — which contributes to one-third of the Republic’s manufacturing performance — expanded for the first time since June last year, increasing 0.5 point from the previous month to 50.2, due to higher new orders, new export orders and factory output.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: “Previously, the electronics sector was a drag to overall manufacturing but now it is actually helping … while the other sectors continue to be challenging,” said Mr Song Seng Wun, CIMB Private Banking economist.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: “Typically the electronics industry tends to lead the broader manufacturing sector, so the electronics PMI’s return to expansion territory, if sustained over the coming months, would definitely be a welcome signal,” said Ms Selena Ling, head of treasury research & strategy, OCBC Bank.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: Despite the life seen in electronics, economists still view the broad picture for manufacturing as difficult, due to soft global demand.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: Regionally, PMIs are a mixed bag. Last month, the PMIs for Vietnam, India, Taiwan stayed in the expansion zone, while Malaysia and Thailand contracted.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: The private sector Caixin/Markit Chinese manufacturing PMI, which focuses on small- and medium-sized firms, dropped 0.6 point from July to 50 points. The official Chinese PMI, which mostly covers larger state-owned manufacturers, improved 0.5 point from the previous month to 50.4 points.

Headline: Manufacturing activity contracts for 14th month
Text: “Overall, the manufacturing sector remains challenging,” said Mr Song. “We are essentially faced with a difficult operating environment where external demand remains soft. Generally, Asian PMIs improved slightly but just marginally. China is still fairly uninspiring in manufacturing activities.” ANGELA TENG

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: SINGAPORE — The share prices of M1, StarHub and Singtel plummeted on Friday (Sept 2) after the Infocomm Development Authority (IDA) announced on Thursday it had received formal expressions of interest from three companies to become Singapore’s fourth mobile carrier.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: Shares in M1, which is especially vulnerable to a new player as its business model is the least diversified, fell as much as 6.8 per cent, while StarHub shares shed as much as 4.7 per cent and Singtel shares lost up to 3.3 per cent. Analysts said the plunge in the share prices was bigger than expected considering that preparations had been made for a fourth telco for some time.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “I think the market is overreacting a little. This (possibility for a fourth telco) is nothing really new; the news yesterday means it’s getting closer to a firm deal,” said Ms Margaret Yang, market analyst at CMC Markets Singapore. “As the news spreads, the selling could last for a couple of days. But eventually it would reach a balance point when people feel it’s oversold. It cannot fall forever.”

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: However, another analyst said the larger number of interested parties and the entrance of Australian stock exchange-listed TPG Telecom into the fray were key factors in the sell-off.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “The share reaction is justified as the three incumbent telcos’ share prices were bid up due to expectations that the potential bidders may fail to raise sufficient funding. The announcement of three bidders, which is more than expected, is also a surprise to investors. The bid from Australia-based TPG is especially surprising. That explained the sharp fall in share prices,” said Mr Bernard Aw, market strategist at financial services firm IG.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: At the close of trading on Friday, M1 shares were down 5.6 per cent at S$2.51, while StarHub shares lost 4.4 per cent to S$3.47 and Singtel shares fell 2.5 per cent to S$3.87.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: The IDA is looking to increase competition in the mobile services market and has said that a new entrant is likely to bring about a wider variety of innovative services and more competitive offerings to consumers.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: On Thursday, the IDA announced that MyRepublic, newly formed company airYotta, and TPG Telecom submitted their expressions of interest to become the fourth mobile operator in Singapore. A spectrum auction to determine the fourth mobile telco is expected by October, with the winning bidder rolling out its services as early as April next year.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “The introduction of a fourth telco is expected to shake up the stagnant and complacent sector. If the new competition is able to force the existing telcos to improve their offerings and services while keeping prices affordable and competitive, this is positive for consumers,” said Mr Aw.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: Analysts told TODAY they foresee competition among the incumbent telcos to intensify in the near term, with M1 to be the most affected by a new player and Singtel to be the least affected. “The cake will be cut by four, so everybody might get a smaller share ... Among these three players, M1 is relatively a small player and so is more susceptible to rising competition in this sector. For Singtel, more than 70 per cent (of its earnings) is from overseas, so it is less susceptible to a fourth telco player in the market,” said CMC Markets’ Ms Yang.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: M1 and StarHub said they are prepared for the upcoming competition, while Singtel declined to comment.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “M1 is not new to competition, and we will continue to compete to protect our market share,” said a company spokesperson.

Headline: Telco shares plunge as 4th mobile carrier looms
Text: “We’re always prepared for competition. Regardless of the number of operators in this saturated market, StarHub will keep our focus on ensuring our offerings remain attractive and relevant,” said a StarHub spokesperson.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: BERLIN - Germany's Transport Ministry has asked the European Commission to investigate exhaust emissions of Fiat Chrysler <FCHA.MI> vehicles for potential illegal manipulation devices, German government documents showed on Thursday.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: Germany's motor vehicle authority KBA began testing the vehicles of several manufacturers, including Fiat, after Volkswagen's <VOWG_p.DE> admission in September last year that it had cheated emissions tests with motor-management software.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: The direct approach to the European Union executive comes after the German transport ministry raised concerns over Fiat vehicles with Italian authorities earlier this year and a subsequent rejection by Italian authorities of claims that Fiat and Chrysler vehicles used illegal exhaust manipulation devices.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: This week's letter to the European Commission, which was seen by Reuters, said that tests by German authorities on the Fiat 500X, Fiat Doblo and Jeep Renegade could prove the "illegal use of a device to switch off exhaust treatment systems" and urged the Commission to consult with Italian authorities to resolve the issue.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: A Fiat spokeswoman said on Thursday that the company's cars conform to current emissions rules and do not contain defeat devices.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: The Commission, meanwhile, said that it is the responsibility of the Italian authorities to remedy wrongdoings.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: "It is first and foremost a dialogue between the two member states concerned, with an obligation to keep the Commission informed and the possibility for the Commission to facilitate a solution if no agreement can be found," the Commission said in a statement.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: A source at the Italian infrastructure ministry, which includes the national motor vehicle authority, said Italy had not received any communication from the German government on the matter.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: The source said Italian tests had shown Fiat 500 cars conformed to emissions rules and did not contain defeat devices, adding that the KBA had never said it disagreed with Italy's findings.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: As part of a widening clampdown on health-threatening nitrogen oxide (NOx) pollution levels in the wake of the VW scandal, the KBA tested 53 different vehicles and found that carmakers were making liberal use of what they described as a “thermal window”.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: This refers to the time when carmakers are allowed to throttle back exhaust emissions management systems to protect engines from potential damage from condensation when cars are started in very cold conditions.

Headline: Germany goes to EU with accusation of Fiat emissions cheating
Text: During their investigations, the KBA found that a very wide range of temperatures was used by carmakers for thermal windows. REUTERS

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: NEW YORK - Verizon Communications Inc <VZ.N> said on Thursday that its chief financial officer, Francis Shammo, plans to retire at the end of the year and will step down from his role on Nov. 1.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: Verizon said its board of directors appointed Matthew D. Ellis, who is currently senior vice president and CFO-operations finance, to succeed Shammo.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: Shammo, 55, will be leaving after 27 years with the company.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: He joined Verizon's predecessor company, Bell Atlantic, in 1989 and became Verizon CFO in 2010.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: During his tenure, Verizon agreed to pay $130 billion to buy Vodafone Group's stake in Verizon Wireless. It also acquired AOL Inc, the owner of the Huffington Post and TechCrunch, last year and agreed to buy web pioneer Yahoo Inc <YHOO.O> for $4.8 billion in July.

Headline: Verizon CFO Shammo to retire at the end of 2016
Text: Ellis, 45, joined Verizon in 2013 after 15 years at Tyson Foods Inc <TSN.N> in various roles. REUTERS

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: SINGAPORE — Businesses and other entities such as non-profit organisations and associations will be able to use a single corporate digital identity instead of multiple login IDs to perform e-Government transactions when the Singapore Corporate Access (CorpPass) is launched on September 15.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: To be rolled out in phases till the end of 2017, the CorpPass portal will progressively replace SingPass, Easy (E-Services Authorisation System) and agency-issued login IDs for local entities with a Unique Entity Number (UEN) and foreign entities who wish to access Government-to-business e-services in Singapore.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: More than 200 government digital services managed by about 60 government agencies will require CorpPass as a login method by December 2017. The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore, Ministry of Trade and Industry, National Environment Agency and Singapore Customs will be in the first phase.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: Individuals (e.g. taxi drivers, hawkers) and local entities (e.g. trust funds, joint ventures) without an UEN will be able to continue to use their SingPass to transact with the Government.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: CorpPass was set up in response to feedback from employees that SingPass should be used for personal transactions, and not corporate transactions. Concerns were raised over the sharing of SingPass ID accounts of individuals for performing business transactions like filing corporate tax.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: With CorpPass, employers will be able appoint administrators to oversee the services without sharing their personal SingPass accounts. Access can also be set by the employer on specific digital services per user.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: Mr Chan Cheow Hoe, assistant chief executive, Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore, said: “CorpPass marks the first time that the Government is rolling out a single corporate digital identity.

Headline: Businesses to access e-govt services via CorpPass
Text: “This creates opportunities for even more services and transactions to be provided online conveniently and securely. More than 1,500 business users have successfully registered and activated their CorpPass accounts since our trial started in April this year. We encourage businesses to sign up early for CorpPass as this will be a required login method for most Government digital services by end of next year.” Angela Teng

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: Former shareholders of Good Technology Corp, a mobile software maker, are suing JPMorgan Chase & Co <JPM.N> for breach of fiduciary duty, according to a lawsuit filed on Thursday.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: JPMorgan was "self-interested" and "conflicted" in its dealings with Good Technology, which led the start-up to sell itself to BlackBerry Ltd <BB.TO> <BBRY.O> in 2015 at a "fire-sale" price of $425 million, the shareholders said in the amended lawsuit filed in Delaware Chancery Court.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: Good Technology was being advised by JPMorgan at the same time as the investment bank was advising BlackBerry, according to the lawsuit. JPMorgan prioritized its relationship with BlackBerry over its dealings with Good Technology, the complaint said.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The lawsuit valued Good Technology at over $1 billion.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: Blackberry and JPMorgan were not immediately available to comment on the issue.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The New York Times first reported the amended lawsuit earlier on Thursday. The complaint is part of a suit Good Technology shareholders originally filed in October 2015.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The suit already named Good Technology directors and executives as defendants and accused them of conflicts of interest.

Headline: Good Technology shareholders sue JPMorgan over fiduciary duty
Text: The case is Good Technology Corporation Stockholder Litigation, Court of Chancery, State of Delaware C.A. No. 11580-VCL REUTERS

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: ABOARD AIR FORCE ONE - President Barack Obama will likely have discussions with world leaders at the upcoming G20 meeting in China about controlling corporate tax avoidance and creating a more fair global tax system, the White House said on Thursday.

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: The EU ruled this week ruled that Apple must pay $13 billion euro ($14.5 billion) in back tax payments, a decision the Obama administration has criticized.

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said he did not expect headlines about progress on corporate tax avoidance from the G20 meeting of global economic leaders that runs Sunday through Monday.

Headline: Obama likely to address corporate tax avoidance at G20: White House
Text: "But I would anticipate that this is an issue that the President will engage in, in the context of discussions at the G20," Earnest said. REUTERS

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: LONDON - Olympus <7733.T>, the Japanese medical equipment and camera maker, is suing former CEO and whistleblower Michael Woodford in a multimillion-pound legal row over allegations of wrongdoing surrounding an executive pension plan.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Almost five years after Woodford lifted the lid on one of Japan's biggest corporate frauds, his former employer is claiming more than 15 million pounds ($20 million) from him and a former colleague, alleging they conspired to maximize their pension benefits by unlawful means, according to court filings.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford, Olympus's first foreign chief executive, was fired two weeks into the job in 2011 after persistently querying unexplained payments worth around $1.7 billion and demanding the resignation of its former chairman and vice president.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: He then alerted global authorities and the media. Olympus initially said Woodford was fired for failing to understand its management style and Japanese culture. But in September 2012 the company and three former executives pleaded guilty in Japan to cover-up charges.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Olympus's KeyMed unit, a surgical products maker in southern England, has now filed a High Court claim against Woodford and Olympus veteran Paul Hillman alleging they breached their duties as directors and trustees of the defined benefit pension plan.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford and Hillman, a former company director who resigned in 2011, deny any wrongdoing and say they acted at all times in accordance with their duties.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "Mr Woodford and Mr Hillman consider the claims against them to be completely baseless and look forward to taking the proceedings to trial and demonstrating what they consider to be the true motivations behind the claims by Olympus," they said in a joint statement.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford, who joined Olympus in 1981 and rose through its ranks to become CEO, has countersued Olympus. He alleges the case brought by KeyMed breaches a 2012 out-of-court settlement over his dismissal and is seeking damages "in the high seven figures".

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Olympus headquarters in Tokyo declined to comment.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Rudolf Muench, a Hamburg-based general manager at Olympus's European headquarters in Germany, said KeyMed was only alerted to possible wrongdoing in 2014 when the "substantial value" of one of the pensions became known.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "KeyMed has a responsibility towards its stakeholders and therefore could not ignore the evidence that was presented," he said in an email to Reuters.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "DELIBERATE WRONGDOING"

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: In documents received by the court on Aug. 26 and seen by Reuters, Olympus said the 2012 full and final employment settlement with Woodford did not prevent further legal action when claims were based on "deliberate wrongdoing or fraud".

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: The case against the men hinges on allegations that they obtained board approval to set up the executive pension plan in 2005 by concealing from others that the purpose of the scheme was "to increase the security of their pension". This was contrary to a board agreement there would be no enhancement of executive benefits through the scheme, the documents allege.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Olympus said the executive scheme provided for overly generous fixed 5 percent per annum increases in pension payments once the pension was activated, that it adopted an overly conservative investment strategy and that it dropped a provision to cut benefits for younger surviving spouses.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford and Hillman, whose wife is more than 10 years his junior, said the pension plan was established in 2007 after two years of discussions and that it was transparent and set up in consultation with the board, senior executives, independent trustees and on the advice of advisers and lawyers.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: They said Olympus raised no concerns about the pension plan during the last decade before issuing a claim in August 2015 and added allegations of fraud four months later "without any evidence to back them up".

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Woodford, 56, said his annual pension benefit rose to 993,000 pounds at the end of his 30-year Olympus career. This was converted into a capital sum of 64.5 million pounds and transferred to a Self Invested Personal Pension (SIPP), a UK government-approved scheme, with Olympus's approval in 2014.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Defined pension benefits are linked to the number of years employees work and their salaries, are paid for life and can be paid to spouses, partners or dependants when the retiree dies.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: Hillman, who is 64 and drawing his pension, told Reuters by telephone there was a catalog of correspondence to show the executive scheme had been set up and run correctly.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: "There is a picture being painted of us being devious and doing things in dark corners when everything has been done openly, in a transparent way," he said.

Headline: Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Olympus in legal dispute with whistleblower Woodford over pension
Text: ($1 = 0.7536 pounds) REUTERS

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: SINGAPORE — The micro-hotel, a concept that first gained traction in Europe with brands like Yotel and CitizenM at airports and in urban centres, is becoming more popular with travellers.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Yotel, which opened its first micro-hotel in London’s Gatwick Airport in 2007 and has others in Amsterdam and New York City, plans to expand in Singapore and Geneva, as well as in San Francisco, Boston and Miami.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Yotel, whose rooms at its New York City property are about 170 sq ft each, is expected to open its first flagship property in Asia next year with the launch of Yotel Singapore in Orchard Road. The 610-room hotel, to be located next to the Thai Embassy, is looking to charge S$200 to S$240 a night, its general manager Brendan Daly was reported by travel industry portal TTG as saying. This will be followed by another micro-hotel in Changi Airport the following year.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “Disruptions from short-term rentals are creating a whole new supply channel,” said Mr Scott Berman, principal in the hospitality and leisure division at PricewaterhouseCoopers.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: As hotels seek to blunt the appeal of accommodation portal Airbnb and court younger and more independent travellers, some are choosing to go the micro-hotel way. These micro-hotels blend elements from cruise ships and hostels and are characterised by compact guest rooms, an embrace of technology and an oversized communal lounge.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: It is not just specialty chains that are drawn to the concept. Lured by the profit potential of squeezing more rooms into the same amount of space, and possibly reducing the overall cost of construction, larger chains are also planning micro-hotel projects.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Hilton Hotels & Resorts is introducing Tru, which will have an average room size of 225 sq ft, compared with the typical room size of about 350 sq ft at Hampton Inn, which is owned by Hilton. Marriott International, which introduced Moxy in Milan, is creating a guest room in the United States that is expected to be about 180 sq ft. A room at a Courtyard by Marriott, by contrast, is about 300 sq ft.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “There’s a higher acceptance of the small rooms,” said Mr Mark van Stekelenburg, a managing director at CBRE Hotels. He said that guests saw value if the hotel offered significant amenities.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: Technology is a big draw, especially when deployed in creative ways. Yotel, for example, dispensed with bellhops in its New York micro-hotel, relying instead on a robotic arm to store and retrieve luggage.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: At CitizenM, a tablet computer controls the blinds and turns on the lights and the television. Moxy uses motion sensors to light the way into the private bathroom.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: For working, Hilton anticipates having private spaces and built-in alcoves instead of traditional business centres.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “There’s much less labour than in a traditional hotel,” said Ms Stephani Robson, a senior lecturer at the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: The focal point of these microhotels is their oversized common areas with sections for working, eating, drinking and playing. A recreation area might include a chess set or a foosball table.

Headline: Micro-hotel Yotel plans first Asian property in S’pore
Text: “Travellers want friends and guests to meet them there and feel good about it,” said Mr Hubert Viriot, chief executive of Yotel. AGENCIES

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: BRUSSELS - The European Commission rejected criticism from one of its own former antitrust chiefs on Friday of its massive tax demand on Apple and pointedly noted that she now works for another U.S. tech company, Uber.

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Neelie Kroes, who was EU competition commissioner for five years until 2010 and ran digital policy until two years ago, said this week's ruling by current antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager that the iPhone maker must pay 13 billion euros of back taxes that Ireland had waived was an incorrect use of EU law.

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: "EU member states have a sovereign right to determine their own tax laws. State aid cannot be used to rewrite those rules," Kroes wrote in the Guardian. "However, the current state aid investigations into tax rulings appear to do exactly that."

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Asked about the article at a regular news briefing on Friday, chief Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said:

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: "We understand that it may be sometimes challenging to reconcile the role as a former commissioner with the temptation to publicly express the views of those in Silicon Valley or elsewhere who oppose the Commission's decisions."

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Kroes, a Dutch liberal who left Brussels when Jean-Claude Juncker replaced Jose Manuel Barroso as Commission president in 2014, now sits on the public policy board of Uber. The Silicon Valley company that runs the ride-hailing app is lobbying the Commission to do more to challenge national rules across the Union that have curbed Uber's development in Europe.

Headline: EU rebuffs Vestager predecessor's criticism of Apple move
Text: Schinas said Kroes's criticism of Vestager's use of EU laws that ban governments giving firms unfair "state aid" -- in Apple's case via a tax deal -- was incorrect: "State aid rules ... were not applied in the way it was alleged," he said. REUTERS

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: “The amount isn’t set in stone at all, I think this figurehead of 13 billion, that is yet to be analyzed in detail,” Hofmann said. If the court backs the Commission, the executive would theoretically be free to challenge hundreds of other complex tax arrangements used, mainly by U.S. companies, to minimize taxes on European sales.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: A Reuters investigation in 2013 showed that at least 74 percent of the 50 biggest U.S. technology companies, including Google and Facebook, use practices similar to Apple’s to reduce their tax bills. http://uk.reuters.com/article/2013/07/23/us-tax-bigtech-idUSBRE96M08W201...

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Ireland is now supposed to calculate exactly how much Apple owes, which is typically paid ahead of an appeal, using the Commission’s methodology. However, a quirk of the Apple ruling may delay this. The Commission said other EU countries could claim some of the 13 billion euros by re-assessing the income of Apple subsidiaries on their territories.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: Apple's appeal will first be to the EU’s General Court, which will take two to three years to rule, lawyers say. A likely appeal to the ECJ could take another two years.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: In meantime, lawyers will be watching more advanced case s.denis Waelbroeck, of law firm Ashurst in Brussels, who is advising Luxembourg on its appeal in the FIAT case, said the General Court could give a ruling on that next March.

Headline: Apple appeal against EU tax demand would break new ground
Text: “Whatever outcome we get will influence Apple,” he said. REUTERS

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: BRUSSELS - Other multinationals that do not employ as extreme Irish tax schemes as Apple Inc but shift profits via the country to tax havens could also be breaching EU rules, Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said on Thursday.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She handed the iPhone maker a record 13-billion-euro bill for Irish registered units that Dublin authorities accepted were liable to tax in no country on Tuesday.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She told Reuters in an interview that other firms' arrangements, which involve routing profits to Irish-registered subsidiaries tax resident in places like Bermuda, might fall foul of the Commission on similar grounds.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: "Taxes have been paid nowhere due to the Irish tax code," she said.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Asked if the bill would have been different if the head office of Apple's Irish unit been registered and paid tax in Bermuda, Vestager said: "not much."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Vestager said the core of the case against Apple was that it had an Irish registered company that booked most of the profits generated across Europe.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: However, since Ireland didn't deem the subsidiary tax resident there, the unit was able to report just a small taxable income at an Irish "branch."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Apple's chief executive, Tim Cook, and Washington have denounced the Commission ruling as an unjust raid on tax that should be paid in the United States. Apple's chief financial officer, Luca Maestri, told reporters on Tuesday that the assertion that Apple doesn't pay taxes anywhere on much of its profits is "simply wrong."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: "These are profits that are taxed in the United States, and for anybody that understands the U.S. worldwide tax system, this is very easy to understand," Maestri said. "We actually accrue those tax liabilities on our balance sheet on an ongoing basis and we've done it consistently over the years."

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Vestager said if Washington chose to tax the profits reported by Apple's Irish operation, she would reduce her demand accordingly.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: The United States could do this by forcing Apple to have its Irish units pay more in fees to Apple in California for the right to license Apple patents.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: "If the U.S. tax authority found that the monies paid due to the cost-sharing agreement were too few ... so that they should pay more in the cost-sharing agreement, that would transfer more money to the States and that may change the books and the accounts in the States," Vestager said.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: Vestager said, however, that the bill would not be affected if Apple next year moved funds from its Irish units to the United States by paying dividends, even though in this case, the dividends would be taxed.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She declined to discuss which other companies' affairs were being looked at by her staff beyond two publicly announced and outstanding investigations into Amazon <AMZN.O> and McDonald's <MCD.N> in Luxembourg.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She said that since being alerted to Apple's methods and other cases by a U.S. Senate probe in 2013, the Commission has been looking through about 1,000 such instances in the EU.

Headline: EU's Vestager warns others, says Apple could cut bill
Text: She dismissed accusations from Apple's Cook and others that her decision was politically motivated or driven by anti-American populism. While U.S. companies have been investigated, she said, most of 35 firms probed over tax in Belgium were from Europe, and those still being looked at were a broad sample. REUTERS

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: NEW YORK - Oil prices fell more than 3 percent on Thursday, heading for their sharpest weekly slide since January as investors brushed aside talk that OPEC might freeze production and focused on a growing glut from U.S. crude stockpiles.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Energy monitoring service Genscape's report of a 714,282-barrel drawdown at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery point for U.S. crude futures during the week ended on Aug. 30 did little to bolster sentiment, traders who saw the report said.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Investors focused instead on Wednesday's government data showing a 2.3 million-barrel build in U.S. crude stocks in the last week, more than double what the market had expected. Inventories of distillates, which include diesel and heating oil, rose nearly 10 times as much as forecast, the data from the U.S. Energy Information Administration showed. [EIA/S]

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Brent crude futures ended the session at $45.45 per barrel, down $1.44 or 3.07 percent.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: U.S. crude's West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures closed down $1.54 or 3.45 percent at $43.16 a barrel.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Both Brent and WTI were down about 9 percent week-to-date for their biggest decline since mid-January.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Technical pressure has also increased on oil, with WTI edging toward a test of its Aug. 11 low of $41.10. That low had been a crucial support for U.S. crude futures, which rallied to above $48 less than a week later.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: "Basically it's a retest of that breakout," Andreas Wunder at Alphatrade Asset Management in Austin, Texas, said, noting the move lower appeared as forceful as the one higher.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: A Reuters poll of 34 analysts and economists forecast Brent would average $45.44 a barrel in 2016, slightly lower than last month's forecast of $45.51. [O/POLL]

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: It was the first downward revision in prices on the poll in six months, and came amid reduced prospects for output curbs by the world's largest oil producers.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: Oil prices rose as much 11 percent in August, posting their biggest monthly rise since April, on speculation the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and other producers might agree to freezing production during Sept. 26-28 talks in Algeria.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: That speculation has since fizzled, although Saudi Foreign Minister Adel al-Jubeir said on Thursday that OPEC and non-OPEC oil producers were moving toward a common position on output.

Headline: Oil slides on glut worry, on track for biggest weekly drop since Jan
Text: "Talk is cheap," Harry Tchilinguirian, global head of commodity markets strategy at BNP Paribas, told the Reuters Global Oil Forum. "Reality will set in, and the market will realize that the agendas of various OPEC producers are not aligned." REUTERS

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: Traders of U.S. short-term interest rate futures trimmed expectations that the Federal Reserve could soon lift interest rates after a government report showed U.S. employers added fewer jobs than expected last month.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: Nonfarm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, the Labor Department said on Friday. Economists had expected a gain of 180,000.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: "It is not a compelling number for the Fed and it is not going to force their hand for a hike in September," said Thomas Simons, an analyst at Jefferies.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: The Fed is now seen as only slightly more likely to raise rates in December than to wait until next year before raising rates. Traders are all but ruling out a rate hike later this month.

Headline: Traders trim bets on Fed rate hike as U.S. job gains slow
Text: Before the report traders saw better than even odds of a December rate hike, based on trading in futures tied to the Fed's policy rate, and a one-in-four chance of a rate hike when the Fed meets Sept. 20-21. REUTERS

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: RICHMOND, Va. - The U.S. economy appears strong enough to warrant significantly higher interest rates, Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker said on Friday.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Lacker, who is not a voting member of the U.S. central bank's rate-setting committee this year, said he still favors raising rates sooner than later and that the Fed's last policy meeting in July would have been a "good time" to tighten policy.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Speaking to a group of economists in Richmond, Lacker argued that a range of economic analysis suggests the Fed's benchmark overnight interest rate - the federal funds rate - is currently too low.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: "It appears that the funds rate should be significantly higher than it is now," he said in the speech.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: He made his comments after the U.S. government reported a hiring slowdown in August that could effectively rule out a rate increase later this month.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: While Lacker is not due to have a vote on policy until 2018, he does participate in discussions on interest rates. The Fed has appeared sharply divided between policymakers who favor rate increases soon and those who urge more caution.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Those favoring caution appeared to get a boost on Friday when a report showed 150,000 U.S. jobs were created last month, fewer than expected.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: But Lacker said the weaker pace of hiring still left the job market on a strengthening path and the case for higher rates would only grow stronger unless job growth slowed "significantly in the months ahead."

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: He suggested there were increased risks in waiting to raise rates.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: "The way the data is playing out I think the longer we wait there is a material increase in risks that we run," Lacker told reporters after his speech.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: The Fed hiked rates in December for the first time in nearly a decade and has signaled since March that two rate increases could be in order this year. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last week she thought the case for a rate hike had strengthened, but many investors have doubts the central bank will raise rates at all this year.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: Lacker said he was concerned the economy could heat up enough for inflation to go above the Fed's 2 percent target, hurting the central bank's credibility. He said warning about prices "might not be fashionable" given that inflation has been below target in recent years.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: But there is a risk the Fed will have to jack up rates quickly, triggering a recession, he said in his speech.

Headline: U.S. economy may need much higher interest rates: Fed's Lacker
Text: "It would be hard to calibrate policy settings carefully enough to avoid precipitating a contraction in real activity," Lacker said. REUTERS

Headline: Harley-Davidson says plans to cut about 200 jobs
Text: Harley-Davidson Inc <HOG.N> plans to cut about 200 positions as the company adjusts production plans to align with its 2016 motorcycle shipment guidance, a company spokeswoman said on Thursday.

Headline: Harley-Davidson says plans to cut about 200 jobs
Text: In July, the motorcycle manufacturer lowered its 2016 full-year shipment guidance to a range of 264,000 to 269,000 motorcycles. The company had previously estimated it would ship 269,000 to 274,000 motorcycles. REUTERS

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: Heavy machinery maker Caterpillar Inc <CAT.N> said it could lay off about 2,000 employees at a plant in Belgium, as it considers shifting production to other facilities as part of a restructuring program announced last year.

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: The company, which manufactures construction equipment at the plant in Gosselies, Belgium said it may shift the production to its facility at Grenoble, France and other locations outside of Europe.

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: Caterpillar said in September 2015 that it will cut as many as 10,000 jobs through 2018 and also might close or consolidate more than 20 plants around the world as it grappled with the mining and energy downturn.

Headline: Caterpillar says it may lay off 2,000 workers at Belgium plant
Text: In July, Caterpillar said that global uncertainty, the vote in Britain to leave the European Union and the attempted coup in Turkey had heightened risks, especially in Europe. REUTERS

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: BEIJING - China's commerce ministry will launch an anti-monopoly probe into Comcast Corp's <CMCSA.O> planned purchase of DreamWorks Animation after receiving unspecified complaints that the U.S. media deal could hurt competition in the Chinese market.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: The investigation comes as China's anti-trust watchdog has hardened its stance on companies striking deals without seeking its clearance, with the body naming, shaming and fining almost a dozen firms over the past year for "gun-jumping".

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: Comcast, owner of NBCUniversal, said in April it would pay $3.8 billion to buy DreamWorks, the producer of the "Kung Fu Panda" and "Shrek" franchises, which was also one of the first Hollywood names to open a production studio in China.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: "Recently MOFCOM received complaints regarding Comcast's decision to buy out DreamWorks, claiming that the deal would hurt competition in the Chinese market," Shen Danyang, spokesman for the Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) said on Friday. Shen didn't say exactly what the complaints were, nor who made them.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: China's film market, the world's second largest, is a magnet for film producers looking to tap the country's 1.4 billion people, even though there are signs that stellar box office growth may be starting to slow.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: Reuters was unable to reach Comcast or DreamWorks for immediate comment out of regular U.S. business hours.

Headline: China launches anti-trust probe into Comcast, DreamWorks deal
Text: Separately, China's commerce ministry said on Friday it would investigate the planned merger of ride-hailing firm Didi Chuxing and the Chinese unit of U.S. rival Uber over anti-monopoly concerns. REUTERS

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Ireland's cabinet agreed on Friday to join Apple in appealing against a multi-billion-euro back tax demand that the European Commission has imposed on the iPhone maker, despite misgivings among independents who back the fragile coalition.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The Commission's ruling this week that the U.S. tech giant must pay up to 13 billion euros ($14.5 billion) to Dublin has angered Washington, which accuses the EU of trying to grab tax revenue that should go to the U.S. government.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: With transatlantic tensions rising, the White House said President Barack Obama would raise the issue of tax avoidance by some multinational corporations at a summit of the G20 leading economies in China this weekend.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Paradoxically, Ireland is determined not to accept the tax windfall, which would be equivalent to what it spent last year on funding its struggling health service.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Finance Minister Michael Noonan has insisted Dublin would fight any adverse ruling ever since the European Union began investigating Apple's Irish tax affairs in 2014, arguing that it had to protect a tax regime that has attracted large numbers of multinational employers.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: On Wednesday, he failed to persuade a group of independent lawmakers, whose support is vital for the minority government, to agree to fight the ruling by European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager that Apple's low tax arrangements in Ireland constitute illegal state aid.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: However, he won them over when the cabinet met again on Friday.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Noonan said the retroactive nature of the EU ruling was "little short of bizarre and outrageous".

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "How could any foreign direct investor come into Europe if they thought the valid arrangements they made under law could be overturned a generation later and they be liable to pay back money," he said at a news conference.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Public Expenditure Minister Paschal Donohoe said Dublin stood behind its corporate tax regime as a means of creating jobs.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "This ruling has seismic and entirely negative consequences for job creation in the future," he said.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Apple, keen to defend its own interests, has already said it will lodge an appeal. For Fine Gael, the main Irish coalition party, a broader principle is at stake. It wants to take on Brussels to safeguard Ireland's decades-old low corporate tax policy that has drawn in multinationals such as Apple, creating one in 10 jobs in what was once an impoverished country.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: A FAIR RATE OF TAX

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The Independent Alliance, a group of five lawmakers, fell in line after the coalition agreed to conduct a review of what tax multinationals pay and what should they pay.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Transport Minister Shane Ross, an Alliance member, defended Apple up to a point. "I think they were acting legally. What they were doing was making use of extraordinary loopholes that existed there," he told reporters. "Multinationals provide absolutely vital jobs to the economy ... (but) multinationals should pay a fair rate of tax in Ireland."

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: A failure of the Alliance to come on board would have cast doubt on the government's survival prospects. Dublin has just over two months to lodge an appeal to the EU's General Court. If that fails, Dublin has said it plans to take the case to the European Court of Justice.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The issue goes to parliament on Wednesday next week, when lawmakers will be recalled from their summer break. The main opposition party, Fianna Fail, also favors challenging Brussels, so the government should easily win the Dail's backing to fight what is by far the largest anti-competition measure imposed on a company by the EU.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Some Irish voters are astounded that the government might turn down the money, and the left-wing Sinn Fein party has led attacks from the opposition.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Apple was found to be holding over $181 billion in accumulated profits offshore, more than any U.S. company, in a study published last year by two left-leaning nonprofit groups, a policy critics say is designed to avoid paying U.S taxes.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: But Apple chief executive Tim Cook has said part of the company's 2014 tax bill would be paid next year when the company repatriates offshore profits to the United States.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: OBAMA TO TAKE THE LEAD

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: The U.S. government is keen to ensure that it, and not Ireland, gets the revenue.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said leaders of the G20 developed and emerging economies would tackle the wider issue when they meet in the Chinese city of Hangzhou on Sept. 4-5.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "The president will ... lead the discussion at the G20 about combating tax avoidance strategies that are implemented by some multinational corporations," Earnest said.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: "We need to find a way to make the global system of taxation more fair - more fair to countries around the world, particularly countries like the United States."

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: A number of G20 governments are worried about how multinationals move profits around so they end up getting taxed in a country that has very low corporate rates.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: The United Auto Workers (UAW) urged Volkswagen <VOWG_p.DE> to accept the National Labor Relations Board's (NLRB) latest order that requires the carmaker to collectively bargain with UAW local union as the representative of a portion of workers at its Tennessee plant.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
