Text: The NLRB on Aug. 26 ordered Volkswagen Group of America Inc among other things to recognize and bargain with UAW, Local 42, as the exclusive collective-bargaining representative of the employees in the bargaining unit. (http://bit.ly/2bTYSf7)

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: "This unanimous decision makes it clear that the company has been operating in violation of federal law by refusing to come to the bargaining table," said Gary Casteel, UAW secretary-treasurer, in a statement.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: "We urge Volkswagen to accept the NLRB order and bargain with the local union at the earliest possible date."

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Volkswagen has filed an appeal against the National Labor Relations Board's order in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, the company said in an email to Reuters.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Volkswagen has said earlier that it will go to a U.S. federal appeals court in an effort to keep the UAW union from representing a portion of the company's plant workers in Chattanooga.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Late last year, a majority of the maintenance, or skilled trades, workers at VW's plant in Chattanooga, Tennessee, voted to be represented by the UAW.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: The vote marked a rare victory for the union in the U.S. South, where it has fought many unsuccessful battles to organize non-unionized auto plants.

Headline: UAW asks Volkswagen to accept NLRB order on Tennessee plant row
Text: Volkswagen was at one time welcoming to the UAW at Chattanooga. But that was before the union lost a closely contested election open to all of the plant's 1,500 workers in February 2014. REUTERS

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: Last year the Organisation for Economic Co Operation and Development unveiled new measures to tackle corporate tax avoidance. A number of countries have moved to implement some of them measures, but the United States has not.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: It needs to change its own tax rules which, for example, allow companies to build up tax-free profits offshore. However, Congress has struggled for years to agree such reforms.

Headline: Ireland to join Apple in fight against EU tax ruling
Text: ($1 = 0.8937 euros) REUTERS

Headline: Ireland to hold independent review of corporate tax system
Text: DUBLIN - Ireland's coalition government has committed to holding an independent review of the country's corporate tax system after it agreed on Friday to join Apple in appealing against a multi-billion-euro back tax demand from the European Commission.

Headline: Ireland to hold independent review of corporate tax system
Text: The review will assess "what tax multinationals do pay and what they should pay", said junior minister John Halligan of the Independent Alliance, a group of five lawmakers whose initial misgivings delayed the launching of an appeal.

Headline: Ireland to hold independent review of corporate tax system
Text: The terms of reference for the review will be decided in the coming days, the Independent Alliance members told reporters. REUTERS

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Delta Air Lines Inc <DAL.N> said its revenue for August was reduced by about $100 million due to an outage that led to the cancellation of 2,300 flights over three days.

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Passenger revenue per available seat mile (PRASM), a key measure of an airline's performance that measures sales against flight capacity, declined 9.5 percent in August from a year earlier, its biggest drop in nine months. [nPn9p2d6Ra]

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Excluding the impact of the outage, Delta's unit revenue was below expectations, J.P.Morgan's Jamie Baker wrote in a note.

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Baker said he expects Delta to cut its third-quarter operating margin to at least 17-19 percent from its current forecast of 19-21 percent.

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: The No. 2 U.S. airline by passenger traffic said last month a power outage hit its computer systems, leading to the flight cancellations. [nL3N1AR3TH]

Headline: Delta Air says outage hurt August revenue by about $100 million
Text: Delta in July forecast a drop of 4-6 percent in PRASM for the third quarter ending September. [nL1N1A00B2] REUTERS

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: LEXINGTON, Ky. - The U.S. labor market is at full strength and the Federal Reserve needs to be on a path of gradual interest rate increases, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said on Thursday.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "It seems like a gradual increase from a very low interest rate that we are at now is pretty compelling to me," Mester told reporters without saying whether she would support an increase at the Fed's policy meeting later this month. REUTERS

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: SAN FRANCISCO - Even if a report due Friday shows U.S. companies kept up their rapid pace of hiring in August, there is still enough resistance among policymakers at the Federal Reserve to delay an interest-rate hike at the bank's September meeting.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Reuters polling forecasts that 180,000 jobs were added last month, well above the 100,000 Fed Chair Janet Yellen says is needed to absorb newcomers to the labor market. At that rate, 2016 would be on pace for more than 2 million new jobs.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Despite those strong gains that have pushed the unemployment rate down to 4.9 percent, some at the Fed are not convinced of the need to move yet. Among them is Fed Board Governor Lael Brainard, who has warned of downside risks to the economy and said the rate hike path needs to be "shallow."

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Governor Jerome Powell, who last week called for "caution" on rate hikes, and Governor Daniel Tarullo, who has signaled he wants to see more evidence that inflation is on the rise, are also skeptical of the need to move soon.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: And even Yellen, who said last week that an improving labor market and signs that inflation are firming have strengthened the case for a rate hike, has said nothing on the timing, even though her more hawkish Vice Chair Stanley Fischer ignited rate hike expectations when he spoke after Yellen.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Despite the strong labor market gains, the economy's performance by other measures has been tepid. The most recent estimates put growth in the second quarter at just 1.1 percent, far less than the 2 percent in the quarter prior to last December's rate hike. The Fed's preferred inflation measure remains stuck at 1.6 percent, well below its 2-percent target.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Weakness in productivity persists as well, an increasing concern for the Federal Reserve as lower productivity will crimp the future potential rate of growth for the economy as a whole.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Reports released Thursday showed U.S. factory activity contracted in August for the first time in six months, pointing to weakness in manufacturing. Annual business investment as a proportion of gross domestic product has been running a full percentage point below its pre-recession readings.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: A working paper published this week on the San Francisco Fed's website added to a gloomy view of longer-term growth prospects in the world's largest economy.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Economist John Fernald -- whose work on productivity is frequently cited by Fed policymakers including Yellen -- estimated the U.S. economy will probably only grow 1.6 percent a year over the next decade or so. That's well below the 2 percent that many Fed policymakers and economists currently expect.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: "For policymakers, it suggests a low 'speed limit' for the economy," Fernald said.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: IF NOT SEPTEMBER, THEN DECEMBER?

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Still, some Fed officials worry that persisting with low rates to edge the unemployment rate down further could lead to uncomfortably strong upward price pressure or feed destabilizing asset bubbles.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: To these policymakers, who include the reliably hawkish heads of the Cleveland and Kansas City Feds, Loretta Mester and Esther George, as well as the usually dovish chief of the Boston Fed, Eric Rosengren, raising interest rates slowly but soon is key to keeping the U.S. economy from overheating.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: "If we stay too loose for too long, bad things can happen," said Barclays' economist Michael Gapen, summing up the view he sees as winning the day at the Fed.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: The Fed last raised rates in December of last year, after keeping them near zero since the 2007-2009 financial crisis to encourage investment and hiring.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Several regional Fed presidents do appear to favor a near-term rate hike.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: So even if September passes without a rate hike, an increase in 2016 is still very much on the table.

Headline: Fed may stay cool on September hike even if job market glows hot
Text: Financial markets also seem primed for December. Traders of Fed funds futures see a 24 percent chance of a hike this month, with a better than even chance of a move in December <0#FF:> <FFZ6>. REUTERS

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Federal Reserve policymakers already skeptical of the need for an interest-rate hike this month gained some ground against their more hawkish colleagues after a government report Friday showed U.S. job gains slowed last month.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: But as long as data in the next few months suggests continued moderate economic growth and a rise in inflation toward the Fed's 2-percent target, Fed policymakers look likely to back a December rate hike as a prudent step toward normalizing what has been nearly a decade of ultra-easy monetary policy.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: The Fed raised short-term interest rates last December by a quarter of a percentage point, but have left them unchanged so far this year. Last week, Fed Chair Janet Yellen said an improving labor market and signs that inflation are firming have strengthened the case for a rate hike, and most regional Fed bank presidents as well as Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer appear to back a rate hike sooner than later.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Some analysts continue to expect the Fed to raise rates this month, including economist Jan Hatzius at Goldman Sachs who said the August job gains are "just enough" to be convincing. August figures are often revised higher in subsequent months.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Even without any revision, monthly average job gains for the most recent three months register 232,000, more than double the level that Yellen says is needed to keep the unemployment rate steady.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: "It appears that the funds rate should be significantly higher than it is now," Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker, a consistent advocate for a rate hike even when the unemployment was higher than its current 4.9 percent, said Friday.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Lacker also said the August payrolls data suggests the job market is still tightening.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: But with resistance among other key Fed policymakers to a near-term rate hike strong, a September rate hike was already seen as unlikely before the jobs report.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: Traders of interest rate futures see about a one in four chance of a rate hike at the Fed's Sept. 20-21 meeting.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: December, however, is another story, with the rate futures market seeing about a 60 percent chance of a rate hike then.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: While the August gain of 151,000 jobs was less than expected, it is still plenty to provide work for new job entrants as well as any discouraged workers reentering the labor market.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: And Fed officials have long said they expect job gains to slow as the U.S. economy nears full employment.

Headline: Jobs report gives ammo to Fed skeptics on September rate hike
Text: "Most (Fed policymakers) think another rate hike sometime soon is the right thing to do," Roberto Perli, Cornerstone Macro economist wrote after the report. "A rate hike this year was a solid base case before the employment report, and still remains a solid base case now." REUTERS

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: ROME - Italy has received no communication from the German transport ministry over emissions tests used by carmaker Fiat Chrysler <FCHA.MI>, a source at Italy's infrastructure ministry said on Thursday.

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: Germany's transport ministry has asked the European Commission to investigate exhaust emissions of Fiat Chrysler vehicles for potential illegal manipulation devices, German government documents showed.

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: The Italian ministry source said the relevant authorities had been in contact and Germany's KBA motor vehicle authority had never disagreed with the Italian ministry's finding that Fiat vehicles complied with emissions rules.

Headline: Italy has had no word from Germany over Fiat emissions: Italy govt source
Text: A Fiat spokeswoman said the cars complied with the rules and do not contain so-called defeat devices. REUTERS

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: KFC and Pizza Hut owner Yum Brands Inc <YUM.N> said Chinese investment firm Primavera Capital and an affiliate of Alibaba Group Holding Ltd <BABA.N> will buy a stake in Yum China for $460 million as Yum prepares to spin off the business.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The deal gives Primavera, a powerful China-focused private equity firm founded by an ex-Goldman Sachs banker, a significant stake in Yum's China business. It also further expands the reach of Ant Financial, which runs Alibaba's Alipay mobile payments platform and has been expanding into China's restaurant industry.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The investors will receive warrants to buy an additional 4 percent stake in Yum China in two tranches at valuations of $12 billion and $15 billion, the company said on Friday.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: A Yum spokesman said the use of the proceeds from the deal will be determined by the future Yum China board of directors.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Yum has signaled that part of the money could go toward expanding across China, as the company signaled last October that it hoped to nearly triple the amount of its restaurants in China to 20,000.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: KFC and Pizza Hut brands reaped the rewards of catering to China's booming economy, with patrons flooding the restaurants that offered fast Western food, a higher level of service and perceived food safety.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: But Yum's China business has hit road blocks in recent years, including a scandal at a minor meat supplier and bird flu outbreaks.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Yum, still the largest fast-food chain in China, has also been losing ground to McDonald's Corp <MCD.N>.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The Louisville, Kentucky-based company's move to separate its China business followed pressure last year from one of its largest investors, Corvex Management, the activist hedge fund run by Keith Meister. Meister is on Yum's board.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: The spinoff is expected on Oct. 31, with Yum China to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange a day later, the company said on Friday.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Primavera will invest $410 million, while Ant Financial, which runs Alibaba's Alipay mobile payments platform, will put in $50 million. China's sovereign wealth fund and New York private equity firm KKR & Co were also in the hunt for a Yum China stake.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Primavera's founder, Fred Hu, will become non-executive chairman of Yum China's board.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Goldman Sachs is financial adviser, while Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz are legal adviser to Yum Brands and Yum China. Simpson Thacher & Bartlett LLP and Fangda Partners are legal advisers to Primavera and Ant.

Headline: Yum to sell stake in China business ahead of spinoff
Text: Yum shares were up 1 percent at $91.70 in morning trading. REUTERS

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Duke Energy Corp's <DUK.N> board must face a shareholder lawsuit over its abrupt 2012 firing of its newly installed chief executive, a Delaware judge has ruled.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: In a decision on Wednesday, Delaware Vice Chancellor Sam Glasscock denied Duke's bid to end the case, finding the shareholder plaintiffs plausibly argued that the defendants might have concealed information about their actions from the public and regulators.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: As part of its $18 billion deal to acquire Progress Energy, Duke had agreed to install Progress head William Johnson as CEO of the combined company. But within hours of the acquisition's closing in July 2012, the new Duke board met and fired Johnson, reinstating former Duke CEO James Rogers, in a vote along company lines.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Johnson left with a pre-negotiated $44 million severance package. Shareholders almost immediately sued Duke, arguing the decision to terminate him was reached in May 2012 and concealed from the public, investors and regulators. Duke's share price subsequently fell and the S&P lowered the company's credit rating.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Duke and the executives and directors named in the lawsuit strongly deny the lawsuit's allegations and any wrongdoing related to the CEO change after the 2012 merger, Duke said in a statement on Thursday.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: Duke said the company, executives and directors would continue to vigorously defend themselves in the litigation.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: In his decision, Glasscock said the plaintiffs plausibly alleged the holdover Duke board members had second thoughts about Johnson in the 18 months between the deal's announcement and its closing. According to the lawsuit, the board decided to conceal its plan to oust Johnson because it did not want to risk trying to renegotiate the merger terms or face further questions from state regulators that could delay its approval.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: They chose instead to wait until a meeting after the acquisition closed to say Johnson was not a good fit to lead the combined company, the lawsuit alleged.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: The abrupt CEO change brought other federal and state claims in North Carolina and an investigation by the state utilities regulator in North Carolina, where Duke and Progress were headquartered.

Headline: Duke Energy shareholder lawsuit over CEO firing moves forward
Text: A settlement with regulators formalized Rogers' exit in 2013. Duke in 2015 settled a securities class action related to the merger in North Carolina federal court for $146 million. Duke and the named executives and directors denied the class allegations of misrepresentations related to the CEO change. REUTERS

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: U.S. employment growth slowed more than expected in August after two straight months of robust gains and wage gains moderated, which could effectively rule out an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve this month.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: KEY POINTS:* Headline job growth at 151k vs 180k estimate

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: * Private sector adds 126k vs 178k estimate

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: * Unemployment rate steady at 4.9 percent

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: * Revisions: July up 20k to 275k; June down 21k to 271k

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: COMMENTS:QUINCY KROSBY, MARKET STRATEGIST, PRUDENTIAL FINANCIAL, NEWARK, NEW JERSEY:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "With equity futures rising, the dollar weakening, gold strengthening, and the 10-year yield pulling back, the market has voted and says a September rate hike is off the table. While the report is solid and could be subject to a positive revision, it falls short of providing a resounding vote for a September move by the Fed. Although there will be a full parade of data before the meeting, there is a premium on the employment data. It was solid but not the stellar numbers needed to convince the market that September is in play."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: RANDY FREDERICK, MANAGING DIRECTOR, TRADING AND DERIVATIVES, CHARLES SCHWAB, AUSTIN, TEXAS:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "Nothing to surprise a whole lot of people in any of this. I think the non-farm payroll number was just a little bit weak but it's nothing to be alarmed about.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't think this particular report, given where it came in at, is enough to move the markets in any material way. Surprisingly the equity futures have responded fairly positively.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "It's not at all surprising to see us move a little higher given that we are at the low end of the range we have been in for the last six weeks. But is this going to be enough to push us out? I'd be very surprised if that happened."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: GREG PETERS,  SENIOR INVESTMENT OFFICER AT PRUDENTIAL FIXED INCOME,  NEWARK, NEW JERSEY:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "Today's payroll figure definitely pushes the September rate hike and it looks like we are data dependent even more so for the rest of the year. I think incoming economic data will create a little more volatility in the fourth quarter. Overall,  I can't believe that after 256 days since the December rate hike last year with hundreds of economic data releases since that time, it seems ludicrous that the Fed's decision is singularly predicated on one single data release that is known to be volatile and subject to significant revisions. Could this really be the case, or are the markets simply putting too much stock in selected events to create their own guideposts given the Fed's poor communication strategy? Either way, to me, this loudly speaks to their massive communication problem and why the markets are increasingly losing confidence in the institution as a consequence."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: TONY BEDIKIAN, HEAD OF GLOBAL MARKETS AT CITIZENS BANK, BOSTON:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "The number came in obviously a little bit below expectations, but still close to 150,000 new jobs. I think the Fed will still view that quite positively. The revisions the last two months were about flat, and I think the Fed is cognizant that the August number historically has had the greatest likelihood of being revised upward by roughly 70,000 jobs on average. So all in all, it looks like a fairly positive number here."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "The market would like to have seen a  200,000 plus payroll print to really get the Fed off the fence. There is still a possibility that the Fed does go in September, because overall the payroll trend has still been positive, the market has priced in about a 1 in 3 chance still of the Fed going later this month, and we still have a little bit more data, there are some inflation numbers to see between now and then, so if we do get some uptick in the inflation data, the CPI and PPI later this month prior to the Fed meeting on the 21st, then  the Fed could go. I think this number doesn't necessarily jog the Fed in the near-term."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: KEVIN LOGAN, CHIEF U.S. ECONOMIST, HSBC SECURITIES, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "At the margin it dissuades the Fed from moving in September. It's not a clincher. If they feel they want to go for other reasons they can. But this jobs report is not a compelling reason.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "The wage gains are very modest and that's important. The whole logic here is that a tighter labor market, means rising wages, means upward pressure on inflation – and for that reason they should reduce accommodation. But that's not happening, so this report does not compel them to move."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: HEIDI LEARNER, CHIEF ECONOMIST, SAVILLS STUDLEY, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't think it shifts the thinking, I do think it could be fifty-fifty. It's not surprising to see moderation in the three-month average is still OK. The only thing that was a little bit surprising to me was the slowdown in temporary help and employment services, which always makes me a little nervous. But there wasn't enough weakness in the report to derail the Fed, but similarly it would not be a mistake now if they waited until December rather than September."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: CRAIG BISHOP, LEAD STRATEGIST FOR U.S. FIXED INCOME, RBC WEALTH MANAGEMENT, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I think (the jobs data) points to continued hiring although some of the other numbers, what we refer to as the Yellen indicators - the measure of slack in the labor force, wages, labor force participation and underemployment –  really showed no progress, in fact wages were lower from a month ago. I think it points to continued hiring but not progress made on those measures that the Fed and Yellen look at to indicate a lessening of slack in the labor force. Looking at it in context of what it means for the September FOMC meeting."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I think it continues to point to a solid employment picture in the U.S., but it wasn't that big blowout number that in our opinion would've been needed to cause the Fed to tilt toward a September rate hike. I think you'll see that reflected in rate hike probabilities throughout the day. So we move on now to focusing on whether it's December or 2017."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: MOHAMED EL-ERIAN, CHIEF ECONOMIC ADVISER, ALLIANZ, NEWPORT BEACH, CALIFORNIA:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "This mixed jobs report puts the Fed in a tricky situation. It's not all around strong enough to assure a September interest rate hike. But it's solid enough to engender a heated policy discussion, especially given the unintended consequences and collateral damage of a prolonged period of ultra low interest rates."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: JASON CELENTE, SENIOR FIXED INCOME PORTFOLIO MANAGER, INSIGHT INVESTMENT, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't think it means much. Net of revisions the import statistics like the headline payroll number and the hourly earnings number were pretty much in line with consensus and trend. As far as the Fed is concerned, I don't think it's a number that is a major setback for what they ultimately want to achieve, which is that a slow and gradual pace for a rate normalization.

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "If you look at the probabilities, the market is likely to trade with anticipation for changes in Fed policy, and if you look at what the market has been pricing for September and December respectively, I think those odds are  probably fairly accurate in our view and I don't think the numbers today really change those probabilities."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: SEAN LYNCH, CO-HEAD OF GLOBAL EQUITY STRATEGY, WELLS FARGO INVESTMENT INSTITUTE, OMAHA, NEBRASKA:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "People are taking a little bit of a relief that it wasn't a 200,000 plus print, certainly in the equity market. 151,000 is a good number, when you look at the last three months we are 230,000-plus on average. Our belief is that equity markets are going to give the Fed at least one rate increase but if they start to perceive a series of hikes coming and coming sooner than later, that is when equity markets will get a little nervous here. But the 150,000 number doesn't increase the odds of that at all."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "I don't know about (September) wiped off the table because the Fed, some of the rhetoric we've seen has been pretty mixed the past couple of weeks. Our view is that they do hold off until later this year, possibly even December or early next year before raising rates. We think slow, steady growth until the end of the year is still a good backdrop for equities, but taking a sigh of relief that it wasn't a blowout number which really would have ratcheted up September and possibly other increases later this year."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: TOM PORCELLI, CHIEF US ECONOMIST, RBC CAPITAL MARKETS, NEW YORK:

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
Text: "It was a middling report at best, particularly as it relates to the conversation on the Fed. There were no positive standouts here, the key underlying data were all pretty soft as well. I don't think this is the kind of the report that the Fed wanted to see ahead of a hike in September, the contours are just too squishy. This should put to rest the conversation on September."

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August
U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August

Headline: U.S. payrolls grow less than expected in August

Text: RATE FUTURES: Fed funds futures prices rise across the term structure. September contract up 0.5 basis point; December up 2 basis points. Probability of a September hike dips to just 18 percent from around 24 percent before the release

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: NEW YORK - U.S. and European stocks ended mostly flat and the dollar fell on Thursday after a report showing weakness in U.S. manufacturing last month weighed on shares as investors eyed Friday's monthly U.S. jobs data, while oil prices tumbled.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The Institute for Supply Management said its index of national factory activity fell to 49.4 in August, below expectations of economists polled by Reuters for a dip to just 52.0. It was the first contraction in manufacturing since February.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The data hurt sentiment amid an already nervous investor environment ahead of Friday's U.S. employment report for August. Federal Reserve Vice Chair Stanley Fischer said last week that the central bank would consider the jobs data when discussing when to next raise interest rates.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: Employers are expected to have added 180,000 jobs in August, according to a Reuters poll of economists.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The benchmark U.S. S&P 500 <.SPX> fell as much as 0.7 percent after the ISM data before stabilizing. The tech-heavy Nasdaq <.IXIC> rose, boosted by Charter Communications <CHTR.O>, which gained 4.5 percent.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The weak U.S. ISM data also stifled European shares. Stocks in the region had earlier climbed to two-week highs.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: "The ISM data was, in a word, disappointing," said Peter Kenny, senior market strategist at Global Markets Advisory Group in New York. "It has forced investors to reconsider the landscape, not go blindly into the narrative that spells out a certainty about interest rates being bumped up in September.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: "Oil prices extended Wednesday's declines, with the market focused for a second straight day on U.S. government data showing a rise in U.S. crude stocks in the latest week.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: MSCI's all-country world equity index <.MIWD00000PUS> was last up 0.8 point, or 0.19 percent, at 417.41.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The Dow Jones industrial average <.DJI> ended up 18.42 points, or 0.1 percent, at 18,419.3. The S&P 500 <.SPX> ended down 0.09 point, or flat, at 2,170.86. The Nasdaq Composite <.IXIC> gained 13.99 points, or 0.27 percent, at 5,227.21.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: Europe's broad FTSEurofirst 300 index <.FTEU3> closed down 0.08 percent, at 1,351.17.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: Brent crude <LCOc1> settled down $1.44, or 3.07 percent, at $45.45 a barrel. U.S. crude <CLc1> settled down $1.54, or 3.45 percent, at $43.16 a barrel.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: The dollar index <.DXY>, which measures the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, pulled back from Wednesday's more than three-week high of 96.255 and was last down 0.42 percent at 95.620 after the ISM data cast doubts on the strength of the U.S. economy.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: U.S. Treasury yields were little changed ahead of Friday's U.S. jobs data. Benchmark 10-year yields <US10YT=RR> were last at 1.570 percent, compared with 1.568 percent late on Wednesday.

Headline: U.S., European shares flat after U.S. data; oil falls
Text: "The scenario that the market is not ready for is for a strong number tomorrow and for the Fed to guide toward a rate hike in September," said Subadra Rajappa, head of U.S. rates strategy at Societe Generale. The dollar's weakness helped spot gold <XAU=> recover after touching a more than two-month low of $1,301.91 an ounce. U.S. gold futures <GCcv1> settled up 0.4 percent at $1,317.10. REUTERS

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: TORONTO - Canadian yoga wear retailer Lululemon Athletica Inc <LULU.O> reported comparable sales growth that fell short of analyst estimates, sending shares down nearly 9 percent on Thursday even as earnings were in line with expectations.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Second-quarter sales online and at stores open at least a year rose 5 percent, excluding exchange rate fluctuations. Analysts polled by research firm Consensus Metrix had expected a 5.9 percent increase.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Baird Equity Research analyst Mark Altschwager said the comparable sales miss would likely "fuel investor anxiety" given high expectations and the strong performance of Lululemon's stock. Before earnings, shares were up 46 percent year to date.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: On a conference call, Chief Financial Officer Stuart Haselden reminded analysts and investors that Lululemon had an online promotion in the second quarter of last year. Excluding the impact of that sale, he said, comparable sales would have increased about 2 more percentage points.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: "We did see traffic continue to be a headwind for us in the second quarter," said Haselden, adding that customers did make larger purchases, offsetting that trend. "I think we are not immune to what's happening from a macro standpoint."

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: U.S. retail sales were unexpectedly flat in July as consumers cut back on discretionary spending.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: The Vancouver-based company forecast fiscal third-quarter earnings between 42 and 44 cents a share. Analysts, on average, had expected earnings of 44 cents for that quarter, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Once a market darling thanks to its successful move into the U.S. market, a feat few Canadian retailers accomplish, the company has struggled with embarrassing product recalls and inventory problems in recent years.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Inventory levels fell 1 percent in the quarter, to $277.3 million.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: The company helped bring pricey women's yoga pants into the fashion mainstream before expanding into running and other sports. It now makes men's clothing, and its Ivivva line offers athletic clothing for younger clientele.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: It competes with Nike Inc <NKE.N> and Under Armour Inc <UA.N>, as well as mainstream clothing retailers from Gap Inc <GPS.N> to Nordstrom <JWN.N>.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Net income rose to $53.6 million, or 39 cents a share, from $47.7 million, or 34 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 14 percent to $514.5 million. Excluding a tax and related interest adjustment, earnings were 38 cents a share.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: On average, analysts had been expecting earnings of 38 cents a share and revenue of $515.5 million, according to Thomson Reuters I/B/E/S.

Headline: Lululemon same-store sales fall short, sending shares lower
Text: Shares dropped 8.6 percent to $70.07 in after-market trading. REUTERS

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: LONDON - Vilified retailer Sports Direct <SPD.L> takes another step in its attempted rehabilitation next week when it hosts members of the public and the media at its headquarters in northern England, slated for working conditions akin to a Victorian workhouse.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: The 450-store sportswear chain, known for discount offers such as mens' polo shirts priced at 5.50 pounds ($7.33), has been condemned by politicians for effectively paying workers less than the minimum wage and by shareholders for poor corporate governance.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: In a u-turn of its previous closed-door attitude, the group which also owns brands such as Lonsdale and Dunlop said last week it would invite non-shareholders to an open day on Sept. 7 to coincide with its annual shareholders' meeting (AGM), access to which has traditionally been restricted.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Attendees will be permitted to observe the AGM before being allowed to question the board, of which billionaire founder Mike Ashley, also owner of Newcastle United soccer club, is a member, then touring the site at Shirebrook in Derbyshire.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: The Shirebrook warehouse was slammed in a report by British lawmakers which said its working practices were closer to that of a Victorian workhouse than a reputable retailer.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: The poor publicity has already prompted a company response and in August thousands of Sports Direct workers were told they would receive back pay totaling 1 million pounds ($1.3 million after their wages fell short of the legal minimum.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Some investors in the chain, in which Ashley owns 55 percent, have rebuked its management and called on the board to launch a further independent review of the way it is run.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Yet an open day in itself is unlikely to appease the investors, given its shares languish 43 percent down this year, a drop which has wiped hundreds of millions of pounds off the value of Ashley's holding.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Investors have called for a review of board oversight, related party transactions and potential conflicts of interest, employment practices, acquisition strategy, oversight of supplier relationships and the management of stores.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Voting at the AGM will give them the chance to express their frustrations with the company, which has issued two profit warnings this year, most recently in March.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Shares in the firm also plunged after Britain voted to leave the EU, dragged down by the collapse in the value of the pound against the dollar and the fact Sports Direct had not hedged its currency for such an outcome.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Legal & General <LGEN.L>, Sports Direct's 11th largest shareholder, has already said it will oppose the re-election of Chairman Keith Hellawell as well as the other non-executive directors.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: Sports Direct is also due to publish next week a report on working practices following an internal investigation.

Headline: Under-fire Sports Direct opens the door after criticism
Text: ($1 = 0.7492 pounds) REUTERS

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: TIANJIN, China - By 2020, Beijing says automakers must meet tough new green standards to cut epic pollution in China's cities. As domestic firms bet heavily on electric cars to meet that goal, foreign peers are set to stay in a different, petrol-driven gear.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: In the latest sign of caution from global automakers in China, Germany's Audi last week unveiled a new factory for high-efficiency transmissions in Tianjin, to be used in petrol-powered cars. While Chinese firms go electric in the world's biggest auto market, Audi is intent on petrol engines that can run farther, cleaner, in tandem with hybrid technology.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: As China's electrified vehicle production booms, some international industry officials warn in private that the ambitious electric goals of domestic firms could prove too costly, too risky, too far from what consumers actually want - and not a good fit with their operations elsewhere. Still, China doled out $4.5 billion last year alone in green car subsidies.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: "In 2020, most cars we will sell will be combustion engines, so to fulfill (fuel consumption targets) you have to improve the consumption of each and every car of the Audi model range," Audi China chief Joachim Wedler said at the opening of the new plant. Wedler didn't comment on Chinese peers' electric car plans.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Automakers globally have struggled to agree on what a greener future will hold for the industry. In China, Beijing and state-linked automakers have thrown their weight behind electric vehicles - despite the fact that the electricity they need may be generated from burning coal.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Under Beijing's 2020 requirements, on average cars must consume less than 5 liters of petrol per 100 kilometers - nearly 30 percent below current standard levels.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Beijing has rolled out a raft of incentives to push domestic automakers - foreign brands generally aren't eligible - to build more electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles, spurring a quadrupling in sales of these so-called "new energy vehicles" (NEVs) in 2015. Even with that surge, just 1.4 percent of cars sold in the first seven months of 2016 were NEVs, as concerns linger over driving range and home charging.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: HYBRID COMPROMISE

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: A powertrain manager at a major foreign automaker's China joint venture said domestic companies' smaller scale made them nimbler. Many are also state-linked, therefore obliged to support government policy, the manager said, declining to be named as he was not authorized to speak to the media.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: For example, Geely - controlled by Li Shufu, a member of the government's political consultative body - wants 90 percent of all sales to be NEVs by 2020. Meanwhile, state-backed GAC Motor plans to be able to produce up to 400,000 green energy cars annually by the end of this year.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Foreign automakers, who must form joint ventures with local partners to produce cars in China, have to consider a different dynamic - how manufacturing strategies on the mainland correlate with their traditional businesses and customers elsewhere.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: The powertrain manager said his company, like Audi, is focusing on a more gradual strategy, developing more efficient engines as well as plug-in petrol-electric hybrids: an interim solution that will please a government intent on cutting harmful emissions.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: Of course, foreign automakers aren't avoiding NEVs entirely.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: General Motors' China venture last year pledged to spend $4 billion on electrification, developing 10 new energy models by 2020.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: In Tianjin, Audi China chief Wedler said the German firm and partner China FAW Group plan to launch their first locally produced plug-in hybrid vehicle this year, with a new imported car based on the same principle on the way next year.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: But Wedler acknowledged that as China's massive auto market evolves, automakers alone won't determine future directions.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: "The whole picture is driven by legislation," Wedler said.

Headline: In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
In China's electric car boom, global automakers select different gear
Text: ($1 = 6.6791 Chinese yuan renminbi) REUTERS

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: VLADIVOSTOK, Russia - Russia hopes to fetch more than $11 billion for a minority stake in the Kremlin's flagship oil producer Rosneft before the end of the year to plug budget holes caused by low crude prices, an industry source told Reuters on Friday.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: The sale will be complicated by sanctions imposed on Moscow over its actions in Ukraine and by many investors' wariness of putting money into Russia as well as volatile commodity markets.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: But Russia is hoping to repeat the success of Rosneft's initial share offering a decade ago when it raised $11 billion in one of the world's biggest such sales, despite concerns that investors would be spooked by Rosneft's purchase of most of the assets of oil firm YUKOS, bankrupted by the Kremlin.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: On Friday, Economy Minister Alexei Ulyukayev said his ministry had received documents needed to kick start the sale of 19.5 percent in Rosneft, including a valuation and proposals on terms of sale.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: An industry source familiar with the sale process said the stake had been valued at over $11 billion. The documents were submitted this week by Rosneftegas, which controls Rosneft on behalf of the government. Italian bank Intesa is advising Rosneftegas on the sale.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: In comments to Russian news agencies later on Friday, Ulyukayev said estimates the stake would be valued at around $11 billion were close to reality.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: After privatization, the government will keep 50 percent plus one share in Rosneft, the world's largest oil firm by reserves among listed companies.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Rosneft produces over a third of Russia's total output of 10.7 million barrels per day - a figure making Russia the world's biggest producer on a par with Saudi Arabia and the United States.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Russian President Vladimir Putin said the sale of the stake should take place before the end of the year and should involve strategic investors.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: "I think we should be aiming precisely for that type of investment. We are getting ready and are planning to do it this year," Putin told Bloomberg News.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Oil major BP owns just under 20 percent in Rosneft following the purchase of BP's Russian joint venture TNK-BP by Rosneft for $50 billion in 2013.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Rosneft's own market value has fallen to $55 billion since then as a result of low oil prices and sanctions imposed on Russia, Rosneft and its chief executive Igor Sechin, one of Putin's closest allies.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: At its initial public offering (IPO), Rosneft was worth nearly $80 billion. Western majors will find it difficult to invest in Rosneft due to sanctions but their place could be taken by Asian investors, including from China and India, which have been seeking to develop resources in Russia.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: Russia is effectively competing with many other resource rich countries for money from investors to compensate for low commodities prices.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: The world's largest non-listed oil firm by reserves and output, Saudi Aramco, is planning to list up to a 5 percent stake in the next two years, seeking an overall valuation of over $2 trillion.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: The industry source said Rosneftegas was asking the government to issue a decree guaranteeing a stable tax regime during the sale of the stake and beyond.

Headline: Russia aiming for over $11 billion from Rosneft stake sale
Text: "You cannot attract solid investors if the tax regime keeps changing," the source said. REUTERS

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: TAIPEI - Mega Financial Holding's <2886.TW> new chairman said the Taiwan state-controlled firm will strengthen risk management after its banking unit was hit by a U.S. fine for anti-money laundering violations, a case that has hugely embarrassed the island's government.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: "There are lots of doubts about us. We'll do whatever we can to find out what has happened," Michael C.S. Chang, 68, told reporters on Friday. "We are going to have a deep review and thorough reform."

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: Chang, who took up his post on Friday, will have to clean up what Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen has called a "ridiculous and incredible" matter, which is threatening to seriously undermine her three-month-old administration.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: New York authorities in mid-August slapped Mega International Commercial Bank with a $180 million fine for violations that included lax attention to risk exposure in Panama, the first time in a decade that a Taiwan-based financial institution has been penalized by U.S. authorities.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: Taiwanese financial regulators flew to Panama and New York this week to continue their investigation into whether Mega's activities led to breach of any Taiwanese laws.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: In 2009, Mega’s banking unit also ran afoul of Australian authorities over compliance and anti-money laundering rules.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: A trained accountant, Chang is known as a firefighter who has dealt with Taiwanese lenders in crisis before.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), during its previous term in office, appointed Chang as chairman of First Financial Holding Co <2892.TW>, another major state-controlled financial firm, where he held the position from 2006 to 2008.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: Chang’s predecessor, Shiu Kuang-si, quit on Wednesday two weeks after being appointed as chairman, in a bid to address allegations of conflicts of interest. Shiu was president of Mega when the suspect transactions took place, and he is the brother-in-law of Taiwan’s central bank chief.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: Another former Mega chairman, Tsai Yeou-tsair, who resigned in March, has been banned from travel abroad, while a former finance minister has been questioned by prosecutors.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: Taiwan Premier Lin Chuan has also had to weather calls to resign, with critics blaming him because the boards of state-controlled financial institutions are packed with government-selected appointees.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: The case has embroiled the central bank, which prides itself on being an independent institution and has been headed by Governor Perng Fai-nan, 77, for 18 years.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: This week the central bank was forced to issue rare statements stating Perng was involved in the Mega case only at the request of other financial regulators in Taiwan.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: Financial Supervisory Commission Vice Chairman Kuei Hsien-nung in early August requested Perng's help to plead with U.S. authorities, including the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, for more time for Mega to deal with the case.

Headline: Mega Financial's new chairman promises reform after U.S. fine
Text: “At the time, there was no information that showed Mega was related to any criminal liability,” Kuei told Reuters this week. “This was all done for the country. We would not have selfish intentions,” he said. REUTERS

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: SEOUL — Samsung Electronics is expected to announce a global recall of the large-screen smartphone Note 7 because of faulty batteries that catch fire, Yonhap reported, citing an unidentified company official.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: The world’s largest smartphone maker will announce the results of an investigation and a plan to deal with the issue as soon as this weekend, according to the news agency.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: “We are conducting a thorough inspection with our partners. We will share the findings and corrective measures as soon as possible. Samsung is fully committed to providing the highest quality products to our consumers,” said a Samsung spokesperson in Singapore in response to TODAY’s queries, declining to comment further on the issue.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: Samsung had gambled that positive reviews for the new device, which features iris-reading technology, would lead to robust sales. Analysts, who were growing increasingly bullish over Samsung’s smartphone sales amid slowing demand for Apple’s iPhones, have been raising their price targets for the company after it reported second-quarter profits above projections in July.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: The Galaxy smartphone maker said on Wednesday (Aug 31) that it delayed shipments of its new devices to mobile carriers, citing more testing needed for quality checks without elaborating on the cause. A series of reports since last week said that the Note7 had caught fire while charging and some customers uploaded pictures of their burned-out devices on the internet.

Headline: Samsung plans global recall of Galaxy Note7 phones: Yonhap
Text: Shares of Samsung Electronics declined 2 per cent to 1,587,000 won (S$1,930) Thursday, while its battery affiliate, Samsung SDI, lost 6.1 per cent to 108,500 won. BLOOMBERG

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: WASHINGTON - The U.S. International Trade Commission voted on Friday to lock in duties on imports of cold-rolled steel flat products from Brazil, India, South Korea and Britain but said imports from Russia were not injuring the U.S. industry.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: The U.S. Commerce Department had previously found the products from Brazil, India, South Korea and Russia were being unfairly subsidized and sold in the United States at below fair value, and that the products from Britain were also being dumped.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: In the case of Brazil, India, South Korea and Britain, the ITC said their imports were harming the U.S. industry, a finding that effectively locked in place duties proposed by the Commerce Department that range as high as 58.36 percent.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: Russian imports will not face duties, because of a lack of a finding of injury.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: After the Commerce Department's finding in July, Brazil indicated it would challenge any duties on its products at the World Trade Organization. Brazilian exports are dominated by Cia. Siderúrgica Nacional <CSNA3.SA> and Usinas Siderurgicas de Minas Gerais SA <USIM5.SA>.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: Other companies whose exports are affected by the decision include South Korean steelmakers POSCO <005490.KS> and Hyundai Steel Co <004020.KS>, Indian producer JSW Steel Ltd <JSTL.NS> and a British subsidiary of Tata Steel Ltd <TISC.NS>.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: Cold-rolled steel is used in automotive body panels, appliances, shipping containers and construction.

Headline: U.S. affirms duties on steel from Brazil, India, UK, South Korea
Text: U.S. officials launched probes into the imports after being petitioned by AK Steel Corp, a subsidiary of AK Steel Holding Co <AKS.N>; ArcelorMittal USA LLC, a unit of ArcelorMittal SA <ISPA.AS>; Nucor Corp <NUE.N>; Steel Dynamics Inc <STLD.O>; and United States Steel Corp <X.N>. REUTERS

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: TOKYO - Japan has asked the European Aviation Safety Agency to ensure a problem with Rolls-Royce <RR.L> engines powering Boeing <BA.N> 787 Dreamliners does not repeat to cause flight disruptions or affect safety.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Japan's Ministry of Land Infrastructure Transport and Tourism said on Friday it issued the request after ANA Holdings <9202.T>, Japan's biggest carrier, canceled 18 flights last month to repair corroded turbine blades in the Rolls-Royce engines on some its Dreamliner fleet.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Officials at the EASA were not immediately available for comment.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Since February, three ANA flights have experienced engine trouble, once on a flight from Kuala Lumpur to Tokyo, a second time in March on a jet traveling to Vietnam and most recently on a domestic route in August.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: The biggest operator of the carbon composite jet on Tuesday said it would replace the faulty turbine blades in all 100 engines on its 50 aircraft, an operation that could take as long as three years to complete.

Headline: Japan asks European aviation agency to ensure safety of Rolls-Royce 787 engines
Text: Of around 450 Dreamliners in operation worldwide, two fifths use the Rolls-Royce engines. Carriers can choose either the Rolls-Royce engines or General Electric Co's <GE.N> GEnx engines for their Dreamliners. REUTERS

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Lazard Ltd <LAZ.N>, the investment bank that advised SolarCity Corp <SCTY.O> on its $2.6 billion sale to Tesla Motors Inc <TSLA.O>, made an error in its analysis that discounted the value of the U.S. solar energy company by $400 million, a regulatory filing by Tesla showed on Wednesday.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: While the purchase price was within the valuation range that Lazard came up with for SolarCity even after accounting for the miscalculation, the error illustrates how even leading investment banks can make mistakes on some of the highest-profile deals.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: The mistake came after Tesla and SolarCity co-founder Elon Musk, who is the largest shareholder in both companies, went out of his way to create processes and structures, including a special board committee at SolarCity, aimed at alleviating concerns that he used his influence to force the two companies into a deal.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: An analysis by Lazard for SolarCity that indicated an equity value of between $14.75 and $34.00 per share was wrong because it double-counted some of the company's projected indebtedness, according to Tesla's filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: This was the result of a computational error "in certain SolarCity spreadsheets setting forth SolarCity’s financial information that Lazard used in its discounted cash flow valuation analyses," according to the filing.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: The error was not included in the valuation analysis performed by Tesla and its financial adviser, Evercore Partners Inc <EVR.N>, the filing said.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: After becoming aware of the mistake on Aug. 18, more than two weeks after the signing of the deal, Lazard realized the accurate valuation range was $18.75 to $37.75 per share.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: SolarCity and Tesla agreed however that the error would not change their view of the deal, according to the filing. The purchase price, to be paid with Tesla stock, equated to $25.37 per share.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Lazard, SolarCity and Tesla declined to comment.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Lazard ranks No. 10 in the Thomson Reuters Americas M&A league table so far this year, down two spots on where it was last year.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: This is not the first time a major investment bank has made a miscalculation on a big deal. An erroneous share count in the leveraged buyout of Tibco Software in 2014 by its financial adviser, Goldman Sachs Group Inc <GS.N>, led to a Tibco shareholder lawsuit that was settled earlier this year.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Goldman discovered it had overstated the number of Tibco's fully diluted shares only after the company agreed to sell itself to private equity firm Vista Equity.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: This had the effect of lowering the sale price to $4.14 billion from the $4.24 billion used in Goldman's fairness opinion. Nevertheless, Tibco decided not to ask Vista to pay the additional $100 million.

Headline: SolarCity adviser Lazard made mistake in Tesla deal analysis
Text: Goldman and Vista agreed to pay $30 million to the Tibco shareholders as part of the settlement, the Wall Street Journal reported at the time. REUTERS

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: LEXINGTON, Ky. - The U.S. labor market is at full strength and the Federal Reserve needs to be on a path of gradual interest rate increases, Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester said on Thursday.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "It seems like a gradual increase from a very low interest rate that we are at now is pretty compelling to me," Mester told reporters in Lexington, Kentucky, without saying whether she would support an increase at the Fed's policy meeting later this month.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Her comments reinforced the signals sent from some policymakers of a growing readiness to raise interest rates if data shows the economy is gathering strength.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last week she thought the case had grown stronger in recent months for an interest rate increase and Fed Vice Chair Stanley Fischer said Yellen's remarks were consistent with a view that the U.S. central bank might raise rates at its Sept. 20-21 policy meeting.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Mester, a voting member on the Fed's policy-setting committee, had earlier in the day told a philanthropy conference that the U.S. economy probably needs to generate between 75,000 and 150,000 jobs per month to keep the jobless rate stable.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Hiring has been stronger than that this year and the U.S. jobless rate is currently at 4.9 percent.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "The economy is basically at full employment," Mester said.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: The U.S. Labor Department's monthly employment report on Friday is expected to show the economy added 180,000 jobs in August <USNFAR=ECI>, according to the median forecast in a Reuters poll.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Mester said she said she did not share the view labor activists delivered to Fed officials last week that low interest rates could help resolve racial income and employment gaps in America.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: "I do not believe that at this point in the business cycle the current very low level of interest rates is an effective solution to these longer-run issues," she said.

Headline: Fed's Mester says case for rate increases is compelling
Text: Mester said last week it makes sense for the Fed to start raising rates. REUTERS

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: WASHINGTON — Employers in the United States created fewer jobs than forecast in August after two straight months of robust gains, lowering the likelihood that the central bank will raise its key interest rate later this month.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: Non-farm payrolls rose by 151,000 jobs last month after an upwardly revised 275,000 increase in July, with hiring in manufacturing and construction sectors declining, the Labor Department said yesterday. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 4.9 per cent as more people entered the job market. Economists polled by Reuters had forecast payrolls rising 180,000 last month and the unemployment rate slipping one-tenth of a percentage point to 4.8 per cent.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: Wall Street opened higher yesterday after the data release, which comes more than two weeks before the Federal Reserve’s Sept 20-21 policy meeting. About five minutes after the opening bell in New York, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.5 per cent at 18,512. The greenback dropped 0.4 per cent to US$1.1240 per euro and fell at a similar pace to 102.87 yen.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: “We had a couple of above-average numbers in the last two months. This is a below-average number. All that suggests the job market is OK but it probably does put September off the table” for an interest rate rise, Mr Jeff Kleintop, chief global investment strategist at financial services firm Charles Schwab said on CNBC TV.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: The Fed has three more policy meetings this year. Fed funds futures data showed the probability of a rate hike in the September meeting falling to 12 per cent from the 27 per cent level before the job data. The likelihood of a rate increase by November fell to 21 per cent from 32 per cent, while the probability of such a move by December dropped to 52 per cent from 58 per cent.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: Analysts said despite the weaker-than-expected job creation, last month’s payrolls data could still be sufficient to push the Fed to tighten policy in December. The rise in payrolls reinforces views that the world’s largest economy has regained speed after almost stalling in the first half of the year.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: The central bank lifted its benchmark overnight interest rate to between 0.25 and 0.5 per cent at the end of last year for the first time in nearly a decade, but has held it steady since amid concerns over persistently low inflation. Fed Chair Janet Yellen said last Friday that the case for raising borrowing costs had strengthened in recent months. With the labour market near full employment and the economy’s recovery from the 2007-09 recession showing signs of ageing, a slowdown in job growth is normal. Ms Yellen has said the economy needs to create just under 100,000 jobs a month to keep up with population growth.

Headline: US job creation softer than forecast, lowers rate hike chance
Text: The timing of the next rate hike could also be determined by wage growth. Average hourly earnings increased three cents in August to US$25.73, or a 0.1 per cent rise, after a solid 0.3 per cent rise in July. The moderation in gains pulled down the year-on-year gain to 2.4 per cent from 2.6 per cent in July. AGENCIES

Headline: Weak global economy, strong dollar weighing on U.S. factories: U.S. labor secretary
Text: WASHINGTON - U.S. Labor Secretary Thomas Perez said on Friday the U.S. economy was enjoying solid job and wage growth, but that a weak global expansion and strong U.S. dollar were hurting the factory sector.

Headline: Weak global economy, strong dollar weighing on U.S. factories: U.S. labor secretary
Text: "When you have the global economy not recovering the way our economy is and when you have that strong dollar, when you're making things to sell to other countries they are now more expensive and the demand for those products ... is not what it needs to be," Perez told CNBC. "Those are the headwinds that we're seeing in manufacturing." REUTERS

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: SINGAPORE — Singapore has maintained its position as the largest foreign exchange (FX) centre in the Asia-Pacific region and the third largest globally after London and New York, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said yesterday.

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: The average daily forex trading volume in Singapore was US$517 billion (S$705 billion) in April, up 35 per cent from US$383 billion in April 2013, when the Bank for International Settlements last conducted its Triennial Central Bank Survey of Foreign Exchange and Derivatives Market Activity.

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: Singapore’s share of global forex volumes has also grown to 7.9 per cent in 2016, from 5.7 per cent three years ago. Globally, trading in forex markets averaged US$5.1 trillion per day in April, down from US$5.4 trillion in April 2013.

Headline: S’pore remains largest forex centre in the Asia-Pacific
Text: “Singapore is building on its role as the pre-eminent marketplace in Asia for global and regional banks, non-bank financial institutions and corporate treasurers to manage their FX risks. MAS is working with the industry to further enhance price discovery, liquidity and transparency in our FX market by strengthening electronic trading capabilities and anchoring market infrastructure,” said Ms Jacqueline Loh, Deputy Managing Director of MAS in a statement.
